The reports shall be filed with the finance director when required by said official, and shall set forth the gross sales from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, the amount of tax collection thereon, or such other information as the finance director may prescribe. 
(i)  Violations. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in City Charter section 4.13. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this section is committed, continued or permitted by such person, and shall be punished accordingly. Any licensee who fails to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the finance director, or who renders a false or fraudulent return, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as aforesaid. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-167. - Delinquency. 
If after forty-five (45) days any excise tax imposed by this division is not paid by any holder of a wholesale alcoholic beverage license, then the excise tax assessed against such license holder shall become delinquent and all of the provisions of this Code relative to the collection of delinquent taxes shall be applicable for the collection of such excise tax. Alcoholic beverages on which city taxes have not been paid are subject to seizure and may be destroyed or sold by public sale as provided by law. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Secs. 3-168—3-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HEARING OFFICERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 3-191. - Hearing by hearing officers. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, hearings provided for pursuant to section 3-85 may be held, at the discretion of the council, by a hearing officer pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-192. - Appointment of hearing officer. 
The hearing officer shall be such person as shall be appointed by the city manager from time to time for such purpose. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-193. - Qualifications of hearing officer. 
Any hearing officer appointed by the city manager pursuant to this chapter shall be a resident of the state, shall be neither an employee nor a full time elected or appointed employee, officer or official of the city, nor the spouse of any such person except that the municipal judge shall, notwithstanding any other provision hereof, be for all purposes hereof a person qualified to act as a hearing officer; and shall be either an attorney who is a member in good standing of the state bar or be a person who, in the sole opinion of the city manager, is experienced in dispute resolution. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-194. - Notice of hearing. 
The city manager shall furnish, or cause to be furnished, to the licensee involved at least ten (10) days prior to the scheduled date of the hearing a notice with respect to such hearing which shall include the time, date, place and purpose thereof as well as the name of the hearing officer before whom such hearing shall be conducted. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-195. - Purpose of hearing. 
The purpose of the hearing shall be to: 
(1)  Afford officials and employees of the city and others an opportunity to present grounds and/or reasons for the suspension and/or revocation of the license in issue; 
(2)  Afford officials and employees of the city and others an opportunity to present the nature of prior violations relative to the license and license in issue, if any, which are considered to be relevant to the issues involved; 
(3)  Afford the licensee an opportunity to respond to any and all prior alleged violations and to the circumstances surrounding any such prior alleged violations; to respond to any evidence with respect to any alleged violations; to present evidence, matters, and witnesses relative to compliance by licensee with the provisions of this chapter and any other matter relative to the purpose as is of the hearing and the issues to be resolved; to propose recommendations relative to proposed actions with respect to the license in issue; to otherwise generally respond to any and all recommendations, reasons and grounds submitted relative to the license in issue; and to otherwise generally present matters relative to possible action by the city in connection with such licensee and license. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-196. - Conduct of disciplinary hearing. 
In connection with the conduct of the disciplinary hearing; 
(1)  The hearing officer shall have the authority to: 
a.  Administer oaths and affirmations to witnesses who testify or offer evidence; 
b.  Issue subpoenas but only to the extent authorized pursuant to the provisions of this chapter; 
c.  Generally regulate and manage the conduct of the hearing; 
d.  Set the time and place for any continuation or postponement of the hearing; 
e.  Determine whether or not to require or accept the filing of briefs and if so the time period therefor; 
f.  Rule upon the admissibility of evidence and offers of proof submitted; 
g.  Rule inappropriate and out of order any despairing, irrelevant or inappropriate matter; 
h.  Limit evidence, statements, arguments and presentations which may [be] unduly lengthy, inappropriate, not germane, not relevant or otherwise inappropriate; 
i.  Reprimand and/or exclude from the hearing any person who fails to conduct themselves in an orderly and courteous manner during the hearing or fails to comply with the rulings of the hearing officer relative to the conduct of the hearing; and 
j.  Otherwise generally conduct the hearing in an orderly manner as in the nature of a hearing before a special master in the superior courts of the state. 
(2)  Continuances may be granted by the hearing officer upon motion of any party or upon the hearing officer's own motion provided that any such continuance shall be granted only to a specific date, time, and space and no such continuance shall be granted for more than fourteen (14) calendar days. 
(3)  Subpoenas may be issued by the hearing officer to any employee of the city or any elected or appointed officer or official of the city upon the timely request therefor by any party; provided, however, that the hearing officer does not have the authority or the power to issue any subpoena to any person other than employees, officers, or officials of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-197. - Rights of licensee at disciplinary hearing. 
(a)  At a disciplinary hearing the licensee involved shall be entitled to: 
(1)  Be represented by an attorney or by other representative; 
(2)  Present matters and witnesses relevant to the purpose of the hearing and the issues to be determined; 
(3)  Question those persons presenting matters which are adverse to the interest of the licensee but only to the extent of relevance, as determined by the hearing officer, to the purposes of the hearing and to the issues to be determined; and 
(4)  Offer suggestions or recommendations relative to the nature and/or extent of action, if any, taken with respect to the license and licensee in issue. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter a licensee subject to such hearing shall not be required to give any testimony or to answer any question with respect to such proceedings nor shall the licensee be required to attend such hearing or to present any evidence or matters in connections therewith. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-198. - Record of hearing. 
A record with respect to hearings shall be maintained by the city clerk which shall consist of and include the following: 
(1)  All written reports, recommendations, responses, objects and other written matters filed in connection with such hearing; 
(2)  All documents, instruments and other memorandum introduced into evidence at such hearing; 
(3)  A written statement to be prepared by the hearing officer with respect to all matters, if any, officially noticed by the hearing officer; 
(4)  All written orders and findings of the hearing officer; and 
(5)  A mechanical recording of the hearing or in lieu thereof a transcript thereof if determined by the hearing officer to be appropriate. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-199. - Recordation of hearing and transcript. 
(a)  The hearing shall be mechanically recorded with the product of such recording being a part of the record of such matter upon completion thereof. 
(b)  Any interested party shall be entitled to employ at their own expense and utilize a stenographic reporter in connection with the hearing. 
(c)  Should the hearing officer so direct, a stenographic reporter shall be utilized in connection with the hearing for the purposes of recording the hearing with the cost thereof to be paid by the city. Should the hearing officer so direct, the stenographic reporter shall prepare a transcript of the hearing with the cost thereof to be paid by the city. In the event the hearing officer so directs the preparation of a transcript by the stenographic reporter then the licensee, upon payment directly to the stenographic reporter of the cost thereof, shall be entitled to a copy of the transcript so prepared. In the event that the hearing officer does not direct the preparation of a transcript then either the city or the licensee shall be entitled to request preparation of a transcript of the hearing from such stenographic reporter upon payment to the stenographic reporter of the cost thereof. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-200. - Representation of city at hearing. 
The city shall be represented at hearings by the city manager and upon his request by the office of the city attorney. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-201. - Informal disposition. 
An informal disposition of a hearing may be made at any stage by stipulation or consent finding, all subject to approval thereof by the hearing officer. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-202. - Procedure following hearing by hearing officers. 
Within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of the conclusion of such hearing, the hearing officer shall prepare and file with the city clerk a written report which shall contain the following: 
(1)  Findings of fact with respect to incidents, actions and/or behavior of the licensee in issue and/or the agents, servants and/or employees thereof which are relevant to the matters and issues to be determined; 
(2)  Findings of fact with respect to prior matters involving the licensee which are relevant to the issues to be determined; 
(3)  Findings of fact with respect to provisions of this chapter, breached or violated by the licensee, if any, which were determined by the hearing officer to be relevant to the issues to be determined; 
(4)  Findings of fact with respect to recommendations of city officials, if any, and the reasons, if any are presented, for such recommendations; and 
(5)  The recommendation of the hearing officer, if any, with respect to what action should be taken relative to the licensee in issue and, if any, in the extent and nature thereof. Such written report of the hearing officer, together with the record in connection with such hearing, shall be promptly filed with the city clerk and a copy of such report of the hearing officer shall be furnished by the hearing officer to the licensee, to the city manager and to the city attorney. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-203. - Right to respond and object to report of hearing officer. 
(a)  Both the licensee and the city manager shall be entitled, within fifteen (15) calendar days after being furnished with such report, to file with the city clerk written objections to any finding of fact or recommendation of the hearing officer. 
(b)  Additionally, both the city manager and the licensee or the employee shall be entitled, within fifteen (15) calendar days after being furnished with such report of the hearing officer, to file a request with the city manager for a de novo hearing before the city council. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-204. - Right of city council to conduct de novo hearing. 
Upon the filing of a request within fifteen (15) calendar days of the furnishing of the report of the hearing officer, or upon the decision of the city council on its own motion, the city council shall be entitled to conduct a de novo hearing with respect to the issues involved in connection with such license and licensee, which hearing shall be conducted upon same basis and accordance with same procedures as the hearing before the hearing officer. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-205. - Determination by city council following hearing. 
(a)  Following the filing of the report of the hearing officer and the lapse of the fifteen-day period for the filing of objections to the report of the hearing officer, the city council shall proceed to make a determination with respect to the issues relative to the license and the licensee involved. 
(b)  Such determination shall be based upon the written report and recommendations, if any, of the hearing officer and the written objections to the report of the hearing officer except in the event of a de novo hearing. 
(c)  In the event of a de novo hearing the city council shall proceed to conduct a hearing upon the relevant issues and following such hearing make a determination based upon matters presented at such do novo hearing. 
(d)  Such determination shall be made by the city council in written form within 30 calendar days following lapse of the time for the filing of objections to the report of the hearing officer, or in the event of the determination by the city council to conduct a de novo hearing then within thirty (30) calendar days following the conclusion thereof, with copies of such written determination to be promptly furnished by the city clerk to the city manager, to the city attorney and to the licensee. 
(e)  Such determination shall include what action with respect to the license and licensee, if any, shall be taken including the extent, duration and exact nature thereof as well as the effective date of the commencement of such action. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Sec. 3-206. - Reconsideration. 
(a)  Both the city manager and the licensee shall be entitled to file a request, within ten (10) calendar days of the date of receipt of the written determination of the city council, for reconsideration of the decision of the city council. 
(b)  The city council shall have the right, in the sole discretion of the city council, to reconsider any decision of the city council based upon a request therefor which demonstrates either the existence of substantial new evidence not available to the party prior to the hearing or providential cause. 
(Ord. of 12-28-09) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate, license and tax the keeping of animals and fowl, § 2-9(qq). 
Cross reference— Buildings, Ch. 5; health and sanitation, Ch. 12; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide animal control services, Ga. Code Ann., § 2-6102; cruelty to animals, Ga. Code Ann., § 26-2802. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Keeping, grazing near buildings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any pen, coop or enclosure for animals or fowl or to permit any animal or fowl to be kept, maintained or grazed within two hundred and fifty (250) feet of any house or building where people reside or work. This section shall not apply to any house or building on the same premises where such animal or fowl is kept or maintained, nor shall it apply to dogs or cats as household pets, but it shall apply to dog kennels where more than three (3) dogs are kept. 
Sec. 4-2. - Vicious animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person to maintain or harbor within the city a manifestly vicious animal unless the same is securely, but humanely, confined or restrained in such manner as to prevent such animal from attacking or biting a person or another animal. It shall be prima facie evidence of viciousness if an animal, without provocation, fiercely attacks or bites persons or animals not on the owner's premises. 
(Code 1967, § 4-5) 
State Law reference— Liability for damages caused by vicious animals, Ga. Code Ann., § 105-110. 
Sec. 4-3. - Keeping so as to constitute nuisance or be offensive. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or permit any animal or fowl in the city in such manner as to create an unsanitary or obnoxious condition, or to become noisy, offensive or a nuisance to neighbors or citizens of the city, or to disturb the peace of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 4-7) 
Sec. 4-4. - Notice to correct offensive conditions. 
Should a complaint to the police department arise from the causes referred to in section 4-3, the person involved shall be properly notified by a member of the police department and given an adequate time to either dispose of the animal or fowl or eliminate the cause of the complaint. 
(Code 1967, § 4-8) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the abatement of nuisances, § 2-9(rr). 
Sec. 4-5. - Animals running at large prohibited; pen regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep chickens, turkeys, pigeons, goats, cows, horses, mules, hogs or pigs in the city unless such party or parties provide suitable coops, pens, lots and enclosures for such fowl or animals, and keep said fowl and animals enclosed and confined therein so that they cannot escape therefrom, and provide further that the following conditions are complied with, as set out below. 
(b)  Wherever fowl are kept as above described, the pens, lots or such other enclosures must not have any part or section thereof located within fifty (50) feet of a residence, hotel, hospital, church or other building where people congregate or reside. 
(c)  Whenever cows, horses, mules, goats, hogs or pigs are kept, the pen, stable, lot, barn or enclosure must not have any part or section thereof located within one hundred fifty (150) feet of a residence, hotel, church, restaurant or other building where people reside or congregate. 
(d)  Whenever fowl and animals are kept as above-mentioned, the pen, lot, stable, coop and/or other enclosure must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times so as not to create a fly breeding place or offensive odors, thereby causing a nuisance and menace to public health. The sanitary safety and nuisance factors of such areas, coops, pens or stables shall be judged by the health authority of the city, whose decision shall be final. 
(e)  Whenever cows, horses, mules or such animals including hogs and pigs are kept, the pen, lot and stables must be graded to drain, or drainage ways must be provided in order to keep said area free of standing water. 
(f)  Wherever cows, horses, mules, hogs, pigs or goats are kept, the manure must be picked up daily and stored, but never allowed to be stored more than four (4) continuous or consecutive days. It shall then be hauled away from the premises and spread in such a manner as not to cause fly breeding. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1) 
Sec. 4-6. - Removal of dead animals. 
It shall be the duty of the owner or persons responsible for any dead animal in the city to remove or dispose of the same in a sanitary and inoffensive manner within twenty-four (24) hours of learning of such dead animal. If not removed within said time, the city may remove the animal and charge the costs thereof against the owner or person responsible. 
(Code 1967, § 4-2) 
State Law reference— Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A., § 62-21. 
Sec. 4-7. - City declared bird sanctuary. 
The entire area within the corporate limits of the city shall be, and the same is hereby designated and established, as a bird sanctuary. 
(Code 1967, § 4-9) 
State Law reference— Protection of birds, nests and eggs, O.C.G.A., § 45-530. 
Secs. 4-8—4-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Dogs, O.C.G.A., §§ 62-20, 62-9927. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 9, 2008, amended division 1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 1 consisted of §§ 4-21—4-31, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 5-77, adopted Aug. 15, 1977. 

Sec. 4-24. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned animal means any domesticated animal which has been placed upon public property or within a public building unattended or uncared for, or upon or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or tenant of the private property and is unattended or uncared for. A domesticated animal shall also be considered as abandoned when it has been upon or within the property of the owner or custodian of such animal for a period of time in excess of thirty-six (36) hours unattended and without proper food and water. 
Abused animal means any animal which is any of the following: 
(1)  Mistreated, beaten, tormented or teased. 
(2)  Deprived of water, food or shelter. 
(3)  Kept under unsanitary conditions. 
(4)  Abandoned. 
(5)  Trained for fighting other animals. 
(6)  Transported in the trunk of any vehicle. 
(7)  Left unattended in a vehicle in extreme heat without proper ventilation. 
Altered animal shall mean a female animal which has been spayed or a male animal which has been castrated (neutered) by a licensed veterinarian in order to render the animal incapable of reproducing. 
Animal at large means any animal not under restraint. 
Animal control center means the facility designated by city council for the detention of animals. 
Animal control officer means any person so designated by the city to perform the duties prescribed by this chapter. 
Animal under restraint means any animal humanely secured by a leash or lead or enclosed by way of fence or other enclosure or under the control of a responsible and competent person and obedient to that person's commands, and the person being present with the animal or the animal confined within a vehicle parked or in motion. 
Companion animal means a domesticated animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. Such pets include, but are not limited to birds, cats, dogs, hamsters, horses, mice, reptiles, domesticated wild animals, exotic animals and other animals associated with human environment. 
Dangerous animal means any animal which constitutes a physical threat to human beings or other domestic animals by virtue of a known propensity to endanger life by an unprovoked assault or by biting so as to cause serious bodily harm or an animal trained, owned or harbored for the purpose, primarily or in part, of animal fighting. An animal shall not be deemed dangerous if: 
(1)  It bites, attacks or menaces: 
a.  Anyone assaulting the owner; 
b.  A trespasser on the property of the owner; or 
c.  Any person or other animal who has tormented or abused it; 
(2)  It is otherwise acting in defense of an attack from a person or other animal upon the owner or other person; or 
(3)  It is protecting or defending its young or other animal. 
Department means the police department. 
Director means the animal control officer. 
Domesticated animal means an animal that is accustomed to living in or about the habitation of people, including, but not limited to cats, cows, dogs, fowl, horses, swine, domesticated wild animals and/or exotic animals. 
Electronic animal confinement system shall mean a commercially produced and professionally installed electronic fence which requires an electrically generated perimeter which is not visible, and that the animal within the perimeter wear an electronic collar which produces an electric shock to the animal when the perimeter is approached. 
Guard dog means any dog which has been trained to attack persons independently or upon oral command and any dog which, while not so trained, is reasonably expected to perform as a guardian of its owner and/or the property upon and within which the dog is located. 
Owner means any person owning, keeping, harboring or acting as custodian of a domesticated animal. 
Public nuisance or public nuisance animal means any animal which: 
(1)  Is found at large in violation of section 4-31 or 4-34; 
(2)  Is unlicensed (unregistered) in violation of section 4-35; 
(3)  Is trained, owned or harbored for the purpose, primarily or in part, of dogfighting; 
(4)  Is dangerous, as defined, and is not restrained or confined, as provided for in sections 4-33 and 4-34; 
(5)  Produces, because of quantity, manner or method in which the animals are domesticated or maintained, unsanitary conditions in the city; or 
(6)  Is inimical to the public health, welfare or safety according to the rules and regulations promulgated by the board of health, which rules and regulations are incorporated herein and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-25. - Animal control center. 
There is created an animal control center for the city under the supervision of the director and the center shall be staffed with such personnel as may from time to time be authorized in the city budget and appropriations. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-26. - Enforcement generally. 
(a)  The primary responsibility for the enforcement of this chapter shall be vested in the director who may call upon the city police from time to time to assist in the enforcement of this chapter. The director may also be designated by the mayor and council as the official rabies control officer for the city. The director may, in the exercise of authority as the director and as the chief rabies control officer for the city, delegate the enforcement responsibilities of this chapter to city employees. 
(b)  Upon information made known to or complaint lodged with the director or the director's authorized representative that any owner, possessor or custodian of any animal is in violation of this chapter, the director or the director's authorized representative shall cause a summons to be issued requiring the owner, possessor or custodian of the animal to appear before a judge of the municipal court on a day and time certain, then and there to stand trial for the violation of this chapter. If a violation of this chapter has not been personally witnessed by the director or the director's authorized representative or other employee of the city, a subpoena shall be issued to the person making the complaint to be and appear on the day and time set for trial, then and there to testify on behalf of the city. The director will refuse to respond to anonymous complaints. 
(c)  If the owner, possessor or custodian of any dog or animal is not known and such dog or animal is upon the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds or other public places or premises or the property of another without that property owner's permission as prohibited by this chapter, upon complaint made to or information made known to the animal control center, it shall be the duty of the director or the director's authorized representative to immediately take possession of such dog or animal and impound it in a facility designated for the detention of animals. Once impounded, an animal shall be kept for a period of time as defined in section 4-30; thereafter, if the animal is not claimed by anyone after a reasonable effort has been made to locate the owner, possessor or custodian of the animal as hereinafter provided, the animal may be disposed of in a humane fashion or in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 4 (§ 4-1-1 et seq.). 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-27. - Fee schedule and miscellaneous regulations. 
(a)  Fees to be collected by the director shall be as established by action of city council, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Dogs and cats adopted or reclaimed must have a current rabies certificate or the owner must pay a late fee in the amount established by action of the mayor and council, a copy of which is on file in the office of the clerk of the City of Nashville, and dogs and cats adopted or reclaimed without a current inoculation must receive a rabies inoculation within five (5) days. 
(c)  For any canine or feline adopted from the animal control center, a fee in the amount established by action of the city council, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, will be charged to have the animal spayed or neutered by a veterinarian participating in the spay/neuter program. The fee will be paid to the veterinarian by the city upon the return of the certificate issued by the city to the veterinarian performing the surgery. The certificate for puppies and kittens will be honored for six (6) months from the date of issue, and thirty (30) days from the date of issue for adult dogs and cats. 
(d)  The fees to be paid for the following shall be in the amount established by action of the city council, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk: 
(1)  For adoption of cats, dogs, kittens and puppies. 
(2)  For boarding impounded animals. 
(3)  As an impoundment fee. 
(4)  As an owner's rabies tag registration fee for altered and unaltered animals: 
a.  Kitten or puppy six (6) months of age or less at time of license application, ten dollars ($10.00). 
b.  Cat or dog with a veterinarian exemption due to a permanent health problem or advanced age (ten (10) years or older) which prevents surgery, ten dollars ($10.00). Such exemption must be noted on the rabies certificate by the vaccinating veterinarian. 
c.  Altered cat or dog, ten dollars ($10.00). (Proof of spay/neuter must accompany animal license application). 
d.  Unaltered cat or dog seven (7) months to ten (10) years, ten dollars ($10.00). 
(5)  For seizing and impounding an animal suspected of being rabid. 
(6)  Any other fees deemed necessary or which are incurred while an animal is in the custody of the animal control center. 
(7)  For a nonrefundable user fee for live animal traps, ten dollars ($10.00) per trap. 
(8)  For emergency transportation of an injured animal to a veterinarian for the animal owner, twenty dollars ($20.00) per animal. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-28. - Public nuisances prohibited. 
It is unlawful to knowingly keep, own, harbor or act as custodian of a public nuisance animal. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-29. - Dangerous animals. 
(a)  If a law enforcement agent of the city has probable cause to believe that a dangerous animal is being harbored in violation of this chapter, such agent may do one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Order the violation immediately corrected and cite the owner or keeper to appear in court for the violation. 
(2)  If the violation cannot be immediately corrected and the animal is posing an imminent, serious threat to human beings or other domestic animals, the animal may be seized and impounded, in which case the owner or keeper will be cited to appear in court for the violation. At the owner's request and expense, such impoundment may be at a veterinarian or licensed kennel of the owner's choosing. If the court rules that the animal is not dangerous, it will be released to the owner. If the court rules that it is dangerous, the animal will be released to the owner after payment of any fees and penalties, and upon presentation of proof that the animal will now be kept restrained or confined as specified in this chapter. 
(b)  If the owner or keeper of an alleged dangerous animal impounded for violation of this chapter presents proof that the animal will now be kept in compliance with this chapter, the animal will be released upon payment of any fees and penalties due. 
(c)  If, within fifteen (15) days after impoundment or such later time as specified by the court, the owner or keeper of an alleged dangerous animal fails to either provide proof that the animal will now be kept restrained or confined in compliance with the provisions of this chapter or fails to reclaim it from animal control after impoundment, and if it cannot be adopted by someone providing proof that it will be kept restrained or confined as specified in this chapter, it will be humanely euthanized. 
(d)  If the owner or keeper of an animal previously deemed a dangerous animal by the court fails to keep the dangerous animal restrained or confined in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and if it cannot be adopted by someone who does not reside in the same household as the owner or keeper providing proof that it will be kept restrained or confined as specified in this chapter, it shall be humanely euthanized. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-30. - Notice to owner of impounded animal. 
(a)  Upon impounding any dog or other animal, the city shall cause to be made a prompt and reasonable effort to locate the animal's owner, possessor or custodian and, upon location thereof, shall send to such owner, possessor or custodian notification of impoundment. For the purpose of this section, it shall be deemed sufficient notice if a notification of impoundment is sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner named on the most recent rabies certificate on file at the address indicated thereon. If the dog or animal is not claimed by the owner, possessor or custodian thereof within three (3) days from the receipt of the certified letter giving notice of impoundment or returning of letter by the post office, then it shall be the duty of the city to dispose of the dog or other animal. If the impounded dog or animal is not wearing a rabies tag or a tag identifying the name, address and telephone number of the dog's or animal's owner, possessor or custodian, the city may dispose of the dog or animal following five (5) days after it is impounded. 
(b)  In addition, if the dog or animal is not claimed as provided for herein, the city, after being satisfied that the dog or animal is in good health, may offer the dog or animal for adoption to any person after the required notification of impoundment has been given. 
(c)  In no event shall any animal be redeemed by its lawful owner, possessor or custodian until the required fees established for boarding the animal are paid. 
(d)  If for any reason as hereinabove described any animal is impounded, or if any owner, possessor or custodian of any animal violates any of the duties imposed by this chapter, in addition to penalties imposed, such owner, possessor or custodian shall be conclusively presumed to have given consent to the adoption of the impounded animal or to have given consent to dispose of the animal in a humane fashion. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-31. - Running at large. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of an animal, or anyone having custody of any animal, to allow it to run at large unattended on or about the streets and highways of the City of Nashville, or on the property of another person without permission of the owner of that property or of the person in possession of that property. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-32. - General responsibilities of owners. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any animal, or anyone having possession or custody of any animal, to exercise reasonable care and to take all necessary steps and precautions to protect other people, property and animals from injuries or damages which might result from such animal's behavior, regardless of whether such behavior is motivated by mischievousness, playfulness or ferocity. 
(b)  If the owner or keeper of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to ensure that there is compliance provisions of this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who possesses, harbors or is in charge of any animal not to immediately remove excrement deposited by the animal on any street right-of-way, public or private property. It shall be the duty of any person having custody and control of any animal, while not on their own property, to have in their possession a device, equipment, or other means for the picking up and removal of animal excrement. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any animal aiding the handicapped (e.g., guide dog) or to an animal when in police or rescue activities. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-33. - Keeping animal under restraint—While on owner's property. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any animal, or anyone having possession or custody of any animal, to ensure that the animal is kept under restraint and that reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent the animal from leaving, while unattended, the real property limits of its owner, possessor or custodian, and to ensure that: 
(1)  The animal is securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, pen or other enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape on its own volition. Such enclosure must be securely locked at any time the animal is left unattended. 
(2)  The animal is on a leash and under the control of a competent person; or is off leash and obedient to that person's command and that person is present with the animal any time it is not restrained as provided for in paragraphs (1) and (3) of this subsection while on the owner's property. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any animal to be confined upon the premises of the owner or custodian of such animal by a leash or chain of less than ten (10) feet in length and equipped with swivels at both ends, except by a leash which is a free running line. Any animal confined by leash or chain shall be restrained at least six (6) feet from all entrance and exit locations to the property or building within which the animal is located. Animals shall not be restrained by leash or chain in a manner and location that precludes unrestricted and safe ingress and egress by animal control or law enforcement personnel. 
(b)  Additional requirements for precautions to be taken by owners of dangerous animals are: 
(1)  Whenever outside of its enclosure as provided for in paragraph (a)(1) of this section, but on the owner's property, a dangerous dog must be attended by the owner and restrained by a secure collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(2)  No dangerous animal shall be chained, tethered or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post or building, outside of its own enclosure as provided for in paragraph (a)(1) of this section. 
(3)  In addition to the requirements in paragraph (a)(1) of this section for owners of dangerous animals who maintain their animals out-of-doors, a portion of their property should be fenced with a perimeter or area fence. Within this perimeter fence, the dangerous animal must be humanely confined inside a pen or kennel of adequate size. The pen or kennel may not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence. The kennel or pen must have secure sides and a secure top attached to all sides; the sides must be sunken into a concrete pad of at least two-inch thickness or securely attached to a wire bottom. The gate to the kennel must be locked. 
(c)  An electronic animal confinement system shall be considered an acceptable enclosure when: 
(1)  The equipment is maintained and in continuous working order, and the animal to be contained within wears the appropriate electronic collar when within the fence perimeters. 
(2)  Permanent and prominently displayed signs are posted at twenty-five-foot intervals around the entire perimeter of the electronic animal confinement system. The signs shall be no smaller than six (6) inches square, and shall read: "Caution—Animal(s) on this property contained by an electronic animal confinement system." 
(d)  In cases where an animal has been deemed dangerous by the court, or has been trained to be a guard dog, an electronic animal confinement system may not be used as either the primary or secondary fence. 
(e)  Individuals who contain their animal(s) by means of an electronic animal confinement system and are found in violation of this section or have been deemed as restraining a dangerous animal(s) pursuant to section 4-29 shall thereafter restrain the animal(s) in the manner provided in subsections (a) and (b) above. 
(f)  Failure to keep any animal confined or under restraint as provided for in this section shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-34. - Same—While off owner's property. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any animal or anyone having possession of any animal to keep the animal under restraint and control at all times while the animal is off the real property limits of the owner, possessor or custodian. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, an animal is deemed under control when: 
(1)  It is securely confined within a vehicle, parked or in motion; 
(2)  It is properly confined with a secure enclosure with the permission of the owner of the property where the enclosure is located; or 
(3)  It is securely restrained by a leash or other device held by a competent person. 
(c)  Additional requirements for precautions to be taken by owners of dangerous animals are that, except when being transported in and securely confined within a vehicle, no dangerous animal shall be permitted off the property of its owner, except when it is: 
(1)  Attended by its owner; 
(2)  Restrained by secure collar and leash (not to exceed six (6) feet in length), both collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape; and 
(3)  Muzzled by any means sufficient to prevent biting other persons or domestic animals. 
(d)  Failure to keep any animal under restraint or control as provided for in this section shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-35. - Rabies vaccination; registration fee; issuance of tag. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any owner or possessor or custodian of any dog or cat three (3) months old or older, when such animal is being kept in the City of Nashville, to procure a current rabies vaccination from a duly licensed veterinarian, and pay the required registration fee. If a dog or cat is being transported from outside the city limits into the City of Nashville where it will reside on a permanent basis with its owner, possessor or custodian, it shall be the duty of the owner, possessor or custodian to have a current rabies tag on the animal transported into the City of Nashville unless the animal has not reached the age of three (3) months. Such rabies tag shall be obtained from the animal control center, after proof of a current vaccination by a recognized licensed veterinarian has been presented. 
(b)  Any owner, custodian or possessor of any dog or cat which has reached the age of three (3) months or older, or who is obligated under this section to obtain the rabies tag therefore, who fails to obtain same shall be obligated to pay a late charge in the amount established by city council, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, for any rabies tag required under the terms of this section. 
(c)  The directors and designees thereof shall exercise the powers and duties of the rabies control officer pursuant to the provisions of section and shall be responsible for enforcing the provisions. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-36. - Collars, tags worn by dogs and cats. 
It shall be the duty of each dog or cat owner, possessor or custodian to provide a collar for such dog or cat to which the rabies inoculation tag shall be attached. The collar, together with the tag, shall be worn by the dog or cat if the animal is required to be inoculated against rabies as provided in section 4-35. Failure to comply with this section shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-37. - Rabies inoculation mandatory for dogs and cats. 
All dogs and cats in the incorporated limits of the city shall be inoculated for the prevention of rabies by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-38. - Guard dogs, dangerous dogs; warning signs on-premises. 
All owners, keepers or harborers of any guard dog or dangerous dog shall display in a prominent place on their premises, and at each entrance or exit to the area where such dog is confined, a sign easily readable by the public using the words "Beware of Dog." 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-39. - Abandonment or abuse. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly abandon or abuse any domesticated animal within the City of Nashville. Each person who knowingly abandons or abuses, or willingly permits such abandonment or abuse, or aids in the abandonment or abuse of any domesticated animal shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-40. - Training for fighting prohibited. 
It shall be prohibited for any person to keep, buy, sell, trade, exchange, give, transport, or deliver any animal: 
(1)  For the purpose of training the animal, primarily or in part, for animal fighting. 
(2)  Which has been trained, primarily or in part, for animal fighting. 
(3)  Which has been or is intended to be engaged in any manner in animal fighting. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-41. - Change of ownership of animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to abandon, sell, trade, swap or give away animals within the real property limits of the animal control facility, except by the established services provided by the animal control division inside the facility itself. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to give away or sell any animal in front of any business or store or on the side of any public roadway in the city. 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
Sec. 4-42. - Neutering of animal(s). 
It shall be the duty of any owner or possessor of any dog or cat adopted from the animal control center to have the dog or cat altered. Puppies and kittens must be altered by a licensed veterinarian within six (6) months from their date of adoption from the animal control center, and adult dogs and cats must be altered by a licensed veterinarian within thirty (30) days of their adoption. Failure to comply with this section may result in a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. of 9-8-08) 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 4-43. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner to keep any dog in the city without having first obtained, annually, a license therefor from the city clerk, or such other agent as the council shall designate. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § B, 8-15-77) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to require licensing of animals, O.C.G.A., § 88-1503. 
Sec. 4-44. - Fee; tag. 
A license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city for each dog annually; such license shall be acquired prior to January 1 of each year and shall be effective from January 1 to December 31, inclusive, of each year. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § B, 8-15-77; Ord. of 5-23-05) 
Sec. 4-45. - Dogs in kennels. 
No license shall be required for dogs kept within a dog kennel duly licensed by the city; provided, however, for the keeper or owner of any such dog kennel to become entitled to the benefits of this section, such owner or keeper must keep all dogs kept in any such dog kennel continuously and securely confined in a separate enclosure built for such purpose, and nothing contained in this section shall apply to any dog allowed to escape or run at large. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § L, 8-15-77) 
Sec. 4-46. - Duplicate license tag. 
Upon satisfactory proof that a license tag has been lost, or worn or damaged beyond further use, the city clerk shall issue a tag for a fee of fifty cents ($0.50). 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § B, 8-15-77) 
Secs. 4-47—4-57. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 4-58. - Dogs subject to impoundment. 
Any dog not wearing a license tag as prescribed herein; any vicious dog not confined, chained or muzzled as herein provided; any dog running at-large; any female dog while in breeding season running or having access to the public streets; any dog not wearing the rabies inoculation tag required by the statutes of Georgia; and any dog which causes annoyance shall be subject to be taken up by any police officer of the city, or any designated representative of the city, the director of the county health department, or his authorized representative, who shall have the dog confined in the dog pound. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § F, 8-15-77) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to impound and dispose of animals running at large, § 2-9(qq). 
Sec. 4-59. - Destruction of animal in attempt to impound. 
(a)  In the event any dog subject to being taken up pursuant to the provisions of this article cannot be captured without actual danger to the officer, or the representative of the city or health department attempting capture, any member of the police department, rabies control officer, or authorized representative, is authorized and directed to shoot such dog when the shooting can be done without endangering persons or other property. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall be construed as requiring any police officer to attempt to capture a dog plainly showing the existence of rabies, but such a dog may be shot by any police officer, rabies control inspector, or his authorized representative on sight, using due care not to injure persons or other property. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § G, 8-15-77) 
Sec. 4-60. - Operation of dog pound. 
The city shall operate either independently or in cooperation with others, or shall contract with the Berrien County Humane Society, for the operation of a suitable place for the impounding of dogs picked up under the terms of this article. If the city shall operate independently, then said facility shall be known as the "dog pound." 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § F, 8-15-77; Ord. of 5-26-98, § 1) 
Sec. 4-61. - Notice to owner. 
Not later than two (2) days after the impounding of any dog, the owner, if known, shall be notified of the time allowed for redemption of the dog. 
Sec. 4-62. - Fees and fines. 
(a)  The keeper of the dog pound shall not release any dog impounded until the owner has paid all pound fees, all fines assessed by the judge for violations of this article for which such dog was impounded, and until the owner has secured license tag and rabies tag as provided in this article. 
(b)  Any dog impounded pursuant to this article which is not suspected of rabies may be reclaimed from the pound upon the payment to the city's authorized representative the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for first release. The release fee shall double for each subsequent infraction occurring within six (6) months of the initial impoundment. In addition to any release fee assessed, there shall be paid the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per day, or any portion thereof, for room and board. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § H, 8-15-77; Ord. of 11-10-97, § 1; Ord. of 5-23-05) 
Sec. 4-63. - Failure to claim. 
Any dog which has been impounded and is not taken up by the owner, within five (5) days of the date impounded, shall be subject to destruction by the keeper of the pound, or other disposition. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § I, 8-15-77) 
State Law reference— Methods of disposal of dead animals, Ga. Code Ann., § 62-2105. 
Sec. 4-64. - Precedence of rabies inspector over pound keeper where rabies is suspected. 
In the case of any vicious dog or any dog giving signs of rabies, the authority of the rabies inspector under the statutes of the state shall take precedence over the keeper of the pound; but the handling of a dog by the rabies control officer shall not relieve any person violating this article from the penalties provided. 
(Ord. No. 5-77, § J, 8-15-77) 
State Law reference— County rabies control officer, Ga. Code Ann., § 88-1506.1. 
Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 12; mobile homes, Ch. 16; flood damage prevention, § 21-18 et seq.; arrangement of refuse storage prior to issuance of building permit, § 25-82; street numbering, § 26-47 et seq.; zoning, App. A, issuance of building permits, App. A, § 11-2; subdivisions, App. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Office of building official—Created. 
There is hereby created the office of building official. 
(Code 1967, § 5-4) 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 5-2. - Office of building official—Appointment. 
The mayor, with the consent of the city council, shall appoint some suitable person as building official, who shall devote his time solely to the business of his office. 
(Code 1967, § 5-5) 
Sec. 5-3. - Office of building official—Qualifications. 
The building official: 
(1)  Shall be an elector of the city; 
(2)  Shall have such technical and practical knowledge of construction and engineering, electrical wiring and electrical engineering, gas installations and appliances, mechanical systems, housing standards and plumbing and sanitation as will enable him to perform the duties required of him under provisions of the various technical regulations of the city; 
(3)  Shall not, by reason of ownership or part ownership, be connected in any building trades firm or business in the city. 
(Code 1967, §§ 5-5, 9-2, 19-2) 
Sec. 5-4. - Office of building official—Assistants. 
Any assistant the building official may be authorized to employ shall be qualified to hold a contractor's license in each of his fields of responsibility. 
(Code 1967, §§ 5-5, 9-2, 19-2) 
Charter reference— Appointment of department heads, § 5-6. 
Sec. 5-5. - Office of building official—Duties. 
The building official shall have exclusive management and control of all buildings under construction or additions to any existing building or alterations and renovations of any buildings in the city, and shall perform all duties, now or hereafter provided by this Code or the ordinances of the city, to be performed by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 5-6) 
Cross reference— Duties of building official with respect to plumbing, § 22-1; administration and enforcement of zoning ordinance, App. A, Art. 11. 
Sec. 5-6. - Fire district designated. 
The fire district of the city shall consist of all territory within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 5-1) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to fix and establish fire limits, § 2-9(kk). 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10. 
Secs. 5-7—5-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Sections 1—3 of an ordinance adopted July 25, 1988, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, have been treated as superseding provisions formerly codified as Art. II, §§ 5-23—5-25, of Ch. 5. Said former provisions pertained to the city's building code and were derived from provisions presumably enacted at the initial (1980) codification; from §§ 5-2 and 5-3 of the city's 1967 Code, and from a motion of May 13, 1974. 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate the construction and repair of buildings and to adopt building codes by reference, § 2-9(11). 
Cross reference— Electrical code, § 9-33; fire prevention code, § 10-39 et seq.; gas code, § 11-16 et seq.; heating and air conditioning code, Ch. 13; housing code, Ch. 14; plumbing code, § 22-19 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt state standard codes, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 84-6014—84-6017; authority to continue to operate under other codes or adopt more restrictive provisions, §§ 84-6013, 84-6015. 

Sec. 5-23. - Adopted. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the desire of Nashville City Council to adopt, in all aspects, the various Georgia codes relating to building, gas, energy, housing, mechanics, plumbing and electricity. The adoption of these codes is done to facilitate proper inspection activities by the City of Nashville, Berrien County, Georgia, relating to construction and to maintenance of buildings within the corporate limits of said city and relating to public safety, health and general welfare. 
(b)  Adoption by reference. The Georgia State Building Code is hereby adopted by reference as though it were copied herein in full. 
(c)  Conflicts and effect. Any matters in said code which are contrary to existing ordinances of the city, shall prevail and all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this section are hereby repealed, and this section shall be in full force and effect immediately upon its adoption and publication as provided by law. 
(d)  Transfer of responsibility. Within said codes when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein, those designated officials of the city who have duties corresponding to those of the named officials in said code shall be deemed to be the responsible officials insofar as enforcing the provisions of said code is concerned. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88, §§ 1—3) 
Sec. 5-24. - Shipping/cargo container. 
(a)  A single rigid, sealed, reusable, metal (corrugated) box in which cargo or freight is shipped by sea vessel, air, truck, or rail, that is generally ten (10), twenty (20), thirty (30), or forty (40) feet in length by eight (8) feet wide by eight (8) or eight and one-half (8½) feet high and is designed and constructed in conformance with International Standards Organization (ISO) standards and International Convention for Safe Containers (ICSC) regulations to withstand normal stresses applied to during regular transport. Container types include: Standard, high, cube, hard top, open top, flat, platform, ventilated, insulated, refrigerated and bulk. 
(b)  After proper application and permitting as hereinafter provided, a container as herein defined shall be utilized solely for storage/utility purposes on a temporary basis only, not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days and shall not be inhabited under any circumstances, absent issuance of a permit by the code enforcement officer of City of Nashville expressly identifying and approving a specific container for a habitation at a specified site in accordance with the guidelines provided by the city. Until such guidelines are adopted, no permits authorizing habitation of a container shall be issued by the city. 
(c)  The property owner and tenant of the premises on which a container is located shall be jointly responsible for ensuring the container is maintained in good condition, free from evidence of deterioration, weathering, discoloration, graffiti, rust, ripping, tearing or other holes or breaks, at all times and shall be maintained in an aesthetically acceptable manner. 
(d)  Prior to proper permitting expressly approving same, and payment of all fees for inspection and approval, containers shall not be placed, located or used in residential, commercial or industrial zones. 
(Ord. No. O-03-18, 9-24-18) 
Secs. 5-25—5-41. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 15. 

Sec. 5-42. - Definition. 
A building or general contracting business within the provisions of this chapter is defined to be a business engaged in by an individual, firm or corporation to do building or construction work of any kind, excepting those covered by other chapters of this Code such as the electrical and plumbing chapters. 
(Code 1967, § 5-7) 
Sec. 5-43. - Qualification for building contractor's license. 
The building official shall determine whether a person has the required competence to be issued a license as a building contractor. 
Sec. 5-44. - Payment of fees prerequisite to issuance of occupational license. 
No license to do business in the city as building contractor shall be issued by the city clerk except upon the presentation of the requisite license fees. 
(Code 1967, § 5-11) 
Editor's note— The schedule of occupational license fees is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 5-45. - Contractor to have place of business in city. 
Every licensed builder or general contractor shall have an established place of business within the limits of the city, provided, that contractors having fixed places of business without the limits of the city may erect a temporary booth or structure to be used as offices, and which shall be maintained as long as such contract work shall be in progress and until the same has been duly inspected and passed by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 5-14) 
Sec. 5-46. - All work to be done under the supervision of licensed builder. 
The person receiving a license as provided herein shall be deemed to be a licensed builder or building contractor or general contractor, provided that any firm or corporation, one member or employee of which holds a license shall be authorized to do business in its firm name or corporation name, but provided further, that the actual work or construction undertaken shall be under the direct supervision of such licensed builder. 
(Code 1967, § 5-12) 
Sec. 5-47. - Fraudulent use of name to obtain permit. 
No person holding a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall allow his name to be used by another for the purpose of obtaining a permit for work to be done which he does not supervise. Violation of this section shall be sufficient cause for suspension of the said license for a period of one year. 
(Code 1967, § 5-13) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
Cross reference— Offenses generally, Ch. 18. 
Secs. 5-48—5-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PERMITS AND FEES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of an ordinance passed and adopted July 25, 1988 have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as a new Art. IV to Ch. 5, the substantive provisions of which consist of §§ 5-58—5-66. 
Cross reference— Plumbing permit fees, § 22-22.1; electrical permit fees, § 9-7.1; mechanical permit fees, § 13-2. 

Sec. 5-58. - Residential buildings—Items required for permit. 
(a)  The following items will be needed before the issuance of a single-family residence permit: 
(1)  Plot plan. Drawing needs to show size of lot and approximate location of the house, distances from the front, sides and rear of the property lines and how far from any other structure on the property. Indicate the northerly direction by an arrow. 
(2)  Legal description of property. Recorded deed, warranty deed or mortgage deed. 
(3)  Building plans (two (2) sets). Include foundation, wall section, (frame construction to include grade and species of lumber to be used), roof view, floor plan, window/door locations and sizes, air and/or heat ducts (one (1) line drawing), show location of air conditioner and/or heater. 
(4)  Energy specifications. Energy specifications to be checked over with the building plans before the building permit can be issued. 
(5)  Power. Contact the appropriate power company to apply for power. The power company will spot the power pole location and need load data information. (Prompt application will cause less delay in final power connections). 
(6)  Elevation. If the property is in a flood zone, the prospective permittee will need an elevation determination by a registered surveyor or engineer. 
(7)  Septic tank permit. If city sewer is not available, a septic tank permit is required from the health department. 
(b)  The owner/occupant will furnish the city with the above items if the owner/occupant is going to do his own building and take out the permit. If the work is to be done by someone else, that person must be a contractor licensed by the city. The contractor will be liable for any permit fees. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-59. - Residential buildings—Responsibility for inspection. 
It is the permittee's responsibility to call for all inspections. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-60. - Residential buildings—Energizing power. 
Effective August 1, 1998, the city will not energize power to any residential building until final inspection is approved. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-61. - Permit fees for new residential buildings. 
(a)  Fees. 
(1)  Permit fees. 

 
(2)  Moving fee. For the moving of any building or structure, except a manufactured home, the fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). The moving of a manufactured home and the set-up with foundation and anchors shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00) plus the required electrical fee. 
(b)  Plan-checking review fees. When the valuation of the proposed construction exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and a plan is required to be submitted by 104.2 of the Standard Southern Building Code, a plan-checking review fee shall be paid to the building official at the time of submitting plans and specifications for checking. Said plan-checking review fee shall be equal to one-fourth of the building permit fee as set forth in 103.7.4 of the Southern Standard Building Code. Such plan-checking fee is in addition to the building permit fee. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88; Ord. of 12-27-05) 
Sec. 5-62. - Commercial buildings—Items required for permit. 
(a)  The following items will be required before the issuance of a commercial building permit. This permit must be issued to a licensed contractor. 
(1)  Plot plan. Show size of property and approximate location of any structures and the distances to the front, rear and side property lines. Indicate any other structures on the property and the distances to them. This will be approved by the director of the department. 
(2)  Legal description of the property. Recorded deed, warranty deed or mortgage deed. 
(3)  Two (2) sets of signed and sealed drawings. Include foundation, wall section (frame construction to include grade and species of lumber to be used), roof view, floor plan, window and door locations and sizes, air and/or heat ducts (one (1) line drawings), show location of air conditioner and/or heater. 
(4)  Energy specifications. Energy specifications to be checked over with the building plans before the building permit can be issued. 
(5)  Power. Contact the appropriate power company to apply for power. The power company will spot the power pole location and need load data information. (Prompt application will cause less delay in final power connections). 
(6)  Elevation. If the property is in a flood zone, the prospective permittee will need an elevation determination by a registered surveyor or engineer. 
(7)  Septic tank permit. If city sewer is not available, a septic tank permit is required from the health department. 
(b)  The contractor will furnish the city with the above items and take out the permit. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-63. - Commercial buildings—Energizing power. 
Effective August 1, 1988, the city will not energize power to any commercial building until final inspection is approved. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-64. - Commercial buildings—Responsibility for inspection. 
It is the permittee's responsibility to call for all inspections. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-65. - Commercial buildings—Sanitary facilities on construction sites. 
Sanitary facilities are required on all construction sites of commercial buildings. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88) 
Sec. 5-66. - Other fees. 
(a)  One hundred dollars ($100.00) and less: No fee, unless inspection is required, in which case a five-dollar fee for each inspection shall be charged. 
(b)  Moving of building or structure ..... $25.00 
(c)  Demolition of building or structure ..... $25.00 
(d)  Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or proceeded with prior to obtaining a permit, the fees herein specified shall be doubled, but the payment of such doubled fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed herein. 
(e)  When the valuation of the proposed construction exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and a plan is required to be submitted, a plan-checking fee shall be paid to the building official at the time of submitting plans and specifications for checking. Said plan-checking fee shall be equal to one-fourth (¼) of the building permit fee or a minimum fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
(f)  Reinspection fees are five dollars ($5.00), payable in advance. 
(g)  Inspection, approval and permitting fees for temporary placement of containers shall be set by resolution and payable in advance and shall be paid prior to placement of said container. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88; Ord. No. O-03-18, 9-24-18) 
Secs. 5-67—5-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION RESTRICTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted March 11, 2013, amended art. V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. V pertained the same subject matter and derived from an ordinance adopted July 8, 1991. 

Sec. 5-76. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to this article: 
Commercial means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. 
Lavatory faucet means a faucet that discharges into a lavatory basin in a domestic or commercial installation. 
Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
Toilet means a water closet. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Sec. 5-77. - Restrictions on residential construction. 
On or after July 1, 2012, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: 
(1)  Employs a gravity tank-type flush-o-meter valve, or flush-o-meter-tank toilet that uses more than an average of one and twenty-eight hundredths (1.28) gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this paragraph shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 2012; 
(2)  Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of two and five-tenths (2.5) gallons of water per minute at sixty (60) pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one-half (0.5) gallons of water per flush; 
(4)  Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than one and one-half (1.5) gallons of water per minute at sixty (60) pounds per square inch of pressure; or 
(5)  Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two (2.0) gallons of water per minute. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Sec. 5-78. - Restrictions on commercial construction. 
On or after July 1, 2012, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subparagraphs (1) through (5) of section 5-77 above. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Sec. 5-79. - Application to replacement toilets and/or showers. 
The requirements of section 5-77 of this article shall apply to any construction initiated after July 1, 2012, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building including replacement of toilets or showers or both. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Sec. 5-80. - Exemptions. 
(a)  New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 5-77 through 5-79 when: 
(1)  The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; 
(2)  When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were installed; 
(3)  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(4)  Units to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles. 
(b)  The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subparagraphs (a)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the city building inspector. A fee of five dollars ($5.00) per fixture shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exception. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Sec. 5-81. - Enforcement; penalty. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the office of the building inspector of the city. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector. 
(b)  Any person who installs any toilet, faucet, urinal or shower head in violation of this Code section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this article shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Upon conviction, a violation of this article may be punished by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both for each offense. Each day of continued violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 3-11-13) 
Secs. 5-82—5-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Inasmuch as an ordinance adopted May 10, 1993, did not specify manner of codification, inclusion herein as Art. VI, §§ 5-86—5-89, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-86. - Unsafe buildings defined. 
All buildings or structures within the corporate limits of the City of Nashville which have any or all of the following defects shall be deemed to be "unsafe buildings." 
(1)  Those in which the interior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity falls outside of the base of such wall; 
(2)  Those buildings which, exclusive of the foundation, show thirty-three (33) percent, or more, of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members, or fifty (50) percent of damage or deterioration of a nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering; 
(3)  Those buildings which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs, or in which the same are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose for which it is used, or intended to be used; 
(4)  Those buildings which have been damaged by fire, wind, or other causes, so as to have become dangerous to life, safety, morals, or the general health and welfare of the occupants thereof or the people of the city; 
(5)  Those buildings which have become or are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary, or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation, or are likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to work injury to the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of those living therein, or may live therein; 
(6)  Those having light, air, and sanitation facilities which are inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of human beings who live or may live therein; 
(7)  Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic, or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes, or other means of communication; 
(8)  Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and injure members of the public or property; 
(9)  Those which, because of their condition, are unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous to the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of the people of the city; and 
(10)  Those buildings which exist in violation of any ordinance of the city, so as to constitute a nuisance and to be unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the people of the City of Nashville, Georgia. 
(Ord. of 5-10-93, § 1) 
Sec. 5-87. - Unsafe buildings as nuisances. 
All unsafe buildings as defined herein are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be repaired, vacated or demolished as provided for in this article hereinbefore and hereinafter. 
(Ord. of 5-10-93, § 2) 
Sec. 5-88. - Duties of the building inspector. 
(a)  The building inspector of the City of Nashville, Georgia, shall be appointed by the mayor and members of the council. The building inspector is specifically charged with the duty of enforcing this article and upon finding, within the corporate limits of the city, an unsafe building as defined herein, shall cause an inspection of said building, and if the same is found to be unsafe as defined herein, shall make a written statement of the conditions and defects of such building and such evidence as may be available be reported to the mayor and council of the city. 
(b)  The building inspector at the time such report is filed with the mayor and members of the council of the city, shall specifically point out the defects in such building which should be repaired, shall specify whether the same is unsafe for human habitation and/or shall recommend to the mayor and council such steps which in his opinion should be taken to remedy the conditions found to exist so that such building will no longer be unsafe, as defined herein. 
(c)  Upon such report being filed with the mayor and members of the council of the city, by the building inspector, such report shall be considered by the mayor and members of the council at its next regular scheduled meeting, and, if, after consideration of the report and evidence filed by the building inspector, the mayor and members of the council, shall determine that reasonable cause to proceed exists, the mayor and members of the council shall then order that a hearing be held at a day and time to be set by the mayor and members of the council within not less than ten (10) days and not more than sixty (60) days to determine if the building described in the building inspector's report is indeed an unsafe building. 
(d)  The owner or owners, tenants, if any, and lienholders of record, if any, of such building shall be served with a copy of such notice of hearing not less than ten (10) days prior to the date fixed for such hearing. The owner or owners and/or lienholders of such building shall be served personally with such notice, if they reside or can be found in the City of Nashville, or cannot be found in the City of Nashville, they shall be served by publishing a copy of such notice, addressed to them, in the newspaper having general circulation in Berrien County, Georgia, in which sheriff's advertisements appear, once a week for four (4) weeks immediately preceding the date of such hearing, and a copy of such notice shall be mailed to such owners and/or lienholders at their last address as shown by the tax records of the city, at least fifteen (15) days prior to such hearing, by registered or certified mail. The tenants in such building, if any, shall be served by leaving a copy with an adult residing in such building. 
(e)  After the hearing, the mayor and members of the council of the city, shall, by resolution, issue an order based upon hearing the evidence produced at such a hearing, and if by such order they find and determine such building to be an unsafe building, as defined herein, such order shall specify the acts and things to be done to such building or in and about such building, including demolition, if necessary to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city and the persons who live or may live in, or who may inhabit such building.
