A copy of such determination shall also be served upon the tax commissioner of Berrien County, who shall include the increased tax on the next regular tax bill rendered on behalf of the city. 
(e)  Persons aggrieved by the determination of the court affirming the determination of the public officer may petition the Superior Court of Berrien County for a writ of certiorari within thirty (30) days of issuance of the court's written determination. 
(Ord. No. O-01-16, § 2, 10-24-16) 
Sec. 5-225. - Remediation or redevelopment. 
(a)  A property owner or person(s) who is chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on real property which has been officially designated pursuant to this article as property maintained in a blighted condition may petition the public officer to lift the designation, upon proof of compliance with the following: 
(1)  Completion of work required under a plan of remedial action or redevelopment approved by the city's planning and development director which addresses the conditions of blight found to exist on or within the property, including compliance with all applicable minimum codes; or 
(2)  Completion of work required under an order entered by the mayor and council in a proceeding brought pursuant to article VI, unsafe buildings, of chapter 5 of the Code of Nashville, Georgia; or 
(3)  Completion of work required under an order entered in a proceeding brought pursuant to article IX, Nashville Derelict Property Ordinance of chapter 5 of the Municipal Code of the City of Nashville. 
(b)  Before action on a petition to lift the designation, the public officer shall cause the property to be thoroughly inspected by a building inspector who, by written inspection report, shall certify that all requisite work has been performed to applicable code in a workmanlike manner, in accordance with the specifications of the plan of remedial action or redevelopment, or applicable court order. Upon finding required work to be satisfactorily performed, the public officer shall issue a written determination that the real property is no longer maintained in a blighted condition. Copies of this determination shall be served upon the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes, and upon the tax commissioner of Berrien County. 
(c)  All plans for remedial action or redevelopment shall be in writing, signed by the person(s) chargeable with the payment of ad valorem taxes on the real property and the director of the city's planning and development department, and contain the following: 
(1)  The plan shall be consistent with the city's comprehensive plan and all laws and ordinances governing the subject property, and shall conform to any urban redevelopment plan adopted for the area within which the property lies; 
(2)  The plan shall set forth in reasonable detail the requirements for repair, closure, demolition, or restoration of existing structures, in accordance with minimal statewide codes; where structures are demolished, the plan shall include provisions for debris removal, stabilization and landscaping of the property; 
(3)  On parcels of five (5) acres or greater, the plan shall address the relationship to local objectives respecting land uses, improved traffic, public transportation, public utilities, recreational and community facilities, and other public improvements; 
(4)  The plan shall contain verifiable funding sources which will be used to complete its requirements and show the feasibility thereof; 
(5)  The plan shall contain a timetable for completion of required work; and 
(6)  Any outstanding ad valorem taxes (state, school, county and city, including the increased tax pursuant to this article) and governmental liens due and payable on the property must be satisfied in full. 
(Ord. No. O-01-16, § 2, 10-24-16) 
Sec. 5-226. - Decrease of tax rate. 
(a)  Real property which has had its designation as maintained in a blighted condition removed by the public officer, as provided in section 5-224, identification of blighted property, of this article, shall be eligible for a decrease in the rate of city ad valorem taxation by applying a factor of 0.5 to the city millage rate applied to the property, so that such property shall be taxed at a lower millage rate than the millage rate generally applied in the municipality or otherwise provided by general law; such decreased rate of taxation shall be applied beginning with the next tax bill rendered following removal of official designation of a real property as blighted. The decreased rate of taxation may be given in successive years, depending on the amount of cost expended by the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property to satisfy its remediation or redevelopment, with every twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or portion thereof equaling one (1) year of tax reduction; provided, however, that no property shall be entitled to reduction in city ad valorem taxes for more than four (4) successive years. 
(b)  In order to claim entitlement for a decreased rate of taxation, the person(s) chargeable with payment of ad valorem taxes on the property shall submit a notarized affidavit to the public officer, supported by receipts or other evidence of payment, of the amount expended. 
(Ord. No. O-01-16, § 2, 10-24-16) 
Sec. 5-227. - Notice to tax commissioner. 
It shall be the duty of the public officer to notify the tax commissioner of Berrien County in writing as to designation or removal of designation of a specific property as maintained in a blighted condition. Such notice shall identify the specific property by street address and tax map, block and parcel number, as assigned by the Berrien County Tax Assessor's Office. The public officer shall cooperate with the tax commissioner to assure accurate tax billing of those properties subject to increased or reduced ad valorem taxation under this article. 
(Ord. No. O-01-16, § 2, 10-24-16) 
Chapter 6 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance of Nov. 26, 1990, amended Ch. 6 to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Ch. 6 consisted of §§ 6-1—6-9 and was derived from Code 1967, §§ 6-1—6-7; a motion of July 22, 1974; and an ordinance of May 11, 1987. 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide cemeteries, § 2-9(w). 
State Law reference— Conveyance of money or property to mayor and city council for cemetery, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-503; authority of city to act as trustee for cemetery funds, § 69-506. 

Sec. 6-1. - Payment for lots. 
(a)  No person will be permitted to open a grave in a city cemetery without first paying to the city clerk the full purchase price of the lot or lots or making other suitable arrangements with the city clerk or city clerk's designee according to terms and conditions specified by the mayor and council or city manager. 
(b)  Upon receipt of payment in full of the purchase price or other suitable arrangement, the city clerk or city clerk's designee shall make a limited warranty deed conveying the lot or lots purchased expressly subject to the conditions and restrictions imposed upon the grave sites under the rules and regulations regarding flowers, memorials and operations of the city cemeteries referenced in said limited warranty deed. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90; Ord. No. O-01-18, 8-13-18) 
Sec. 6-2. - Permit to dig grave, erect headstone, monuments, memorials, etc. 
(a)  No person shall erect or place a headstone, monument, memorial, bench, chair or similar structure on a grave lot until such headstone, monument, memorial, bench, chair or similar structure has been determined by the city manager, city manager's designee or city cemetery staff to be compliant with the applicable rules and regulations regarding flowers, memorials and operations of the city's cemeteries. 
(b)  The rules and regulations regarding flowers, memorials and operations may be amended, revised or supplemented from time to time as the council deems necessary to protect the public health and safety of the general public, person's owning or visiting gravesites in the city's municipal cemeteries and city employees, agents or independent contactor's responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the city's cemeteries. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90; Ord. No. O-01-18, 8-13-18) 
Sec. 6-3. - Burials in vaults. 
All burials shall be made in a vault, which shall be constructed of materials other than wood. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-4. - Top soil; damage to sod; removal of surplus clay. 
No sand or clay shall be used as top soil upon the lots. No damage shall be done to grass sod adjacent to a new grave at the time of opening a new grave. The city, within a reasonable time, will remove the surplus clay not needed in properly closing a newly made grave. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-5. - Alignment of headstones and monuments. 
All headstones and/or monuments are to be aligned as closely as possible in a straight line with one another in said cemetery. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-6. - Height of monuments and stones. 
Monuments and tombstones shall be limited to a height of four (4) feet. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-7. - Coping around lots. 
No person owning a lot in a city cemetery shall be allowed to place coping of any material around his lot or lots. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-8. - Slabs, corner markers and foot markers. 
No slabs will be allowed in Memorial Gardens. Corner markers, if placed, shall be flush with the ground surface and are placed at the owner's risk. The city will not be held liable for mower damage, etc. Foot markers will be allowed. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-9. - Shrubbery. 
No person owning a lot in a city cemetery shall be allowed to place any shrubbery or live plants on his individual lot or lots. Any foliage or trees planted will be done by the city, at its discretion. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-10. - Sale of lots by sexton. 
All sales of cemetery lots are to be done only by the appointed cemetery sexton. All sales are to be in order of progression within the current block of lots. No random sales will be permitted within the cemetery. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-11. - Visiting hours in cemeteries. 
Visiting hours in all city cemeteries shall be from sunup until sundown. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90) 
Sec. 6-12. - Price of lots. 
The price per gravesite of cemetery lots owned by the City of Nashville will be as set forth in the schedule of rates and charges on file in the office of the city clerk effective as of the date thereof and modified as hereinafter provided. These prices shall be regulated by mayor and council in open session; however, any changes in the price of said lots will become effective the Monday following two (2) weeks' publication of notice of any revision of said gravesite lot prices. 
(Ord. of 11-26-90; Ord. of 12-28-98, § 1; Ord. of 12-9-13) 
Sec. 6-12.1. - Price of lots—Eastview Cemetery. 
The price per grave-site for Eastview Cemetery will be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). These prices shall be regulated by the mayor and council in open session. 
(Ord. of 8-22-05) 
Chapter 7 - CIVIL DEFENSE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to proclaim and deal with emergencies, § 2-9(d). 
Cross reference— Police department, Ch. 23; obedience to officers directing traffic, § 28-3. 
State Law reference— Civil defense act, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 86-18. 

Sec. 7-1. - Definition. 
As used in this chapter, the term "civil defense" means the preparation for the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of man-made or natural origin, caused by enemy attack, sabotage, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, fire fighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
(Code 1967, § 7-1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 86-1803. 
Sec. 7-2. - Penalty for violation. 
It shall be unlawful, during an emergency, for any person: 
(1)  To willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the civil defense corps in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by virtue of this chapter. 
(2)  To do any act forbidden by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this chapter if such act is of such nature as to give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of this city or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. 
(3)  To wear or carry or display without authority any mark or identification specified by the council of defense. 
(Code 1967, § 7-8) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide penalties for violations of rules and regulations, § 2-9(ww). 
Sec. 7-3. - Civil defense director. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of the civil defense director. Such officer shall be nominated by the mayor, as provided by law. 
(b)  The civil defense director is hereby directed: 
(1)  To represent the mayor on all matters pertaining to civil defense. 
(2)  To require and direct cooperation of city officials in the preparation and implementation of civil defense plans. 
(3)  During periods of emergency, to direct the services of any city officers or employees. 
(4)  During periods of emergency, to obtain vital supplies and equipment needed for the protection of life and property of people and bind the city for the value thereof and if required immediately, requisition same. 
(Code 1967, § 7-4) 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Appointment and duties of local civil defense director, Ga. Code Ann., § 86-1809. 
Sec. 7-4. - Civil defense corps. 
Officers and employees of the city, together with volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during an emergency, and all groups, organizations and persons who make the agreements by which they are charged with duties necessary for the protection of life and property in the city during such an emergency, shall constitute the civil defense corps. 
(Code 1967, § 7-5) 
Sec. 7-5. - Divisions of the civil defense corps. 
(a)  The functions and duties of the civil defense corps shall be distributed among the divisions as listed below. Each division shall be under the direction of a chief and a deputy chief, appointed by the council of defense. The chiefs of divisions will include public officials such as sheriffs, chiefs of police and fire departments and heads of agencies dealing with transportation, communications and other sundry services as well as private persons who through their profession, business, knowledge or experience are particularly qualified to head divisions requiring specialized knowledge and experience. 
(b)  The divisions are established as follows: 
Law enforcement division 
Fire services division 
Transportation division 
Medical and health division 
Communications division 
Welfare division 
Information and education division. 
(Code 1967, § 7-6) 
Sec. 7-6. - Volunteers. 
All persons other than officers and employees of the city, volunteering in service pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such service, they shall have the same immunities as officers and employees of the city performing similar duties. 
(Code 1967, § 7-7) 
State Law reference— Immunity from liability, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 86-1817, 86-1822. 
Sec. 7-7. - Council of defense—Created; membership. 
The Nashville Council of Defense is hereby created and shall include the following: 
Mayor 
Director of civil defense 
Police chief 
Fire chief 
County health officer 
City engineer 
County or city welfare officer 
American Red Cross representative 
Others including representatives of business, labor, civic and patriotic organizations as appointed by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1967, § 7-2) 
State Law reference— Local organization for civil defense, Ga. Code Ann., § 86-1809. 
Sec. 7-8. - Same—Powers and duties. 
It shall be the duty of the council of defense and it is hereby empowered: 
(1)  To develop a city civil defense plan. This plan shall provide for the effective mobilization of all the resources of the city, both private and public. 
(2)  To prepare and recommend for consideration by the city council ordinances necessary to implement the civil defense plan. 
(3)  To consider and recommend to the director of civil defense for approval mutual aid plans and agreements. 
(Code 1967, § 7-3) 
State Law reference— Mutual aid arrangements, Ga. Code Ann., § 86-1808. 
Chapter 8 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Filling of vacancy in office of mayor or councilman, § 2-5; authority of mayor and city council to regulate city elections, § 2-9(g); elections generally, § 3-1 et seq. 
Cross reference— Mayor and city council, § 2-20 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal elections, Ga. Code Ann., Title 34A; ballots for primary elections, forms and stubs, §§ 34A-1002, 34A-1006; violations of Municipal Election Code, § 34A-1601; false statements, § 34A-1602.

ARTICLE III. - CANDIDATES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Filing for office, § 3-2. 
State Law reference— Nomination of candidates, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-901 et seq. 

Sec. 8-44. - Reserved.

Sec. 8-45. - Qualifying for different post or office. 
Once a candidate has qualified to run for a designated post or office in any given city election, that candidate cannot change from running for that particular post or office and run for another post or office in that same election, nor can he totally withdraw from the election and qualify for another post or office in that particular election, notwithstanding his being withdrawn voluntarily or for cause from failure to comply with the qualifying regulations. 
(Ord. of 12-12-72, § II) 
State Law reference— Qualifying for office, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-901 et seq. 
Sec. 8-46. - Refund of qualification fee. 
Once a candidate has qualified to run for a particular post or office in a city election he shall not be reimbursed his qualifying fee if he for any reason voluntarily withdraws from the race; but, he will be reimbursed his qualifying fee only if he is withdrawn from the race for cause for failure to fully comply with the qualifying regulations. 
(Ord. of 12-12-72, § III) 
State Law reference— Qualification fees, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-904. 
Secs. 8-47—8-62. - Reserved.

Chapter 9 - ELECTRICITY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Electrical department created. 
There is hereby created a department of the city to be known as the electrical department. 
(Code 1967, § 9-1) 
Charter reference— Appointment of department heads, § 5-6. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 9-2. - General powers and duties of building official. 
The building official shall be chief of the electrical inspection department. It shall be his duty to issue permits for all electrical work and to have supervision over all such work done in the city. He shall see that all fees are paid for permits and paid over to the city. He shall keep a record of all the transactions of his office and shall be provided with proper blank applications for the convenient listing of information regarding electrical work for which permits are to be issued. 
(Code 1967, § 9-3) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
Sec. 9-3. - Regulation of electric wires and appliances. 
The building official is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to regulate and determine the placing of electric light and power wires in and on buildings in the city so as to prevent fires, accidents or injuries to persons or property, and to cause all electrical appliances to be so placed, constructed and guarded, as not to cause fire or accidents or to endanger life or property, and whenever in the judgment of the building official an electric wire or appliance shall be defective by reason of insufficient insulation, or from any other cause, the said building official shall at once cause the immediate removal of such defects. 
(Code 1967, § 9-3) 
Sec. 9-4. - Management of city electrical installations. 
The building official shall be the chief of the electrical department; shall have exclusive management and control of all electrical devices installed and inaugurated by the city; and shall have the power to cause the removal of all wires or the turning off of all currents when the circuit interferes with the work of the fire department. 
(Code 1967, § 9-3) 
Sec. 9-5. - Enforcement of regulations. 
It shall be the duty of the building official to see that all the provisions of this article and the city electrical code are enforced. He shall issue permits only to bona fide, licensed contractors within the provisions of this article, and shall not permit any electrical wiring of any class whatever within the limits of the city except under the direct supervision of an individual holding a license issued in due form by the state for the current license year. Provided, that where large buildings and establishments have in their regular employ a man competent to keep in repair the electrical equipment and wiring or to install new wiring or electrical equipment in such building or establishment, such employee shall upon the approval of the building official as to his fitness to properly discharge such duties, be issued a special permit to attend to such work solely in the particular building or establishment. 
(Code 1967, § 9-4) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
State Law reference— Holder of statewide electrical contractor's license exempt from local examination requirement, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-5716. 
Sec. 9-6. - Inspections during progress of work. 
The building official shall make such necessary inspections of work as it progresses to be satisfied that the requirements of this article and the electrical code of the city are fulfilled, and in the event he shall, upon such inspection, find such electrical work or construction not to be in compliance therewith, he shall immediately notify the electrical contractor under whose supervision the work is being done, and such notice shall be in writing and shall specify wherein such work or construction shall be found defective. 
(Code 1967, § 9-5) 
Sec. 9-7. - Permits. 
No alteration or change shall be made in writing of any building, nor shall any building be wired for the placing of electric lights, motors or heating devices, without first securing from the building official a permit therefor, nor shall any change be made in any electrical plant, after inspection, without notifying the building official and securing a permit therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 9-6) 
Cross reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
Sec. 9-7.1. - Electrical permit fees. 
New Services 

 
Remodeling, Repair and Additions 
For commercial and residential buildings, based on existing amp service without upgrading service: 
New Services 

 
(Ord. of 7-25-88; Ord. of 12-27-05) 
Sec. 9-8. - Notice of completion of wiring; certificate of inspection. 
Upon the completion of the wiring of any building it shall be the duty of the individual doing the same to notify the building official, who shall at once inspect the same, and if approved by him, he shall issue a certificate of inspection, which shall contain the date of such inspection and an outline of the results of such inspection, but no such certificate shall be issued unless the electric light, power or heating installation, and all apparatus, wire and other facilities connected with it shall be in strict conformity with the rules and regulations set forth in the electrical code adopted in section 9-33, nor shall current be turned on for such installation until said certificate be issued. 
(Code 1967, § 9-7) 
Sec. 9-9. - Conditions on removal of poles. 
All persons maintaining poles on the streets or public places of the city, for the purpose of supporting wires for the transmission or conducting of electricity for any purpose, or other poles or posts, shall be, and they are hereby required, when any poles are taken up or removed, to remove such pole in its entirety and fill up the hole from which said pole is removed with like material to that of the surrounding surface, and it shall be unlawful to permit the stump or any portion of any pole that has heretofore been, or shall be hereafter removed, to remain on any street or public place in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 9-8) 
Sec. 9-10. - Inspection fees. 
All owners, agents or occupants of buildings in the city wherein inspection is required under the ordinances of the city to be made of the electric wires installed therein, and all persons installing wiring for electric light, heat or power in the city shall pay or cause to be paid to the city, inspection fees as fixed by the council from time to time. 
(Code 1967, § 9-9) 
Sec. 9-11. - Notice of work ready for inspection to be in writing. 
When the electrical work for which a permit has been obtained is ready for inspection, notice in writing shall be given to the building official stating the location of the work and the name of the owner or the building contractor. 
(Code 1967, § 9-10) 
Sec. 9-12. - Reinspections; fees. 
If after the first visit to a job on a notice to inspect same, it is necessary to return to reinspect any work whether from defect or the work not being ready, the building official will return only on a written notice; a fee fixed by the council from time to time for doing so will be charged and collected in advance. 
(Code 1967, § 9-11) 
Sec. 9-13. - Payment of fee prerequisite to certificate of inspection. 
All payments for inspections shall be made before the building official shall give a certificate of inspection to the owner, agent or occupant, and such certificate of inspection shall only be given upon the presentation of a receipt from the city for the payment of the amount required by section 9-10. 
(Code 1967, § 9-12) 
Sec. 9-14. - Work to be left open until inspection. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to lath, seal or in any manner conceal any electrical wiring or equipment in any building under construction or repair until the same has been inspected and the notice posted as required by this article. 
(Code 1967, § 9-14) 
Sec. 9-15. - Wiring to be done after roofing; plumbing roughed in. 
Wire shall not be placed in buildings by the knob and tube or nonmetallic type construction until the roof of the building is on. The parts of the building where the plumbing is planned shall not be wired until the plumbing is roughed in. 
(Code 1967, § 9-15) 
Sec. 9-16. - Certificate of inspection prerequisite to supplying electricity. 
The power company shall not connect and supply electric current to any building unless a certificate of inspection has been issued in proper form. 
(Code 1967, § 9-16) 
Secs. 9-17—9-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Sections 1—3 of an ordinance adopted July 25, 1988, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, have been treated as superseding provisions formerly codified as Ch. 9, Art. II, §§ 9-33 and 9-34. These former provisions pertained to the electrical code and were derived from provisions presumably enacted during the 1980 codification and from Code 1967, § 9-13. 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5-23; fire prevention code, § 10-39 et seq.; gas code, § 11-16 et seq.; heating and air conditioning code, Ch. 13; housing code, Ch. 14; plumbing code, § 22-19 et seq. 

Sec. 9-33. - Adopted. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the desire of Nashville City Council to adopt, in all aspects, the various Georgia codes relating to building, gas, energy, housing, mechanics, plumbing and electricity. The adoption of these codes is done to facilitate proper inspection activities by the City of Nashville, Berrien County, Georgia, relating to construction and to maintenance of buildings within the corporate limits of said city and relating to public safety, health and general welfare. 
(b)  Adoption by reference. The Georgia State Electrical Code is hereby adopted by reference as though it were copied herein in full. 
(c)  Conflicts and effect. Any matters in said code which are contrary to existing ordinances of the city shall prevail and all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this section are hereby repealed, and this section shall be in full force and effect immediately upon its adoption and publication as provided by law. 
(d)  Transfer of responsibility. Within said code when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein, those designated officials of the city who have duties corresponding to those of the named officials in said code shall be deemed to be the responsible officials insofar as enforcing the provisions of said code is concerned. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88, §§ 1—3) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to establish minimum standards for electrical wiring and equipment and to adopt electrical codes by reference, § 2-9 (ll). 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt state standard codes, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 84-6014—84-6017; authority to continue to operate under other codes or adopt more restrictive provisions, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 84-6013, 84-6015. 
Secs. 9-34—9-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference— Electrical contractors, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 84-57. 

Sec. 9-51. - Definition. 
An electrical contracting business, within the provisions of this article, is defined to be a business engaged in by an individual, firm or corporation, to do electrical wiring installations, installation of electric motors, electric fixtures, electric bells or any electric work for purposes of which electric current is utilized for light, heat, power or signal systems. 
(Code 1967, § 9-20) 
Sec. 9-52. - License required for persons doing electrical contracting. 
All persons engaged in an electrical contracting business shall obtain a city license. 
(Code 1967, § 9-19) 
State Law reference— Holder of statewide electrical contractor's license exempt from local examination requirement, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-5716. 
Sec. 9-53. - State license prerequisite for city license. 
No license to do business in the city as an electrical contractor shall be issued by the city clerk except upon presentation of a valid statewide license, and the payment of requisite license fee, as set out in the occupational license fee schedule on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 9-25) 
State Law reference— Holder of statewide electrical contractor's license exempt from local examination requirement, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-5716. 
Sec. 9-54. - Electrical contractor to have place of business in city; temporary office. 
Every licensed electrical contractor doing business in the city shall have an established place of business within the city, provided that contractors having fixed places of business without the limits of the city may erect a temporary booth or structure to be used as offices, and which shall be maintained as long as such contract work shall be in progress and until such work has been duly inspected and passed by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 9-24) 
Sec. 9-55. - Work to be done under supervision of licensed electrician. 
(a)  A person holding a valid statewide license shall be deemed to be a certified electrician or electrical contractor, who must obtain a city business license. 
(b)  All work shall be done under the supervision of a certified electrician or electrical contractor; provided, that any firm or corporation, one (1) member or employee of which holds a license issued by the state, shall be authorized to do business in its firm or corporation name, but provided further, that the actual work or installation undertaken shall be under the direct supervision of such certified electrician or electrical contractor. 
(Code 1967, § 9-17) 
State Law reference— Holder of statewide electrical contractor's license exempt from local examination requirement, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-5716. 
Sec. 9-56. - Improper use of licensee's name. 
Any person who shall knowingly permit any other person, not holding a license as provided for in this article, to secure, in the name of such licensee, a permit to do any electrical work of any nature or kind whatsoever in the city, which contract or work shall not be, bona fide, the work, contract or employment of such person holding said license, shall upon proof thereof before the building official, forfeit such license and he shall not thereafter receive a license for a period of one (1) year. 
(Code 1967, § 9-18)

Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to prescribe fire safety regulations, § 2-9(kk). 
Cross reference— Fire district, § 5-6; burning of solid waste, § 25-103 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide fire protection services, Ga. Code Ann., § 2-6102; crossing fire hose, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-1110; following fire apparatus, § 68A-1109. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - State safety fire commissioner; rules and regulations adopted. 
The rules and regulations now and hereafter promulgated for the prevention of destruction of life and property by fire, explosion and related hazards in this state by the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, under authority of the powers vested in and duties imposed upon said Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner by the laws of Georgia (Acts of 1949, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-701 et seq.), are hereby adopted as rules and regulations of this city. 
(Code 1967, § 10-5) 
State Law reference— Inspections by local inspection departments serving as state inspections, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-706. 
Sec. 10-2. - Same—Cooperation by city officials. 
The local fire marshal for this city, when appointed, together with all other city officials, department heads and employees, shall lend their cooperation to the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, state fire marshal and/or his deputies or assistants whenever called upon by him or them in the enforcement of the Georgia Safety Fire Law (Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-701 et seq.) and the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 10-6) 
State Law reference— State fire marshal, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-704 et seq.; local fire marshal, § 92A-706. 
Sec. 10-3. - Self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps. 
(a)  Self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps shall be allowed in the city. 
(b)  If the council determines that the operation of self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps will not be injurious to the health or welfare of the residents of the city, it shall grant a license to any applicant that meets the local and state regulations governing same and is not otherwise disqualified by law who shall make application on a form prescribed by the council. The license shall be effective from January 1 to December 31 of each year. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a self-service motor fuel dispensing pump unless he shall have obtained a valid license from the council and an attendant is present at the pump's location. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to motor fuel dispensing units which are not open to the public. 
(Ord. of 4-9-73, § 1; Ord. No. 2-76, 3-8-76) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate the transportation, storage and use of combustible materials, § 2-9(vv). 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 23-2713 et seq., 23-9914; Gasoline Marketing Practices Act, Ga. Code Ann., § 106-1101 et seq. 
Sec. 10-4. - Turning on fire hydrant. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an authorized city official or employee, to turn on a fire hydrant. 
(Code 1967, § 10-3) 
Secs. 10-5—10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Police authority of fire department, § 28-2. 

Sec. 10-21. - Full-time. 
There shall be a full-time fire department. Said fire department is to employ three (3) full-time employees, and one (1) or more of said full-time employees are to be on duty at the said fire department twenty-four (24) hours a day, every day of the year. Said fire department is to employ nineteen (19) volunteer firemen which said volunteer firemen will respond to every fire alarm and participate in fighting any and all fires to be controlled or extinguished by the fire department. 
(Ord. of 9-24-73, § 1) 
Sec. 10-22. - Calls outside city limits. 
The volunteer fire department shall man the county fire equipment under the following provisions: 
(1)  The fire siren will sound in answer to a county fire call, and the county will pay each fireman answering the call the same sum that the city pays. 
(2)  Three (3) firefighters will man the county fire equipment, and the county will pay the sum of five dollars ($5.00) per person per hour after the first hour or portion of an hour. 
(3)  The county will maintain and furnish equipment and supplies for all out-of-town fire calls and will furnish insurance protection for its equipment. 
(4)  The county will help pay for the construction of a new building to house its equipment on a pro rata basis of a five-year contract, the cost of the construction to be determined jointly by the city and the county. 
(Code 1967, § 10-2; Ord. of 3-8-76, § 1-4) 
Sec. 10-23. - User fee for fire department services. 
(1)  The City of Nashville's Fire Department shall initiate user fees for the delivery of fire department services, personnel, supplies, and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle accidents and structure fires. The rate of the user fees shall be that which is the usual, customary and reasonable costs (UCR), which included any services, personnel, supplies and equipment and may fluctuate based on the needs of the accident or fire. 
(2)  The user fees shall be filed upon the motor vehicle insurance, commercial or homeowner's insurance, representing an add-on-cost of the claim for damages of the vehicles, property and/or injuries. The claim costs shall be filed against the insurance coverage of the owner of a vehicle, owner of the property, or responsible party. 
(3)  The City of Nashville's Fire Department, at the option of the governing board for each respective department, are authorized to initiate a user fee for the delivery of fire department services, personnel, supplies and equipment to the scene of an oil and hazardous waste incident. The rate of the user fee shall be that which is the usual, customary, and reasonable costs (UCR), which includes any services, personnel, supplies and equipment and may fluctuate based on the needs of the incident. The user fee shall be filed against the vehicle, commercial or homeowner's insurance, representing an add-on-cost of the claim for damages of the property. The claim costs shall be filed upon the insurance coverage of the owner of the property, or responsible party. 
(4)  The respective fire department or their designees are hereby authorized to execute any and all documents and/or implement any and all procedures necessary to effectuate the collection of fees in order to enhance services by the fire department. 
(5)  The city manager and/or finance director may make rules or regulations, and from time-to-time may amend, revoke and add rules and regulations consistent with this section as they deem necessary or expedient in respect to billing for these fees or the collection thereof. 
(6)  All amounts collected as a result of this section shall be placed into a fund as established by the city manager to be used exclusively for personnel, supplies and equipment for the fire department. 
(Ord. of 8-10-07, §§ 1—6) 
Secs. 10-24—10-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 10-39. - Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the "Fire Prevention Code" recommended by the American Insurance Association, being particularly the 1976 edition thereof, and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, a copy of which has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city limits. 
(Code 1967, § 10-4) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to adopt recognized codes by reference, § 2-9(nn). 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5-23; electrical code, § 9-33; gas code, § 11-16; heating and air conditioning code, § 13-1; housing code, § 14-1; plumbing code, § 22-19. 
Sec. 10-40. - Modifications. 
The chief of the fire department shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the codes shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed shall be entered upon the records of the fire department and a signed copy shall be furnished to the applicant. 
Sec. 10-41. - Appeals. 
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief to the city council within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. 
Sec. 10-42. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
The chief of the fire department shall determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall required permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the fire prevention code. The chief of the fire department shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
Sec. 10-43. - Conflicts. 
In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted by this article and applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations shall prevail and be controlling. 
Sec. 10-44. - Gasoline storage tanks. 
All storage tanks for the storing of any kind of flammable gas or liquid (gasoline, etc.,) therein and located within the city shall be located no less thank one and one-half (½) feet below the surface of the land except storage tanks belonging to petroleum or gasoline wholesalers who have an unexpired wholesale gasoline or petroleum license from the city. 
(Ord. of 10-12-70, § I) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate the transportation, storage and use of combustible materials, § 2-9(vv).

ARTICLE II. - GAS CODE[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 11-16. - Adopted. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the desire of the Nashville City Council to adopt, in all aspects, the various Georgia codes relating to building, gas, energy, housing, mechanics, plumbing and electricity. The adoption of these codes is done to facilitate proper inspection activities by the City of Nashville, Berrien County, Georgia, relating to construction and to maintenance of buildings within the corporate limits of said city and relating to public safety, health and general welfare.

Any matters in said code which are contrary to existing ordinances of the city shall prevail and all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this section are hereby repealed, and this section shall be in full force and effect immediately upon its adoption and publication as provided by law. 
(d)  Transfer of responsibility. Within said code when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein; those designated officials of the city who have duties corresponding to those of the named officials in said code shall be deemed to be the responsible officials insofar as enforcing the provisions of said code is concerned. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88, §§ 1—3) 
Editor's note— Having not expressly amended the Code, §§ 1—3 of an ordinance enacted July 25, 1988, have been treated as superseding the former provisions codified herein as §§ 11-16—11-19. Said former provisions pertained to the adoption of the gas code, amendments and additions, standards applicable thereto, and conflicts between the gas code and other ordinances, rules and regulations. These provisions were derived from provisions presumably enacted during the 1980 codification and from Code 1967, §§ 19-29, 19-30, 19-38 and 19-40. 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to adopt gas codes by reference, § 2-9(ll). 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5-23; electrical code, § 9-33; fire prevention code, § 10-39 et seq.; heating and air conditioning code, § 13-1; housing code, § 14-1; plumbing code, § 22-19 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt state standard codes, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 84-6014—84-6017; authority to continue to operate under other codes or adopt more restrictive provisions, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 84-6013, 84-6015. 
Secs. 11-17—11-19. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note to § 11-16. 
Sec. 11-20. - Provisions of permit. 
Each permit shall state the kind of work to be performed thereunder and that it shall be unlawful for any person to do or perform any work other than that designated in said permit. Such permit shall also state the location by street and number of the consumer's premises where such work is to be done and shall be valid only for the location so stated. A separate permit shall be issued for each consumer's premises and shall terminate ninety (90) days after issuance unless extended by the gas inspector for good and sufficient cause. 
(Code 1967, § 19-38) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
Sec. 11-21. - Effect of permit. 
The issuance or granting of a permit shall not be deemed or construed to be a permit for or approval of any violation of the provisions of this chapter or any other law. No permit purporting to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter shall be valid. 
(Code 1967, § 19-34) 
Sec. 11-22. - Permit where gas not used for one year. 
A new permit shall be required for a consumer's premises which have already been piped for gas but in which no gas has been used for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months or more. 
(Code 1967, § 19-43) 
Sec. 11-23. - Temporary use of gas. 
When only the temporary use of gas is desired, the building official, upon application, may issue a permit for a temporary use for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days, provided that the consumer's gas facility is given a test similar to that required for any facility for which a longer use is contemplated. 
(Code 1967, § 19-35) 
Sec. 11-24. - Emergencies. 
In the event of any emergency endangering the life, health, safety or property of any person and necessitating immediate repairs to any gas facility or gas appliance, the owners of such gas facility or appliance without first obtaining a permit shall take or cause to be taken immediate emergency action for the protection of life, health, safety and property through such appropriate measures as may be required to cure or remedy the dangerous conditions and not later than the next succeeding business day such owner shall apply for a permit as required under this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 19-37) 
Sec. 11-25. - Notice of completion of work. 
When any work done under a permit issued by the building official is completed and ready for inspection, the person to whom the permit has been issued shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after completion, give notice to the building official that the same has been completed and is ready for inspection, and the building official shall cause said work to be inspected within a reasonable time thereafter. 
(Code 1967, § 19-39) 
Sec. 11-26. - Defective work or materials. 
If the inspection shall show that defective materials have been used or defective workmanship has been performed in the construction, installation, alteration, repair or extension of any gas pipe fixture in or on any consumer's premises, such defective materials or work shall be replaced by the permittee within three (3) days, after which the building official shall reinspect the replaced materials or work. 
(Code 1967, § 19-45) 
Sec. 11-27. - Proximity of gas to water line. 
No person shall install a gas service line on consumer's premises in the same ditch as the water service line without written permission of the utilities department. 
(Code 1967, § 19-56) 
Sec. 11-28. - Disconnection of dangerous or defective facilities. 
The building official is authorized to cause to be disconnected any gas facility or appliance connected before a certificate of approval has been issued which upon inspection shall be found defective or in such condition as to endanger life, health and safety or property. In all cases where such disconnection is made a notice shall be affixed thereto and shall state that the same has been disconnected by the building official, together with the reason or reasons therefor, and it shall be unlawful for any person to remove said notice or to reconnect said gas facility or appliance until authorized by the building official to do so. 
(Code 1967, § 19-46) 
Sec. 11-29. - Repairs or alterations. 
Repairs or alterations to gas facilities or gas appliances shall be made with such materials, by such methods and according to such standards as are provided for by this chapter for new work except when in the opinion of the building official it is impractical to do so. 
(Code 1967, § 19-52) 
Sec. 11-30. - Exceeding rated capacity. 
In no case shall a gas appliance be fired or adjusted to pass a greater amount of gas than the rated capacity of the particular gas appliance. 
(Code 1967, § 19-51) 
Sec. 11-31. - Unauthorized devices. 
No person shall sell or offer to sell, lease, connect or install within the corporate limits of the city any device purporting to reduce gas consumption when such device is intended as an adjunct or addition to a gas appliance which in any way will reduce the effectiveness of ignition of the gas issuing from the burner or impair the combustion of such burner. 
(Code 1967, § 19-54) 
Sec. 11-32. - Devices for reducing gas consumption. 
No person shall install or use any device intended as an adjunct or addition to a gas appliance or to be suspended above or wholly or partially to enclose any burner of a gas appliance in such manner as to reduce the effectiveness of the ignition of the gas issuing from the burner or impair combustion of said burner. No person shall cause gas supplied by the utilities department to bypass the meter by which the amount of gas supplied by the department is measured. 
(Code 1967, § 19-55) 
Sec. 11-33. - Vents as nuisances. 
No person shall permit or suffer any vent to unduly annoy the residents, occupants or owners of any building in the neighborhood. If such annoyance is caused by any vent, the building official shall cause the vent to be altered, relocated or improved, or carried to such height as may be necessary for the protection of the neighboring property. 
(Code 1967, § 19-48) 
Sec. 11-34. - Conversion of appliances to gas. 
Before a gas supply is furnished by the city to a consumer who has previously been using butane or other liquefied petroleum gases, the city shall properly adjust all appliances to insure safe operation of the burners and proper combustion of the gas. When converting to liquid petroleum gas from natural gas all appliances shall be properly adjusted to insure safe operation of the burner and combustion of petroleum gas. 
(Code 1967, § 19-53) 
Sec. 11-35. - Heating appliance conversion. 
All heating appliances which are converted to gas shall be vacuumed, cleaned and brushed down. 
(Code 1967, § 19-49) 
Sec. 11-36. - Refusal of service. 
The utilities department is authorized to discontinue or refuse to supply gas for any gas facility or gas appliance which it may find to be defective or leaky or in such condition as to endanger life, health, safety or property. In such case, the utilities department shall immediately give written notice of discontinuance or refusal of service to the building official and to the consumers. The building official shall immediately make an investigation of the conditions reported by the utilities department and it shall be unlawful for any person to reconnect said gas facility or appliance until authorized by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 19-47) 
Sec. 11-37. - City's facility. 
No person, unless in the employ of the city gas system, shall repair, alter or open a gas facility of the city or set or remove a gas service meter or do any other work on the gas supply system of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 19-36) 
Sec. 11-38. - Liability of the city. 
This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee thereof any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured by any defect in any gas facility or appliance or by any work in connection therewith; nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof be deemed to have assumed any such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized hereunder or by the issuance of any certificate of approval, permit or license hereunder by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 19-32) 
State Law reference— Powers, duties and liabilities of cities, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-301 et seq. 
Secs. 11-39—11-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS FITTERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 15. 

Sec. 11-55. - Gas fitter's license. 
No person shall construct, install, extend, alter, repair or improve any gas facility or gas appliance within the city unless such person has first procured a gas fitter's license therefor from the building official as provided in this article. All applications for such license shall be in writing upon forms to be prescribed by the building official. All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire within one (1) year from the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked as herein provided, shall be nontransferable and shall be posted conspicuously to public view in the principal place of business of the licensee. The provisions of this section apply only to such work as is performed on the property or premises of consumers. 
(Code 1967, § 19-64) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to license building trades, § 2-9(ll). 
Sec. 11-56. - License fee. 
The license fee for a gas fitter shall be fixed by the council. 
(Code 1967, § 19-65) 
Sec. 11-57. - Surety bond. 
Before any license is granted to any person under this article there shall be filed with the building official a bond or policy of public liability; such bond or insurance policy shall be written in limits not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) each person and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each accident for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each accident for property damage liability and shall include coverage for the hazard of explosion executed by the applicant and a surety company authorized to do business in this state as surety, running to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the licensee of all work in full compliance with all provisions of this article and any person injured by failure of said licensee to comply with the provisions of this article shall have the right of action against the licensee and his surety in his name. Provided, however, that any person wishing to avail himself of the benefits of the surety bond shall commence action thereof within one (1) year after the date of the completion of the work alleged to have been improperly performed. The bond herein required shall expire on the thirty-first day of December next following its approval by the city clerk and thereafter by the first day of January of each year a new bond, in form and substance as herein required, shall be given by such person to cover all work he shall perform during each year. Any such bond shall be approved as to form and legal content by the city attorney. A license as hereinabove provided may be issued upon approval of such surety bond, provided the requirements hereof are fulfilled. 
(Code 1967, § 19-66) 
Sec. 11-58. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
Any license granted under provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked by the building official whenever it shall be made to appear to him that the person to whom the license is issued has violated any of the provisions of this article. In the event the building official shall suspend or revoke said license he shall cause to be served upon the licensee a formal order of suspension or revocation of said license which order shall recite the reason therefor. An appeal from any order of the building official suspending or revoking a license granted hereunder may be taken to the council within five (5) days after service upon the licensee of the order of suspension or revocation. Action by the council upon such revocation or suspension shall be deemed final. The suspension or revocation of a license shall not entitle the licensee to a refund of any unearned portion of the fee paid. Any order provided for in this article shall be served either by delivering a copy personally upon the licensee or by leaving a copy with some person of suitable age and discretion at the place of business of the licensee or, if no person may be found at the place of business of the licensee, by leaving such order in a conspicuous place on the premises and mailing a copy of the order to the licensee at his place of business as set forth in his application for a license. 
(Code 1967, § 19-67)
