ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1—12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal regulation of food service establishments, Ga. Code Ann., § 88-1002. 

Sec. 12-16. - Health certificate—Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or from the city to engage in the business of serving food or preparing it for the public consumption in or from any cafe, lunch room, lunch stand, boarding house, hotel, mobile food vendor or any other place where the public is invited to enter or be served from; or for any person to engage in the sale or handling of any meats, fish, oyster, soft drinks, ice cream or soda water or to be employed as a cook or nursemaid in a private home, until and after such person shall be examined by the health officer and a certificate furnished him or her establishing his or her freedom from any disease which might be transmissible through the operation of the business or the performance of the work engaged in. 
(Code 1967, § 12-4; Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-17. - Health certificate—Annual physical. 
Each person engaged in any of the businesses enumerated in this article shall at all times hold a certificate from the health officer showing a physical examination within twelve (12) months of said time and a freedom from contagious disease. 
(Code 1967, § 12-5) 
Sec. 12-18. - Health certificate—In holder's possession; special examination; revocation. 
Each person engaged in any of the enumerated businesses shall at all times, keep his or her certificate of health in his or her possession and submit the same for inspection to any officer of the city when called upon. In addition to provisions hereof, all persons engaged in the business or businesses enumerated in this article shall at all times be subject to further inspection as to the matter in which such business or businesses are conducted, and the health officer shall at all times have the right to require other and special examinations of such persons, in his discretion, and upon examination, he may revoke any certificate previously given to such persons. 
(Code 1967, § 12-6) 
Sec. 12-19. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
(a)  Commissary shall mean an approved catering establishment, restaurant, or other approved place in which food, containers or supplies are kept, handled, prepared, packaged or stored. 
(b)  Mobile food vendor shall mean a retail food establishment that reports to and operates from a commissary and is readily moveable, is a motorized wheeled vehicle, or a towed wheeled vehicle designed and equipped to serve food. 
(c)  Pushcart shall mean a non-self-propelled vehicle limited to serving commissary prepared or prepackaged food and non-potentially hazardous food, unless the equipment is commercially designed and approved to handle food preparation and service. Pushcarts shall not be required to comply with mobile vehicular safety requirements. 
(d)  Temporary food establishment shall mean a retail food establishment, other than a licensed mobile food vendor or pushcart, that is not intended to be permanent and that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than three (3) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. 
(e)  Ice cream truck shall mean a motor vehicle in which ice cream, popsicles, ice sherbets or other frozen desserts of any kind are carried for the purpose of retail sale on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-20. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, food of any type from a commissary, mobile retail food establishment, pushcart or temporary food establishment without a license first having been granted under this section, except for city-sponsored events. 
(b)  An application for a license or a permit hereunder shall be submitted to the city manager or his or her designee setting forth all information required hereunder and in compliance with this ordinance. The city manager or his or her designee shall develop a form of application for the purpose of compliance with this article. 
(c)  The following information shall be provided with each application for a mobile food vendor permit: 
(1)  Name of the mobile food vendor; 
(2)  Make, model, and license plate number of vending unit; 
(3)  Owner's contact information; (cell phone, email address mailing address) 
(4)  Operator's contact information; (cell phone, email address mailing address) 
(5)  Type of vendor (street vending unit or sidewalk vending unit); 
(6)  Copy of approved permit from the Berrien County Health Department; 
(7)  List of operating locations and times; 
(8)  Signatures from property owners indicating consent for the use of their property; 
(9)  Signature of applicant indicating agreement to the listed requirements. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-21. - Prohibited conduct and requirements. 
(a)  Except for ice cream trucks, no mobile food vendor shall conduct business or operate in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  A mobile food vendor shall not operate on any private property without the prior consent of the owner. 
(c)  A mobile food vendor shall maintain a one million-dollar ($1,000,000.00) liability insurance policy. Proof of current liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in Georgia, protecting the mobile food vendor, the public and the city from all claims for damage to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the permit. Such insurance shall name the city as an additional insured and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date without thirty (30) days' advanced written notice to the city. 
(d)  Except for ice cream trucks, a mobile food vendor shall not make sounds or announcements to call attention to the mobile food vehicle either while traveling on the public rights-of-way or when stationary. At all times said mobile food vendor shall be in compliance with the City of Nashville noise ordinance. 
(e)  The license under which a mobile food vendor is operating must be firmly attached and visible on the mobile food vendor or pushcart at all times. 
(f)  Any driver of a mobile food vendor motorized vehicle must possess a valid Georgia driver's license. 
(g)  Except for ice cream trucks, mobile food vendors are allowed only in commercial and industrial zoning districts. 
(h)  Mobile food vendors shall not be located within fifteen (15) feet of any street intersection or pedestrian crosswalk or ten (10) feet of any driveway. 
(i)  No sale or offer for sale shall be made by any mobile food vendor between 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. unless such sale is in conjunction with a city-approved special event or film production permit. 
(j)  Vending structures shall not be left unattended or stored at any time on the open vending site when vending is not taking place or during restricted hours of operation. 
(k)  No sale or offer for sale of food ice cream, frozen milk, frozen dairy or ice confection products shall be made from a mobile food vendor unless each side of the vehicle is marked, in letters and numbers at least three (3) inches in height, with the name and address of the mobile food vendor licensee. 
(l)  The mobile food vendor shall comply with all state, federal and local health and safety regulations and requirements and shall obtain and maintain any and all licenses required by any other health, organization or governmental organization having jurisdiction over this subject matter. 
(m)  The following safety regulations shall apply to any and all vehicles operating under this article or used for mobile retail food establishments: 
(1)  Every vehicle shall be equipped with a reverse gear signal alarm with a sound distinguishable from the surrounding noise level. 
(2)  Every vehicle shall be equipped with two (2) rear-vision mirrors, one (1) at each side, firmly attached to the outside of the motor vehicle, and so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the highway to the rear, along both sides of the vehicle. 
(n)  The mobile food vendor may sell food and non-alcoholic beverage items only. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-22. - Indemnity. 
As part of the permitting process set forth herein, any person or entity receiving a permit set forth herein shall execute an indemnity agreement indemnifying and releasing the City of Nashville, its agents, employees and elected officials from any and all liability against any and all claims, actions and suits of any type whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-23. - Revocation and suspension. 
The city shall have the right to revoke or suspend any license granted hereunder effective immediately which said suspension may be appealed by permittee within ten (10) days to the council. Provided however, said suspension shall remain in effect until over turned upon hearing before the council. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Sec. 12-24. - Fee. 
The fees for applications for license under this section shall be set by resolution. 
(Ord. No. O-02-18, 9-10-18) 
Secs. 12-25—12-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRUGS AND DRUG APPARATUS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Controlled Substances Act, Ga. Code Ann., § 79A-801 et seq. 

Sec. 12-35. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases used in this article shall have the following meaning unless the context otherwise requires: 
Apothecary means a licensed pharmacist as defined by the laws of this state and, where the context so requires, the owner of a store or other place of business where narcotic drugs are compounded or dispensed by a licensed pharmacist; but nothing in this article shall be construed as conferring on a person who is not registered nor licensed as a pharmacist any authority, right or privilege that is not granted to him by the pharmacy laws of this state. 
Coca leaves includes cocaine and any compound, manufacture, salt derivative, mixture or preparation of coca leaves, except derivatives of coca leaves which do not contain cocaine, ecgonine or substances from which cocaine or ecgonine may be synthesized or made. 
Dentist means a person authorized by law to practice dentistry in this state. 
Drugs means coca leaves, opium, isonipecaine, marijuana and every other substance neither chemically nor physically distinguishable from them and any other drugs to which the federal laws regulating narcotic drugs may not apply; and any drug found by the state board of pharmacy to have an addiction-forming or addiction-sustaining liability similar to morphine or cocaine; Methylphenidate NCI (Ritalin); Phencyclindine NCI (PCP); Methylbenzilate; Diethyltryptaimine (DET); N-Methyl-3-piperdyl Benzilate (HCI) (LBJ, JB-336); N-Ethyl-3-piperdyl Benzilate HCI (JB-318); Benactylzine HCI (DMZ); 3, 4-Methylendedioxy amphetamine HCI (STP, DoM); Dipropyltryptamine (DPT); Chlordiazepoxide (Librium); Asmadore; any drug, which under the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (52 Stat. 1040 (1938)), Title 21, United States Code, section 301, or under any law of this state, may be dispensed only upon prescription; any drug which the state board of pharmacy shall determine to be dangerous or detrimental to the public health when taken in accordance to directions. 
Hospital means an institution for the care and treatment of the sick and injured approved by the state board of pharmacy as proper to be intrusted with the custody of narcotic drugs and the professional use of narcotic drugs under the direction of a physician, dentist or veterinarian. 
Marijuana means all parts of the plant Cannibis sativa L., whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or resin; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plants, any other compound, manufacture, salt derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, cake or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
Opium includes morphine, codeine and heroin, and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of opium, but does not include apomorphine or any of its salts. 
Physician means a person authorized to practice medicine in this state and any other person authorized by law to treat sick and injured human beings in this state and to use narcotic drugs in connection with such treatment, including osteopaths who are authorized to secure a federal narcotic permit as allowed physicians and other persons. Provided, however, osteopaths shall be allowed to purchase, prescribe, dispense and administer, for the alleviation of pain only, certain narcotic drugs, to-wit: Those narcotic drugs or their derivative, the sale or dispensing of which is regulated by the federal act known as "The Harrison Narcotic Act," as amended, said Act being set out in 26 U.S.C.A., Internal Revenue Code, Section 3220 et seq. 
Veterinarian means a person authorized by law to practice veterinary medicine in this state. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, § 5) 
State Law reference— Pharmacists, Ga. Code Ann., § 79A-401 et seq.; dentists, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-701 et seq.; medical practitioners, § 84-901 et seq.; veterinarians, § 84-1501 et seq. 
Sec. 12-36. - Unlawful possession of drugs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than a person described in Ga. Code Ann., section 79A-814, under the caption registration requirements, to possess drugs known as: 
(1)  Methylphenidate HCI (Ritalin)  Phencyclidine HCI (PCP)  Methylbenzilate  Diethyltryptamine (DET)  N-Methyl-3-piperdyl Benzilate HCI (LBJ, JB-336)  N-Ethyl-3-piperdyl Benzilate HCI (JB-318)  Benactylzine HCI (DMZ)  3, 4-Methylenedioxy amphetamine HCI (MDA)  4-Methyl-2, 5-dimethoxyamphetamine HCI (STP, DOM)  Diprohyltryptamine (DPT)  Chlordiazepoxide (Librium)  Asmadore 
(2)  Any drug which, under the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (52 Stat. 1040 (1938)), Title 21, United States Code, Section 301, or under any law of this state, may be dispensed; 
(3)  Any drug which the state board of pharmacy shall determine to be dangerous or detrimental to the public health when taken in accordance to directions; 
unless (1) such drug was obtained upon a valid prescription and is held in the original container in which such drug was delivered; or (2) such drug was delivered by a practitioner in the course of his professional practice and the drug is held in the immediate container in which said drug was delivered. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, § 4) 
Sec. 12-37. - Unlawful possession of drug apparatus generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any apparatus, device or instrument for the unauthorized use of drugs. Use shall not be unauthorized if authorized by a physician, dentist, veterinarian or hospital. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, § 1) 
Sec. 12-38. - Hypodermic needles and syringes—Possession. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, except a dealer in surgical instruments, physician, apothecary, dentist, veterinarian or nurse, attendant or intern of a hospital, sanatorium or institution in which persons are treated for disability or disease, at any time to have, possess or buy a hypodermic needle or hypodermic syringe unless said possession or purchase is authorized by the prescription or the certificate of a physician, dentist or veterinarian. It shall be unlawful to sell a hypodermic needle or hypodermic syringe unless such sale is authorized by prescription or certificate of a physician, dentist or veterinarian and the prescription or certificate is not to be refilled unless authorized by the prescriber; provided that this action shall not apply if possession, sale or purchase was for a harmless purpose. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, § 3) 
Sec. 12-39. - Same—Destruction. 
All hypodermic syringes and hypodermic needles must be destroyed when no longer in use for medical purposes, and it shall be unlawful not to destroy them. Hypodermic needles shall be broken off from the hub, glass hypodermic syringes shall be broken and disposable hypodermic syringes shall be incinerated. 
(Ord. of 4-24-72, § 2) 
Secs. 12-40—12-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MODEL GLUE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Authority for this article, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1806. 

Sec. 12-56. - Definition. 
The term "model glue," as used in this article, shall mean any glue, cement, solvent or chemical substitute containing one (1) or more of the following chemicals: acetone, amyl chloride (iso- and tertiary), benzene, carbon disulfide, carbon tetrachloride, chloroform, ether, ethyl acetate, ethyl alcohol, ethylene dichloride, isopropyl acetate, isopropyl alcohol, isopropyl ether, methyl acetate, methyl alcohol, propylene dichloride, propylene oxide, trichlorethylene, amyl acetate, amyl alcohol, butyl acetate, butyl alcohol, butyl ether, diethylcarbonate, diethylene oxide (dioxan), dipropyl ketone, ethyl butyrate, ethylene glycol menoethyl ether (cellosolve), ethylene glycol monomethyl ether acetate (methyl cellosolve acetate), isobutyl alcohol, methyl amyl acetate, methyl amyl alcohol, methyl isobutyl ketone, or toluene. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, § II) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1802. 
Sec. 12-57. - Possession, buying, selling or transferring of model glue prohibited. 
No person shall intentionally possess, buy, sell, transfer possession or receive possession of any model glue for the purpose of violating or aiding another person to violate any provision of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, § III) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1803. 
Sec. 12-58. - Purchase by minors. 
No person shall sell or transfer possession of any model glue to another person, under eighteen (18) years of age, nor shall any person under eighteen (18) years of age possess or buy any model glue unless purchase is for model building or other lawful use and the person under eighteen (18) years of age has in his possession and exhibits to the seller or transferor the written consent of his parent or legal guardian to make said purchase or take possession of said model glue; provided, any minor who shall transfer possession of said model glue to another minor for model building or other lawful purpose shall not be held criminally liable for failing to require exhibition of the written consent of the transferee-minor's parents or for failing to keep same available for inspection by law enforcement officials. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, § IV) 
Cross reference— Minors and premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, § 3-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1804. 
Sec. 12-59. - Consent of parent for purchase; records. 
The person making a sale or transfer of possession of model glue to a person under eighteen (18) years of age must require such purchaser to exhibit the written consent of his parent or guardian and the name and address of the consenting parent or guardian. All data required by this article shall be kept available by the seller for inspection by law enforcement officials for a period of six (6) months. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, § V) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1805. 
Sec. 12-60. - Inhaling. 
No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, stupefaction, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration or dulling of the senses or nervous system, intentionally smell or inhale the fumes from any model glue as defined in section 12-56; provided, that this section shall not apply to the inhalation of any anesthesia for medical or dental purposes. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, § I) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1801. 
Secs. 12-61—12-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY 

Sec. 12-77. - Cross-connection and contamination of public water supplies. 
(1)  No person shall construct, maintain or operate a physical arrangement whereby a public water system is or may be connected directly or indirectly with a nonpotable water system or non-permitted water system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture or other device which contains or may contain contaminated water, liquid, gases, sewage or other waste of unknown or unsafe quality, which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water system as the results of backflow, bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeover devices, or other temporary, permanent or potential connections through which or because of which back-flow or back-siphonage could or would occur. 
(2)  A supplier of water or any person having possession or control of facilities which may cause the contamination of a public water system has the responsibility to prevent water from unapproved sources or any contaminants from entering the public water system by such physical arrangements cited in paragraph (1) of this section. 
(3)  Any person connecting to and purchasing water from a public water system and reselling it to others is considered a supplier of the water so purchased as well as a consumer, and is also responsible for the quality of such water. 
(4)  A supplier shall, when requested by the code enforcement officer for the City of Nashville (hereinafter C.E. Officer), develop a control program for the elimination and prevention of all cross-connections. A written plan for the program shall be submitted to the C.E. Officer for review and approval within two (2) weeks or less in accordance with a written request by the C.E. Officer. When the plan is approved, the owner shall implement the program immediately. 
(5)  The procedures for back-flow and back-siphonage prevention and cross-connection control shall conform to those recommended by the American Water Works Association, Manual 14, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Cross-Connection Manual. 
(6)  The supplier shall require that all backflow prevention assemblies installed pursuant to this section be field tested following installation, repair, or relocation and at least annually thereafter. 
(7)  After December 1, 2006, all required field testing shall be performed by persons who are certified in the testing of backflow prevention assemblies by the Georgia Statewide Backflow Prevention Assembly Certification Program, as approved by the division, the American Backflow Prevention Association (ABPA), the American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE) or the University of Florida TREEO Center. 
(8)  Gauges used in the testing of backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested for accuracy annually in accordance with the University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control or American Water Works Association Manual 14. Public water systems shall require testers to include test gauge serial numbers on "test and maintenance" report forms and ensure testers have gauges tested for accuracy. 
(9)  Each water supplier shall maintain records of the following for a minimum of three (3) years: 
(a)  Most current hazard assessment, conducted pursuant to Section 608 of the Georgia State Minimum Standard Plumbing Code (International Plumbing Code); 
(b)  Locations and types of backflow protection and associated hazards; 
(c)  Results of all backflow prevention assembly field testing and air gap inspections; and 
(d)  Repairs made to, or replacement or relocation of, backflow protection. 
(10)  Summaries of the information in subsection (9)(a)—(d) shall be available to the C.E. Officer on request for a minimum of three (3) years. 
(11)  The supplier shall ensure that backflow prevention assemblies that fail the field test are repaired or replaced within thirty (30) days. 
(12)  The supplier shall ensure that bypass piping installed around any approved backflow preventer is equipped with a backflow preventer providing an equivalent level of protection. 
(13)  Reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in any location subject to possible flooding. This includes pits and/or vaults which are not provided with a gravity drain to the ground's surface that is capable of exceeding the discharge rate of the relief valve. 
(14)  Each supplier shall notify the C.E. Officer of any known incident of backflow into the public water system as soon as possible but no later than the end of the next business day upon discovery of the incident. If requested to do so by the C.E. Officer, the supplier shall submit a written report of the incident describing the nature and severity of the backflow, the actions taken by the water supplier in response to the incident, and the action plan intended to prevent such incidents in the future. 
(15)  The supplier of water shall deny or discontinue water service to a commercial consumer if a required backflow prevention device is not installed or properly maintained. Water service shall not be restored to such premises until the deficiencies have been corrected or eliminated to the satisfaction of the supplier and the C.E. Officer. Residential connections shall be maintained in accordance with the Georgia State Minimum Standard Plumbing Code (International Plumbing Code). 
(16)  To assist in the implementation and enforcement of this section and to ensure that the City of Nashville is aware of all potential contaminating sources, no person, firm, business or other entity recognized under statute law shall own, dig, install, reopen or operate any private well system which may result in contamination of any public water system without first obtaining a private well permit from the C.E. Officer for the City of Nashville. An application for such permit shall be filed with the C.E. Officer on a form provided by the City of Nashville pursuant to procedures established by the C.E. Officer. The permit may be issued within two (2) weeks provided the C.E. Officer determines the proposed well is in compliance with the applicable local, state and federal laws, poses no significant or reasonably definable threat to the public water supply as contemplated herein, and is consistent with the policies and procedures adopted by the city council for the City of Nashville. The cost of such permit shall be $_____. 
(17)  If any section, paragraph, clause, phrase or provision of this section shall be adjudged invalid or held unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the remaining portion of this section. 
(Ord. of 11-11-06, §§ (1)—(17); Ord. of 2-14-11) 
Sec. 12-78. - Outdoor watering of landscape. 
(1)  Restriction on outdoor watering of landscape. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(a)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(b)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable city ordinances and state guidelines; 
(c)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(d)  Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; 
(e)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(f)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; 
(g)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(h)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld containers; 
(i)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(j)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(k)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(l)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration or irrigation systems; or 
(m)  Hydroseeding. 
(2)  Enforcement. 
(a)  No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this section. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer shall be the enforcement authority for this section. The city manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(c)  Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the municipal court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. 
(Ord. of 1-3-11)

(c)  Conflicts and effect. Within said code when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein those designated officials of the city who have duties corresponding to those of the named officials in said code shall be deemed to be the responsible officials insofar as enforcing the provisions of said code is concerned. 
(Ord. of 7-25-88, §§ 1—3)

Chapter 15 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— The schedule of license taxes is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to levy license fees and taxes on occupations, § 2-9(r). 
Cross reference— Building contractors, § 5-42 et seq.; electrical contractors, § 9-51 et seq.; gas fitters, § 11-55 et seq.; plumbing contractors, § 22-43 et seq.; license of contract solid waste collectors, § 25-133; taxation generally, Ch. 27. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-1. - Levy of tax. 
For the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of the government of the city, the license taxes specified and listed in the ordinance from which this article is derived are hereby levied and are to be collected for each fiscal year beginning January 1 and ending December 31. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 1) 
Editor's note— The schedule of license taxes is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Cross reference— License to erect monuments, § 6-5. 
Sec. 15-2. - Violation by company or corporation. 
Should any offender under this article be a company or corporation, resident or nonresident, the officers, agents or representatives of such company or corporation acting for or representing it shall be deemed guilty of any violation by the company or corporation. 
(Code 1967, § 14-4; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 20) 
Sec. 15-3. - Applicability of tax. 
The license taxes are levied against and are to be paid by all persons, whether residents or nonresidents of the city, who may engage in, prosecute, follow or carry on within the corporate limits of the city, either by themselves or through agents or other representatives, any trade, business, calling, vocation or profession specified and scheduled in the ordinance from which this article is derived. The amount of said license tax levied by this article on the respective trades, businesses, callings, vocations and professions, or on persons engaged in, prosecuting or carrying on the same, are set forth in the schedule on file in the office of the city clerk, which schedule is specifically made a part of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 14-9; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 2) 
Sec. 15-4. - Wholesalers selling at retail. 
Operators of trucks paying a wholesale license fee for delivery shall be charged a retail license fee also if they make sales to individuals in competition with merchants. The retail license fee shall be the same as the wholesale license fee. 
(Mo. of 12-29-75) 
Sec. 15-5. - Each location of a business taxed. 
Should any person engage in, prosecute or carry on any trade, business, calling, vocation or profession at different places in the city, each place shall be subject to the license tax herein provided. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 17) 
Sec. 15-6. - Doing business in the city defined. 
Every person operating or maintaining a factory, office, plant or business property of any nature, without the corporate limits of the city, who has an office or place of transacting business, or is represented by an officer, agent, employee or servant, in the city, or who makes deliveries of his products in the city limits, by his automobile or other vehicles or his own servants or agents, or solicits business, or who maintains a city salesman in the city for the purpose of soliciting business, or who does business in the city, by retailing or wholesaling his goods, wares or merchandise, shall register with the city clerk and secure a license as provided by this article and pay the same license tax as paid by any person having a similar factory, office, plant or business within the corporate limits of the city, and in default thereof, the said officers, agents, employees or servants for such person shall be subject to be prosecuted and subject to the same penalties as other persons who fail to register and secure from said city clerk a certificate or license. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 14) 
Sec. 15-7. - All businesses at one location taxed. 
In every case where more than one (1) of the trades, callings, businesses, vocations or professions, which are taxed by the terms of this article, shall be pursued or carried on or practiced in the same place by the same person at the same time, the rate and amount severally prescribed in the schedule regulating the same for each trade, business, calling, vocation or profession, and for each different and separate line and character of goods especially enumerated and set out in said schedule, shall be paid. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 15) 
Sec. 15-8. - Registration with city clerk. 
All persons who may engage in, prosecute, follow or carry on any of the trades, businesses, callings, vocations or professions listed in the tax schedule shall, prior to entering upon or continuing such trades, businesses, callings, vocations or professions, register with the city clerk their names together with the trade, business, calling, vocation or profession in which they are engaged, or propose to engage. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 3) 
Sec. 15-9. - Failure to register. 
(a)  Upon the failure of any person to register with the city clerk and pay the license tax when due as provided in this article, said city clerk shall, from the best information obtainable, register the same, and such registration when made shall have all the force and effect as if the defaulting person had duly registered as provided in section 15-8 of this article. There shall be a ten-percent penalty for payment after January first. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of thirty (30) days after such default, or sooner if said city clerk deems necessary to protect the interest of the city, he shall issue a fi fa for the amount of said license tax with interest, as other tax fi fas in favor of the city are issued; thereupon, said city clerk shall turn the same over to the chief of police and it shall be his duty to force collection of the same by levy and sell the same as other tax fi fas in favor of the city. Said city clerk and chief of police shall be entitled to and there shall be paid to them the same items of cost as on other fi fas issued by the city. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, §§ 9, 10) 
State Law reference— Executions, Ga. Code Ann., Title 39, § 81A-169. 
Sec. 15-10. - Misrepresentation. 
Any person who shall use any deceitful means or misrepresentation in the obtaining of a license or permit from the city to do business in the city, shall be guilty of violating this article. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 11) 
State Law reference— Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, Ga. Code Ann., § 106-701 et seq. 
Sec. 15-11. - Fraudulent claim of indigence or disability. 
Any person who shall fraudulently and deceitfully use the official certificate of any indigent or disabled veteran of any war, or blind person, issued to such indigent or disabled veteran of any war, or blind person, under a statute of the state, for the purpose of peddling or conducting any business as provided by the laws of the state, shall be guilty of violating this article. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 12) 
State Law reference— Disabled veterans and blind persons to peddle or conduct business or profession without license, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-2011 et seq.; fraudulent claim of exemption from state tax, Ga. Code Ann., § 92-9922; deceit as giving right of civil action, Ga. Code Ann., § 105-302. 
Sec. 15-12. - Taxation of businesses not specified in schedule. 
All local and itinerant traders, canvassers or agents and all other persons not specifically mentioned in this article shall, before entering upon, engaging in, prosecuting or carrying on any trade, business, calling, vocation or profession in the city, register with the city clerk and secure a certificate or license as provided by this article and pay to said city clerk a license tax fixed by the council for the fiscal period. Provided, however, should any person deem said license tax excessive, upon such person filing with said city clerk an affidavit as to the exact nature of the trade, business, calling, vocation or profession proposed to be engaged in, prosecuted or carried on, it shall be the duty of said city clerk to forthwith notify the chairman of the licenses and business regulations committee, who may immediately convene said committee in extra session for the purpose of fixing a reasonable license tax, or same may be taken up at a regular meeting of the city council, whose findings shall be final. 
(Code 1967, §§ 14-6—14-8; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 16) 
Sec. 15-13. - Issuance of certificate or license. 
Upon the persons registering with the city clerk as provided in this article, said city clerk shall issue to said person so registering a certificate or license certifying that such person has paid the license tax, said certificate or license to be in such form as said city clerk may determine; provided, however, the same shall be signed by him as such city clerk. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 4) 
Sec. 15-14. - Conditions for issuance of certificate or license. 
The city clerk shall issue a certificate or license only: 
(1)  When satisfied that the business, trade, calling, vocation or profession does not, and will not, violate the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the city; and 
(2)  Upon the fulfillment of the registration requirements of this article; and 
(3)  Upon the payment of the license tax levied by this article. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 5) 
Cross reference— Zoning, App. A. 
Sec. 15-15. - Oath of licensee. 
The city clerk may administer an oath to all persons taking out a license under this article or cause the same to be administered in his presence, as to the nature of the trade, business, calling, vocation or profession proposed to be engaged in, prosecuted or carried on; and where the amount of the license tax levied by this article depends upon amount or quantity, said oath shall also include statements necessary to determine or arrive at the license tax to be paid; and if the person applying for such license is acting for or on behalf of any firm, company or corporation, such person shall state his connection with such firm, company or corporation, and said city clerk shall be satisfied that such person has authority to represent such firm, company or corporation and has knowledge of the facts of which he deposes. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 13) 
Cross reference— Duties of city clerk generally, § 2-44. 
Sec. 15-16. - Payment of tax; interest; returned checks. 
The license taxes are due and payable in advance, the same to be due and payable to the city clerk at the time of registration or when such registration should have been made; and said license tax, if not paid when due, shall bear interest at the rate of seven (7) percent per annum from March first of the year of issue, or from the date of beginning business in the city if said business is begun after March first. There will be an automatic penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount of the license fee in any instance where a check given in payment of said license is returned to the city clerk by the bank on which it is drawn for any reason whatsoever. 
(Code 1967, § 14-5; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 6) 
Charter reference— Authority of city to add interest to taxes not paid when due, § 7-3. 
State Law reference— Criminal issuance of a bad check, Ga. Code Ann., § 26-1704. 
Sec. 15-17. - Commencement of business after August first. 
No license will be issued for less than one (1) year, except after August first, at which time when any new business is started, the license may be issued on the basis of six (6) months, except as otherwise specified in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 14-2; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 7) 
Sec. 15-18. - Posting or carrying of certificate or license; inspection. 
Every person to whom a certificate or license is issued by the city clerk under authority of this article shall post the same in a conspicuous place in the place of business for which the same was issued or on the premises where the trade, business, calling, vocation or profession covered by said certificate or license may be engaged in, prosecuted, followed or carried on by the person to whom the same was issued, and in the event he should have or maintain no such place, he shall at all times have and carry the same with him while engaging in, prosecuting, following or carrying on his trade, business, calling, vocation or profession; said certificate or license is at all times subject to be inspected by and on demand of the chief of police or of anyone of the police force. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 8) 
Charter reference— Enforcement of ordinances by members of police department, § 5-7. 
Sec. 15-19. - Authority of chief of police. 
The chief of police shall have full authority to stop vehicles and/or work or carrying on of business in any manner, to impound any vehicle or machinery being used in violation of this article and/or arrest any violator of this article. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 9) 
Charter reference— Arrest powers of police include hot or fresh pursuit, § 5-7. 
Cross reference— Police department, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference— Arrest, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 27-2, Ch. 27-8. 
Sec. 15-20. - Transfer of certificate. 
A certificate or license issued by the city clerk under the authority of this article may be transferred as assigned, except as noted in the schedule of taxes, provided the person conducts the business for which the license was issued at the same place and pays to said city clerk ten (10) percent of the amount of the license tax provided in this article for the carrying on of said business. If the business is moved to a different location, with the same owner and operators, the license may also be transferred to said new location by notifying the city clerk or the city clerk's office. In the event that the proper authorities are not notified, an additional ten (10) percent fee shall be charged for the transfer. 
(Code 1967, § 14-3; Ord. of 1-14-74, § 7) 
Sec. 15-21. - License valid for only one calendar year. 
No business or professional license to operate within the city shall have an extent of coverage to exceed a single calendar year. 
(Code 1967, § 14-1) 
Sec. 15-22. - Suspension or revocation. 
All licenses, permits or other authority to engage in, prosecute or carry on any trade, business, calling, vocation or profession for which a license tax is levied by this article shall be subject to suspension or revocation by the council if and when the council may find or determine that the same is being used for a purpose not intended, or that it is in the public interest of the city that same be suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 18) 
Sec. 15-23. - Farm products. 
While the legal right of the producer to sell the product of his own farm is distinctly recognized, this right shall not be construed so as to authorize any person to purchase goods or produce or other things of value within or without the city and bring the same within the city and offer same for sale to either merchants or customers. He shall be deemed a peddler and shall be required to obtain a license as such, whether he offers for sale eggs, chickens, farm products or other things of value. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 23) 
State Law reference— Farm products exempt from taxation, Ga. Code Ann. § 92-201. 
Sec. 15-24. - Proceedings under prior ordinance. 
So much, and such parts of ordinances heretofore passed as provided for the issuing and enforcement of execution for and tax assessment, or part of tax assessment, required by any such ordinance, and now remaining unpaid, shall continue and remain in force so as to authorize the issuance of such execution, and the collection of the same, until such taxes or assessments shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74, § 22) 
State Law reference— Executions, Ga. Code Ann., Title 39, § 81A-169. 
DIVISION 2. - OCCUPATION TAXES, ADMINISTRATIVE FEES AND REGULATORY FEES 

Sec. 15-25. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the following meaning. 
Administrative fee: The component of the occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
City: The City of Nashville. 
Employee: An individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA federal income tax or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2 but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
Location or office: A fixed place located within the City of Nashville from which a person conducts business, but shall not include a work site located in the city for less than six (6) months for the purpose of serving a single customer or project. 
Occupation tax: A tax levied for revenue purposes on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business in the City of Nashville. 
Occupation tax certificate: A document issued by the City of Nashville acknowledging payment of the occupation tax and administrative fee. 
Practitioners of professions and occupations: Those individuals listed in O.C.G.A. section 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) but does not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if such business pays an occupation tax. 
Regulatory fee: A fee which approximates the cost of regulatory activity by the city. 
Regulatory fee certificate: A document issued by the City of Nashville acknowledging payment of a regulatory fee. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1; Ord. of 12-11-95) 
Sec. 15-26. - Administrative fee. 
A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is required on all occupation tax accounts for the initial registration, annual renewal or reopening of such accounts. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-27. - Regulatory fee. 
(a)  Businesses and individuals engaging in the occupations or businesses set forth in Appendix A must pay a nonrefundable regulatory fee in accordance with the rate set forth in Appendix A. 
(b)  If a business or individual initially engages in an activity regulated by the city on or after July 1 in any year, the regulatory fee for the remaining portion of the year shall be fifty (50) percent of the regulatory fee for the entire year. 
(c)  Every business, individual and location subject to payment of a regulatory fee levied by this division shall display a current regulatory fee certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the regulatory fee certificate or an unaltered duplicate of such certificate shall be shown to any police officer or city clerk upon request. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Editor's note— Appendix A referred to above has not been included herein but can be found on file for inspection in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 15-28. - Occupation tax levied; limitations. 
(a)  An occupation tax based upon number of employees in the State of Georgia is levied upon businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices within the corporated limits of the city and, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, upon out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the city but with employees or agents engaging in substantial efforts to solicit business or serve customers or clients in the State of Georgia in accordance with the following schedule: 

 
(b)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one (1) occupation tax for each location of a business or practitioner. 
(c)  A business or practitioner which is subject to an occupation tax by another local government and claiming an exemption from or limitation to the occupation tax imposed by this division shall submit documentation as to current payment of the occupation tax to the other local government and the basis of such tax. 
(1)  If a business or practitioner with no location or office in Georgia provides to the city proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state which purports to tax the business' or practioner's sales or services in this state, then the business or practitioner shall be exempt from this occupation tax. 
(2)  A business or practitioner with no location or office in Georgia shall only be required to pay occupation tax to the local government in Georgia where the largest dollar volume of business is done or service is performed by such business or practitioner. This limitation shall only apply when the business or practitioner has provided to the city satisfactory proof of as to the applicability of this subsection. 
(3)  A business or practitioner which has locations in Georgia subject to occupation tax by more than one (1) local government in Georgia shall only be subject to occupation tax by the City of Nashville for the number of employees who are employed within the corporate limits of the city. This limitation shall only apply when the business or practitioner has provided to the city satisfactory proof of current payment of the occupation tax of the other local government(s). 
(4)  If an employee works for the same business or practitioner in more than one (1) municipal corporation or county and the business or practitioner submits proof of this, the employee shall be counted as an employee in the city only if the city is the jurisdiction where such employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year. 
(d)  If a business or practitioner commences business in the city on or after July 1 in any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be fifty (50) percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. The administrative fee shall not be reduced. 
(e)  If a business or practitioner does not know how many employees which are the basis of this occupation tax will be employed by the business or practitioner during the current calendar year, then the business or practitioner shall file a return estimating the number of employees which are the basis of this occupation tax. If such estimate is not accurate, then no later then December 31 the business or practitioner shall file an amended return indicating the actual number of employees during the previous calendar year. Any overpayment of the occupation tax may be credited to the business or practitioner's account for future tax liability, offset against other amounts due and owing to the city for any reason or paid to the business or practitioner at the discretion of the city clerk. 
(f)  Real estate brokers shall be subject to occupation tax pursuant to this division only if they maintain a principal or branch office in the city. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1; Ord. of 8-22-05) 
Sec. 15-29. - Occupation tax certificate. 
Every business, practitioner and location subject to payment of the occupation tax levied by this division shall display a current occupation tax certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the occupation tax certificate shall be shown to any police officer upon request. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-30. - Practitioners of professions and occupations. 
Practitioners of professions and occupations as defined in this division shall pay the occupation tax as set forth in section 15-28 above or shall pay an occupation tax of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) per practitioner. On the tax return for 1995 or such later time as the practitioner first commences business in the city, the practitioner shall elect a method of taxation. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by a written request filed by the practitioner on or before February 1 of the year in which the election is to be changed. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1; Ord. of 8-22-05) 
Sec. 15-31. - Exemptions. 
(a)  No occupation tax shall be levied on the following: 
(1)  Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, or instrumentality of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state; 
(2)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission; 
(3)  Those electrical service businesses organized under Chapter 3 of Title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia; 
(4)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agribusiness; 
(5)  Nonprofit, agricultural product cooperative marketing associations pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; 
(6)  Motor common carries pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; 
(7)  Persons purchasing guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal or hulls in carload lots for distribution among the purchasers for use and not sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; 
(8)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356 for persons selling or introducing into the city agricultural products or livestock, including animal products, raised in this state when the sale and introduction are made by the producer of the product and the sale is made within ninety (90) days of the introduction of the product into the city; 
(9)  Depository institutions pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; or 
(10)  Any business where the levy of such occupation tax is prohibited by the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States. 
(b)  The exemptions and limitations contained in this division shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect in any way any franchise fees, business taxes or other fees or taxes otherwise allowed by law. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-32. - Evidence of state registration when required. 
Each person who is licensed under title 43 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated by the examining boards of the secretary of state's office shall provide evidence of proper and current state license before the city occupation tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate may be issued. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-33. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
(a)  Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of an occupation tax certificate or a regulatory fee certificate, show evidence of such qualification. 
(b)  Any business required to submit an annual application for continuance of the business shall do so before the registration is issued. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-34. - Filing returns; other information required or requested. 
(a)  On or before December 31 of each year, an individual, business or practitioner subject to this occupation tax ordinance shall file with the city clerk on a form approved by and available from the city a signed return attesting to the number of employees of such business or practitioner during the calendar year. 
(b)  Individuals, businesses and practitioners doing business in the city shall submit to the city clerk or make available within thirty (30) days such information as may be required or requested by the city to determine the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or regulatory fee or to facilitate levying or collection of the occupation tax and/or regulatory fee(s). 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-35. - Confidentiality. 
Information provided by a business or practitioner to the city for the purpose of determining the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or levying or collecting the occupation tax is confidential and exempt from disclosure under article 4 of chapter 18 of title 50 of the Official Code of Georgia. Such information may be provided to the governing authority of another local government for occupation tax purposes or pursuant to court order of for the purpose of collecting occupation tax or prosecution for failure or refusal to pay occupation tax. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-36. - Date due; penalty. 
(a)  Any occupation tax or regulatory fee due pursuant to this division shall be due and payable annually on January 1. In the event that any person commences business or initially engages in a regulated activity in the city after January 1 in any year, the tax and/or fee shall be due and payable on the date of the commencement of the business or regulated activity. 
(b)  Any individual, business or practitioner subject to any occupation tax or regulatory fee imposed by this division which is unpaid for ninety (90) days after the date on which payment was due shall be subject to a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax or fee due. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-37. - Enforcement; violations. 
(a)  It is the duty of the city clerk to administer and enforce the provisions of this division, to perform all functions necessary to administer and enforce this ordinance and to summon violators of this division to appear before the municipal court. The city clerk may issue executions against individuals, businesses and practitioner for taxes and fees which are due and owing. 
(b)  The city clerk shall issue executions against individuals, businesses and practitioners for taxes and fees which are due and owning. Such executions shall bear interest at the rate authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40 or, if such statute should be repealed, one (1) percent per month. The lien shall cover the property of the individual, business or practitioner liable for payment of the delinquent occupation tax or regulatory fee and become fixed as of the date and time the occupation tax or regulatory fee became delinquent. The execution shall be levied by city clerk of the city upon property of the delinquent tax or fee payer located in the city and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, including penalty, interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be as provided by the Code and Charter of the city and the laws of Georgia. The defendants at execution shall have the rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality of the tax or otherwise as provided by the Charter of the city and the laws of Georgia in regard to tax executions. 
(c)  When a nulla bona entry has been entered upon an execution, the person against whom the entry is made shall not be allowed to, entitled to have or collect any fees or charged whatever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the nulla bona entry has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due to such person as if such person had never defaulted in the payment of the tax. 
(d)  Individuals, businesses and practitioners who fail or refuse to pay any occupation tax or regulatory fee charged pursuant to this division shall be subject to a fine and penalties. 
(e)  Individuals, businesses and practitioners who fail or refuse to make a timely or truthful tax return or make available truthful and accurate information the city requests or requires for determining applicability or amount of occupation tax or regulatory fee, or for levying or collecting such occupation tax or regulatory fee shall be subject to suspension of the right to conduct business. 
(f)  All persons subject to the occupation tax or regulatory fee imposed by this division shall be required to file for and pay such tax or fee. For failure to do so, any officers or agents soliciting for or obtaining such person or business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons, businesses or practitioners who fail to obtain, make a return for, or pay the applicable occupation tax or regulatory fee. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-38. - Public hearing. 
After January 1, 1996, the city shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the occupation tax rate specified in section 15-28. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-39. - Prior ordinance. 
To the extent that any occupation taxes or regulatory fees are owed pursuant to an ordinance passed prior to this one, such amount remain due and owing and the provisions of that prior ordinance will remain in effect with respect to such unpaid occupation taxes or regulatory fees until such time as they are paid in full. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
Sec. 15-40. - Severability. 
In the event any portion of this division shall be declared or adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, it is the intention of the city council of the City of Nashville that such adjudication shall in no manner affect the other sections, sentences, clauses or phrases of this division which shall remain in full force and effect as if the invalid or unconstitutional section, sentence, clause or phrase were not originally part of the division. 
(Ord. of 12-27-94, § 1) 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-41. - Nursery schools. 
Whenever more than six (6) children are kept as a home occupation, the location shall be deemed a nursery school for the purposes of city ordinances, and a license for such occupation shall be required. 
(Mo. of 1-28-74) 
Editor's note— The amount of the license tax is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
State Law reference— Immunization of children attending day-care centers, Ga. Code Ann., § 99-223. 
Sec. 15-42. - Drive-in movies. 
No open-air theater shall be permitted in the city unless it is equipped with individual speakers set up at each parking space, and the volume then toned down to such a degree that it will not disturb the citizens living in that immediate vicinity. The license for this type theater is to be the same as that charged for a theater in a building. 
(Code 1967, § 14-23) 
Editor's note— The license tax schedule is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 15-43. - Auctions in public, open places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell at public auction or outcry any kind of new or secondhand cloth, clothing, hats, shoes, merchandise, notions, wares or anything else of value on the streets, lanes, alleys or vacant lots of the city. 
(b)  All auctioneers or other persons selling at public outcry or auctioning anything by any method known shall conduct said business in an enclosed space other than a warehouse, in the city and shall pay to the city a license tax fixed by the council and the license shall be procured and tacked over the door where such business is carried on each morning before said business is begun for the day. 
(Code 1967, § 14-29) 
Editor's note— The amount of the license tax is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
State Law reference— Auctioneers and apprentice auctioneers, Ga. Code Ann., § 84-301a et seq., jewelry auctions, § 84-1701 et seq. 
Sec. 15-44. - Sunday closing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, or the agent, servant or employee of any person, to keep open, operate or participate in keeping open or operating any place or premises, whether open or enclosed, for the purpose of selling, bartering, exchanging or demonstrating, exhibiting or negotiating for sale, barter or exchange, within the corporate limits of the city, on the first day of the week, commonly called Sunday, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  The following trades, businesses and enterprises are exempted from the provisions of this section, subject to the conditions herein provided: 
(1)  Drugstores wherein doctors' prescriptions are filled, or wherein medical supplies are sold; 
(2)  Restaurants, cafes, lunchrooms, coffee shops, dining rooms and similar places wherein food is prepared and served for human consumption; 
(3)  Ice cream parlors; 
(4)  Automobile filling stations and garages; 
(5)  Motion picture theaters; 
(6)  Landscape nurseries; 
(7)  Neighborhood food stores, curb stores, minute markets and similar establishments; 
(8)  Sale of newspapers, magazines and books; 
(9)  Self-service laundry and dry cleaning establishments. 
(c)  The exemptions hereinabove provided shall apply only to those establishments which employ not more than three (3) full- or part-time personnel working at any one time on Sunday, including the owner and operator of such establishment. 
(d)  The following trades, businesses and enterprises are hereby exempted from the operation of this section: 
(1)  Hospitals; 
(2)  Medical and dental clinics; 
(3)  Funeral homes; 
(4)  Hotels, motels and places of lodging. 
(Code 1967, § 14-21) 
Cross reference— Sales of alcoholic beverages prohibited on Sundays, § 3-7. 
State Law reference— Violating the Sabbath day, Ga. Code Ann., § 26-9908; Sunday operation of businesses, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 106-801 et seq., 106-9912. 
Secs. 15-45—15-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BEAUTY AND BARBERSHOPS 

Sec. 15-56. - Scope of division. 
This division shall apply to any person within the city operating a barbershop, beauty parlor or beauty salon or as a hairdresser, or operating the same in a private dwelling. 
(Code 1967, § 14-54) 
State Law reference— Barbers, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 84-4; cosmetologists, Ch. 84-44. 
Sec. 15-57. - City license required. 
The owners and operators of a barbershop, beauty shop or beauty salon, and hairdressers, shall secure a special city license annually, on the first day of January, from the city clerk, to operate a barbershop, beauty shop or beauty salon or as a hairdresser within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 14-55) 
Sec. 15-58. - State certificate or license prerequisite to issuance of license; freedom from contagious disease. 
The owners and operators, at the time of application for a city license, shall furnish the city clerk a statement in writing that all barbers, beauticians and hairdressers, practicing in the shop for which the license is to be used, shall have a state license or certificate of registration to practice the occupation of a barber, beautician or hairdresser and that all barbers, hairdressers and beauticians are at the time of application free from contagious and infectious diseases. 
(Code 1967, § 14-56) 
Secs. 15-59—15-69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS 

Sec. 15-70. - Definitions. 
Taking orders for anything whatsoever, except religious items, for future delivery or shipment, or seeking donations or information, shall be deemed canvassing or soliciting. If deliveries are made the license for salesmen will apply as covered in the license tax schedule on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 14-35) 
State Law reference— Peddlers regulated, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 84-20. 
Sec. 15-71. - Registration generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a canvasser or solicitor, calling at or telephoning to residences, offices or businesses without the previous consent of the occupant, for the purpose of soliciting orders, sales, subscriptions or business of any kind, or seeking for information or donations, without first having registered at the city hall with the city clerk or his designated authority. Each registrant shall be required to fill out a registration form giving complete identification, signature, name of employer, product sold, manufacturer of products or name of organization he is representing and proposed method of operation in the city, and such other identification or information as may be requested. 
(Code 1967, § 14-37) 
Sec. 15-72. - Registration fee. 
Each registrant shall pay to the city clerk or his designated representative a registration fee fixed by the council. 
(Code 1967, § 14-38) 
Editor's note— The amount of the registration fee is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 15-73. - Identification card; issuance; use. 
Each applicant who shows evidence of good character and who pays the registration fee provided shall be furnished an identification card indicating he has registered and showing the expiration date. Each person shall at all times while in the city have upon his person the registration card and shall exhibit same whenever requested to do so by any municipal authority or by any person being solicited. Possession of this registration card shall not in any way represent an endorsement or approval of any products or project by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 14-39) 
Sec. 15-74. - Revocation of card, permit. 
Any identification card or permit may be revoked by the city clerk or the chief of police or their designated representative because of any violation by the registrant (or any one (1) of a group of registrants) of this division, or of any ordinance of the city, or of any state or federal law, or whenever the registrant shall cease to possess the qualifications and good character required in this division for the original registration. 
(Code 1967, § 14-40) 
Sec. 15-75. - Hours of soliciting. 
There shall be no soliciting before 8:00 a.m. and after 5:00 p.m. 
(Code 1967, § 14-41) 
Sec. 15-76. - Applicability of provisions. 
Nothing in this division shall apply to officers or employees of the city, county, state or federal governments or the school system or any subdivision thereof, when an official business; nor shall it apply to any person holding a regular business license in the city; nor to any local nonprofit organization such as boy scouts, civic clubs, school organizations and the like, when the membership of said club or organization does the soliciting itself; but it shall apply when the soliciting is done by a paid solicitor or by a solicitor on contract with an organization with only a percentage or portion of any sales or collections to go to the benefit of said nonprofit club or organization. 
(Code 1967, § 14-36) 
Secs. 15-77—15-87. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CIRCUSES, CARNIVALS, THEATRICAL TROUPES 

Sec. 15-88. - Approval of council. 
(a)  Any person desiring to have a permit for a circus, carnival or theatrical performance shall apply in writing to the council for such permit. 
(b)  Such permit shall be issued upon the approval of a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the council. 
(Code 1967, § 14-63) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate theatrical performances, § 2-9(uu). 
Sec. 15-89. - Time of carnivals. 
(a)  All carnivals are hereby prohibited from showing in the city during the months of July, August, September and October, except at fairs that are sponsored by local or civic organizations, and then only by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the mayor and council. 
(b)  This section shall apply to carnivals and shows that have merry-go-rounds, ferris wheels, rides, concessions, etc. 
(Code 1967, § 14-62) 
Secs. 15-90—15-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FIREARM AND WEAPON SALES 

Sec. 15-101. - Compliance by seller. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell to any purchaser any pistol, dirk or switch-blade knife without complying with sections 15-102 and 15-103. 
(Ord. No. 9-76, § I, 6-28-76) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate or prohibit the sale of firearms, § 2-9(vv). 
Sec. 15-102. - Statement required from purchaser. 
The merchant or dealer from whom a prospective buyer shall seek to purchase a pistol, dirk or switch-blade knife shall, before making a sale to such prospective purchaser, obtain from such prospective purchaser his name, place of residence, age, occupation and a statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime of violence or charged with the violation of criminal law in this or any other state. 
(Ord. No. 9-76, § I, 6-28-76) 
Sec. 15-103. - Information furnished to police department. 
It shall be the duty of the merchant or dealer promptly to deliver to the police department a duplicate of the questions propounded to the purchaser of a pistol, dirk or switch-blade knife, together with a duplicate of the answers made by him, all as recorded in the printed form provided therefor. Where such a sale is made, a description of the item sold, including serial number, if any, shall be entered on said form by said seller in the place provided. 
(Ord. No. 9-76, § I, 6-28-76) 
Cross reference— Police department, Ch. 23. 
Secs. 15-104—15-114. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - HOTEL-MOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted June 8, 2009, enacted new provisions to be designated §§ 15-220—15-231. Inasmuch as there already exists sections with these designations, the new provisions have been redesignated as §§ 15-115—15-126. Original section numbering has been maintained in the history notes following each section. 

Sec. 15-115. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Due date means the twentieth day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
Folio means primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the operator and the occupant and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date of occupancy, and the amount of rent charged for each date, together with the amounts of applicable excise tax, and the method of payment. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one (1) or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. 
Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any guestroom or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guestroom in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use, or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in the city, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guestroom in a hotel for more than ten (10) continuous days next preceding such date. No person shall become a permanent resident until such person shall have occupied a guestroom in a hotel for more than ten (10) continuous days. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number; excepting the United States, the state, and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Tax means the tax on occupants imposed by this article as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
(Ord. of 6-8-09, § 15-220) 
Sec. 15-116. - Tax rate. 
There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guestroom in a hotel in the city a tax at the rate of five (5) percent of the amount of rent unless an exemption is provided under section 15-118. 
(Ord. of 6-8-09, § 15-221) 
State Law reference— Hotel-motel tax authorized, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51. 
Sec. 15-117. - Collection of tax by operator. 
Every operator renting guestrooms in this city shall collect a tax of five (5) percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exemption is provided under section 15-118. The operator shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other taxes applicable. This tax shall be due from the occupant and shall be collected by the operator at the same time that the rent is collected. 
(Ord. of 6-8-09, § 15-222) 
Sec. 15-118. - Exemptions. 
The tax levied by this article shall be subject to the exemptions provided by law. 
(Ord. of 6-8-09, § 15-223) 
State Law reference— Exemptions generally, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-51 et seq. 
Sec. 15-119. - Registration of operator; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register with the finance director on a form provided by said official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than thirty (30) days after the date that the ordinance from which this article is derived becomes effective. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place of business, and other information that would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by the finance director. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person. In case of ownership by an association or partnership, the registration shall be signed by a member or partner. In case of ownership by a corporation, the registration shall be signed by an officer. The finance director shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant.
