ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Loitering. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found idling, standing, loitering or loafing within the city as follows: 
(1)  In, on or upon the streets, sidewalks or alleys, in such a manner as to impede vehicular or pedestrian traffic or to be detrimental to the safety, health or general welfare of the city or citizens thereof. 
(2)  In or upon poolrooms, restaurants, whiskey stores or beer halls, dance halls or any legal or illegal place of business. 
(Code 1967, § 16-3) 
State Law reference— Unruly child defined, Ga. Code Ann., § 24A-401; loitering on school premises, Ga. Code Ann., § 32-9925; loitering on psychiatric hospital grounds, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 35-9902, 88-2716; loitering near convicts, Ga. Code Ann., § 77-328. 
Sec. 18-2. - Handbills; distribution. 
Before distributing handbills, application shall be made to the city council for a permit which shall be issued by the city clerk upon the approval of the application by the council. 
(Code 1967, § 16-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Curfew for minors. 
It is hereby declared to be a violation of this Code for the parent or guardian of any minor to permit him to be on the streets of the city after 12:00 midnight, unattended or unaccompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(Code 1967, § 16-1) 
Cross reference— Minors and premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, § 3-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Juvenile court jurisdiction over juveniles, Ga. Code Ann., § 24A-301. 
Sec. 18-4. - Evangelistic tent revivals. 
No evangelistic tent revival shall be held in any residential district as designated by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
Sec. 18-5. - Erection of political signs prohibited; penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to erect, locate or maintain any political sign on any property or right-of-way of the city. 
(b)  Any person who fails to comply with this section shall be deemed guilty of a municipal offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as for other violations of the municipal code. 
(Ord. No. 80-2, §§ 1, 2, 9-22-80) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-2, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 22, 1980, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified herein as § 18-5 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 18-6. - Cash bonds for offenses. 
The following cash bonds shall be paid for offenses committed in the city: 
BONDS 

 
TRAFFIC 

 
CITY ORDINANCES 

 
(Ord. of 6-8-87; Ord. of 5-11-99, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-01, § I) 
Sec. 18-7. - Yard/garage sale regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
Yard/garage sales shall mean and include all general sales, open to the public, conducted from or on any premises in any residential or nonresidential zone, as defined by the zoning ordinance, for the purpose of disposing of personal property including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," "flea market," or "rummage" sale. This definition does not include the operation of such businesses carried on in a nonresidential zone where the person conducting the sale does on a regular day-to-day basis and such operation is otherwise properly licensed and conducted in accordance with other applicable ordinances. 
Personal property shall mean property, which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of his or her residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. It does not include merchandise, which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
(b)  Property permitted to be sold. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, under authority granted by this section, property other than personal property. 
(c)  Permit required. No yard/garage sale shall be conducted unless and until the individuals, desiring to conduct such sale obtains a permit therefore from the building/codes enforcement department. Members of more than one (1) residence may join in obtaining a permit for yard/garage sale to be conducted at the residence of one (1) of them. Permits may be obtained for any nonresidential location. 
(d)  Permit procedure. 
(1)  Application. The applicant or applicants for a yard/garage sale permit shall file a written application with the building/codes enforcement department at least three (3) days in advance of the proposed sale setting forth the following information: 
a.  Full name and address of applicant or applicants. 
b.  The location at which the proposed yard/garage sale is to be held. 
c.  The date or dates upon which the sale will be held. 
d.  The date or dates of any other yard/garage sales by the same applicant or applicants within the current calendar year. 
e.  A statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his own personal property and was neither acquired nor consigned for the purpose of resale. 
f.  A statement that the applicant will fully comply with this and all other applicable ordinances and laws. 
(2)  Permit fee. An administrative processing fee of five dollars ($5.00) for the issuance of such permit shall accompany the application. 
(3)  Issuance of permit. Upon the applicant complying with the terms of this section, the building/codes enforcement department shall issue a permit. 
(e)  Permit conditions. The permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such yard/garage sale. No more than two (2) such permits may be issued to one (1) residential location, residence and/or family household during any calendar year. If members of more than one (1) residence join in requesting a permit, then such permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all such residences. No more than two (2) permits may be issued for any nonresidential location during any calendar year. 
(f)  Hours of operation. Sales shall be limited in time to no more than 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on two (2) consecutive days. 
(g)  Exceptions. 
(1)  If sale not held because of inclement weather. If a yard/garage sale is not held on the dates for which the permit is issued or is terminated during the first day of the sale because of inclement weather conditions, and an affidavit by the permit holder to this effect is submitted, the building/code enforcement offices shall issue another permit to the applicant for a yard/garage sale to be conducted at the same location within thirty (30) days from the date when the first sale was to be held. No additional permit fee is required. 
(2)  Third sale permitted. A third yard/garage sale shall be permitted in a calendar year if satisfactory proof on a bona fide change in ownership of the real property is first presented to the building/codes enforcement department. 
(h)  Display of sale property. Personal property offered for sale may be displayed within the residence, in a garage, carport, and/or in a front, side or rear yard, but only in such areas. No personal property offered for sale at a yard/garage sale shall be displayed in any public right-of-way. A vehicle offered for sale may be displayed on a permanently constructed driveway within such front or side yard. 
(i)  Display of permit. Any permit in possession of the holder or holders of a yard/garage sale shall be posted on the premises in a conspicuous place so as to be seen by the public or any city official. 
(j)  Advertising: signs permitted. Only the following specified signs may be displayed in relation to a pending yard/garage sale: 
(1)  Two (2) signs permitted. Two (2) signs of not more than four (4) square feet shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence or nonresidential site where the yard/garage sale is being conducted. 
(2)  Directional signs. Two (2) signs of not more than two (2) square feet each are permitted, provided that the premises on which the yard/garage sale is conducted is not on a major thoroughfare, and written permission to erect signs is received from the property owners on whose property such signs are to be placed. 
(3)  Time limitations. No sign or other form of advertisement shall be exhibited for more than two (2) days prior to the day such sale is to commence. 
(4)  Removal of signs. Signs must be removed at the close of the yard/garage sale activities. 
(k)  Persons exempted from section. The provisions of this section shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order of process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Any sale conducted by any merchant or mercantile or other business establishment on a regular, day-to-day basis from or at the place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by applicable zoning regulations of the city, or under the protection of the nonconforming use section thereof, or any other sale conducted by a manufacturer, dealer or vendor in which sale would be conducted from properly zoned premises, and not otherwise prohibited by other ordinances. 
(4)  Any sale conducted by a nonprofit charitable organization or religious organization who conducts such sale upon real property owned by such nonprofit charitable organization or religious organization. 
(l)  Violations and penalty. Any person found guilty of violating the terms of this section shall be subject to a penalty of up to fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense, up to two (2) offenses. Each subsequent offense shall be subject to a penalty of two hundred-fifty dollars ($250.00) each. 
(Ord. of 11-27-06) 
Sec. 18-8. - Keeping and maintenance of a disorderly house prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, group of persons or organization to have, keep, operate or allow to be operated or maintained a common, ill-governed and disorderly premises, which serves to foster or encourage gambling, drinking, loud, lewd or boisterous behavior or other such misbehavior or other misconduct so as to create, cause or allow to continue the common disturbance of the neighborhood or which misbehavior or misconduct serves to disturb or distress the lives of orderly and law abiding citizens residing, abiding or passing adjacent to such premises. 
(Ord. of 10-9-06) 
Secs. 18-9—18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to prevent offenses against the public peace, § 2-9(tt). 
Cross reference— Vicious animals generally, § 4-2; nuisance dogs, § 4-27; vicious dogs, § 4-28. 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct and related offenses, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 26-26; crimes involving dangerous instrumentalities and practices, Ch. 26-29. 

Sec. 18-21. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of committing within the corporate limits of the city any act or acts of commission or omission generally known as disorderly conduct, as the term is generally understood and defined by the court of the state. 
(b)  Specific acts. In addition to the general broad language of subsection (a), and without restricting the language of said subsection, it is intended by this section to prohibit the commission of, and to provide punishment for, the following specific acts: 
(1)  Disturbing the peace. 
(2)  Resisting arrest, and resisting any officer of the city in the lawful performance of his duties. 
(3)  Assembling for purposes of gambling. 
(4)  Committing a breach of the peace. 
(5)  Violent or boisterous conduct calculated to disturb the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(6)  Appearing in an intoxicated condition outside of the offender's own home. 
(7)  Making unusual or unnecessary noises calculated to disturb the peace and good order. 
(8)  Using profane or obscene language toward others in such manner as to be offensive. 
(9)  Committing riotous acts. 
(10)  Maliciously interfering with pedestrians or with traffic. 
(11)  Indecent acts in the presence of others. 
It shall also be deemed to be disorderly conduct for any person to urinate, expose his or her genitals, quarrel, fight, solicit men or women for immoral purposes, use profane or vulgar language, act in boisterous, noisy and rough manner, commit any mischief or otherwise behave in a disorderly manner in or on any of the public streets, lanes or alleys in the city or in any public place or in any other place within the corporate limits of the city or to aid, assist, encourage or promote the same to be done by any other person. 
(Code 1967, § 16-24) 
Sec. 18-22. - Discharging firearms; fireworks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any gun, pistol, revolver, fire cracker, Roman candle, sky rocket, torpedo, or other firework within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-26) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate or prohibit the use of firearms, § 2-9(vv). 
State Law reference— Fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 92A-8; discharging firearms on or near public highways, O.C.G.A. § 26-2909. 
Sec. 18-23. - Throwing of missiles. 
No person shall throw any stone, rock or other missile upon or at any vehicle, building, tree or other public or private property, or upon or at any person in any public or private way or place. 
Secs. 18-24—18-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES RELATIVE TO PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, O.C.G.A. ch. 26-15; burglary and related offenses, ch. 26-16; theft, ch. 26-18; robbery, ch. 26-19 

Sec. 18-40. - Placing broken glass on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break glass upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys or lanes of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-67) 
Sec. 18-41. - Spitting on sidewalk, other places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate sputum (spit) upon the sidewalks of the city, or upon the floors or walls of the city hall or courthouse. 
(Code 1967, § 16-70) 
Sec. 18-42. - Littering. 
No person shall place any solid waste in the street, public place, roadway or private premises except it be in proper containers for collection or under the express prior written approval of the administrative officer of the sanitation department. No person shall place any solid waste in any stream, lake or other body of water. 
(Code 1967, §§ 11-3, 16-66; Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8-5) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 29-2612; ch. 85-16C. 
Sec. 18-43. - Petit theft. 
Any person who shall take, conceal, misappropriate, damage or otherwise render useless, any property (with a value not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00)) belonging to another by any means or method, with the intent to deprive or defraud the true owner of said property, or the use or benefit thereof, or to misappropriate the same to the use of the taker, or any other person, shall be deemed guilty of petit theft. 
(Ord. of 11-10-08) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Nov. 10, 2008 amended § 18-43 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 18-43 pertained to shoplifting and derived from the 1967 Code. 
Sec. 18-44. - Defacing property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to mark obscene signs or language, cut or otherwise deface any fence, house, building, automobile, truck or any other vehicle or tree or shrubbery within the city limits. 
Code 1967, § 16-69) 
Sec. 18-45. - Damaging city property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, destroy or mutilate any water or gas meters, jail mattress, plumbing or any other city property, real or personal. 
(Code 1967, § 16-68) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 26-2613. 
Sec. 18-46. - Obstructing officials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, resist or oppose the mayor, councilmen, policemen, chief of police, chief of the fire department, firemen, utilities superintendent or other officers of the city in the performance of any duty required of such officers by the Charter, or this Code, or any laws or orders of the city authorizing such duty. 
(Code 1967, § 16-52) 
State Law reference— Abuse of governmental office, O.C.G.A. Ch. 26-23; obstruction of law enforcement, Ch. 26-25; impersonating public officer, § 26-2405. 
Sec. 18-47. - Trees and shrubs. 
(a)  Planting and removal. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, remove, injure or cut any tree, bush or shrub in or from any public street, parkway or other public place without first obtaining a permit therefore from the city clerk. 
(b)  Advertisements. It shall be unlawful for any person to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any public place. 
(c)  Dangerous trees. Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place in the city in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. 
Any tree or limb of a tree which is likely to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such trees grows or stands. 
The director of public works may cause to be trimmed or removed any and all such trees or shrubs so that the obstruction or danger to traffic or passage shall be removed. 
(d)  Poles and wires. Any person who maintains poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places of the city shall keep such wires and poles free and away from any nearby trees or shrubs in such places, and keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the director of public works, so that no injury shall befall either the poles and wires or the shrubs and trees by their contact. 
Sec. 18-48. - Tree protection. 
(1)  Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Building: Any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls that encloses a space and is intended for the shelter, housing or enclosure of any individual, animal, process, equipment, goods or materials of any kind or nature or as further defined in the city's building codes. 
Building inspector: The city official charged with enforcing the city's building codes and zoning ordinance. 
Caliper: Tree trunk diameter measured at a point six (6) inches above ground level. 
City: The City of Nashville, Georgia. 
City arborist: The person charged by the mayor and council of the City of Nashville with the duty of administering this section. 
Critical root zone: The land area circular in shape and centered on the trunk of a tree, the radius of which circle is defined by the farthest canopy dripline. 
DBH: A tree's diameter at breast height (four and one-half (4.5) feet above ground level). If a tree splits into multiple trunks below four and one-half (4.5) feet, then each trunk is measured and counted as a separate tree. 
Development area: Under an approved tree protection plan, the portion of a tract exempted from the tree protection zone; it consists of: 
(a)  The area to be occupied by buildings; 
(b)  The area to be occupied by unenclosed accessory uses; and 
(c)  The area necessary to meet maximum parking requirements. 
Dripline or canopy dripline: A vertical line extending from the outer surface of a tree's branch tips down to the ground. 
Existing density factor: See subsection (9)(b)1. 
Height: Height of mature specimens under favorable growing conditions. If expressed as a range, the midpoint of the range is the "average height" and the bottom of the range is the "minimum height." 
Large tree: A tree with a height at maturity of forty (40) feet or more. 
Replacement density factor: See subsection (9)(b)2. 
Shade tree: A broad-leaf tree having an average height at maturity of at least twenty (20) feet and having a broad spread relative to its height (excluding trees with pyramidal, conical or columnar crowns) and a dense canopy, so as to provide shade to structures or parking areas in the summer months. 
Site density factor: (Total site area, in acres) times twenty-five (25). 
Small tree: A tree with a height at maturity of not more than forty (40) feet. 
Tree: Any self-supporting woody perennial plant, usually with one (1) main stem or trunk and many branches, which has a trunk diameter of two (2) inches or more measured at a point six (6) inches above ground level and which normally attains a height of at least ten (10) feet at maturity. 
Tree protection zone: The crown width of a tree, constituting the area surrounding a preserved or planted tree that is essential to that tree's health and survival, and is protected within the guidelines of this section. 
(2)  The building inspector shall periodically, but not less often than once every ten (10) years, prepare a complete inventory of all trees growing on city property and having a caliper of at least two (2) inches or a DBH of at least two (2) inches. 
(3)  Each year the city, through the building inspector, shall organize and conduct a tree planting program, designed at least to replace trees that have been cut from city property during the previous year. Replacement trees shall have the following qualities: Spacing and the potential size of species chosen shall be compatible with spatial limitations of the site on which they are to be planted; the species must be ecologically compatible with the specifically intended growing site; replacement trees must have the potential for size and quality comparable to the removed trees; and preference shall be given to specimens of no more than three (3) inches DBH. The number (expressed in units having a minimum caliper of two (2) inches) of replacement trees to be planted shall be determined with reference to the DBH of each tree that was cut during the previous year, according to the following table: 

 
(4)  (a)  The cutting or removal on city property of any tree having a DBH of two (2) inches or greater without the approval of the tree board shall be unlawful. Any person violating this section or authorizing another to violate this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The removal from private property of any tree having a DBH of four (4) inches or greater without a permit or except in connection with an approved tree protection plan shall be unlawful. Any person violating this section or authorizing another to violate this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  A person whose applications for a tree removal permit has been denied shall have the right to file a written appeal of such denial to the tree board, within thirty (30) days of the date of such denial. 
(5)  (a)  There is hereby established a tree board for the City of Nashville (hereinafter referred to as the "board"). 
(b)  The purpose of the board shall be to perform the duties specified in this section and to perform such other duties as shall be provided from time to time by ordinance. 
(c)  The board shall consist of six (6) members appointed and removable by majority vote of the mayor and council. Members of the board shall be residents of the city. 
(d)  The term of office of each member of the board shall be on a calendar year basis for a two-year period; provided that in the appointment of the first board three (3) members shall be appointed for an initial one-year term and three (3) members shall be appointed for an initial two-year term. Any member shall be subject to removal either with or without cause by the mayor and council at any time. 
(e)  Members of the board shall receive no compensation for their services except that they may be reimbursed for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred by them in direct connection with the performance of their duties, subject to the approval of such reimbursements by the mayor and council and in accordance with such documentation and other requirements as may be imposed by the mayor and council. 
(f)  Meetings of the board shall be held quarterly or more often as may be necessary for the board to perform its duties and responsibilities. The board shall have the power to adopt such rules, policies, procedures and regulations for the transacting of its business and for the determination of issues and matters coming before the board as it deems necessary or appropriate. The board shall elect from among its members a chairman and a vice chairman. The city clerk shall serve as secretary of the board. The city attorney shall be the legal advisor and legal representative of the board and shall render such legal assistance to the board as shall be necessary. 
(g)  Should any member of the board have any personal or financial interest or relationship with respect to any person, matter or issue pending before the board, then such member shall be disqualified to participate in board deliberations in connection with such person, matter or issue. 
(h)  The board shall generally investigate and advise officials of the City of Nashville regarding the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal and disposition of trees growing on city property. The board shall develop lists of trees recommended for planting within the City of Nashville. The board shall, upon request by the mayor, investigate and advise city officials with respect to specific matters relating to trees within the city. The board shall hear and determine such issues and matters as may come before it, and exercise such powers, and perform such duties, as may be provided by this section or any other city ordinance. 
(i)  The city's annual budget shall include appropriations for the administration of this section, in such amounts as each year are determined to be appropriate. 
(6)  The city arborist with the advice of the tree board from time to time shall have the right and power to authorize the removal of a tree from city property only upon a showing that the tree has a life expectancy of less than fifteen (15) years, or that extensive decay within the trunk is present, or that the tree suffers from significant insect or pathological problems, or that the tree has suffered significant damage from lightning, wind or other causes, or that threatens to cause injury to the public or damage to existing structures, or that the tree interferes with the construction of a new structure or an addition to an existing structure, or that the tree interferes with the construction, protection, or maintenance of public utilities or streets. 
(7)  Nothing in this section shall restrict or limit the right of the city to prune any tree whether growing on public or private property that threatens the safety of persons or property on city property, or that interferes with public utilities or other public improvements or the safe or convenient utilization of public streets, or that is infected with any injurious fungus, insect, pest or disease. 
(8)  A proposal for development or improvement of any tract of land involving the expenditure of at least twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) shall include a tree protection plan, including trees to be planted in order to meet the minimum requirements of this section. The tree protection plan may be included in the soil erosion and sediment control plan. Such plan shall be submitted to and approved by the building inspector prior to any grading, bulldozing or other removal of the existing vegetation that may affect the health of existing tree coverage. The plan shall show the following: 
(a)  Names and addresses of owner(s) of record and the applicant. 
(b)  Boundary lines of the tract by lengths and bearings, streets adjoining the property, total area of the tract, north point, graphic scale and date. 
(c)  All trees ten (10) inches DBH or greater, including the crown width of each individual tree, which will remain on the site and be protected during construction; and trees less than ten (10) inches DBH which are submitted for credit against the number of replacement trees to be planted to achieve the required site density factor ("SDF"), and the common and botanical names and the size of each tree. In heavily wooded areas that will not be disturbed, the plan may show only the boundaries of each stand of trees and a list of the number, size and species of ten-inch DBH or larger trees in each stand. 
(d)  Locations of proposed buildings, structures and paved areas. 
(e)  Locations of all utility lines. Utility lines must be placed along corridors between critical root zones of trees which will remain on the site. 
(f)  Limits of land disturbance, clearing, grading, and trenching. 
(g)  Limits of tree protection zones, showing trees to be maintained and planted, specifying species and size. 
(h)  Grade changes or other work adjacent to a tree which would affect it adversely, with drawings or descriptions as to how the grade, drainage, and aeration will be maintained around the tree. 
(i)  Planting schedule. 
(9)  (a)  The minimum required quantity of trees on a site after development must produce a total SDF of twenty-five (25) units per acre. The SDF is determined as follows: 
SDF = (total site area, in acres) x 25 
(b)  The number of new trees to be planted on a site after development is determined as follows: 
1.  Using Table 1, calculate the existing density factor ("EDF") of trees ten (10) inches DBH or greater which will remain on the site and be protected during construction. Existing trees of at least two (2) inches DBH, but less than ten (10) inches DBH, which will remain on the site and be protected during construction, may be counted as one-half (0.5) unit each, provided such trees have grown in uncrowded conditions and have developed normal spread. Add together the individual units for each tree to get the EDF. 

 
2.  To calculate the replacement density factor ("RDF"), subtract the EDF from the SDF. 

 
(c)  Application of density factors to the plan: 
1.  No tree shall be planted closer to a building foundation or water, sewer, electrical or natural gas line, than as follows: 
(A)  Five (5) feet for a mature small tree. 
(B)  Ten (10) feet for a mature medium tree. 
(C)  Fifteen (15) feet for a mature large tree. 
2.  No tree shall be planted under overhead utility distribution lines if the average mature height of the tree is greater than the lowest overhead wire. 
3.  Landscape islands shall be provided within parking areas of six (6) or more spaces, but shall not be required within vehicle storage or display areas. 
(A)  The total areas of such islands shall compromise at least five (5) percent of the parking lot area in commercial and residential zoning districts or three (3) percent of the parking lot area in industrial zoning districts; plus one (1) percent of other vehicle use area on the property such as loading, storage or display areas. 
(B)  Each island shall contain a minimum of fifty (50) square feet. It shall be so shaped that a five-foot diameter circle will fit within the island. No portion of an island less than three (3) feet in width may be counted in the area. 
(C)  Landscape islands shall be located in such a manner as to divide and break up the expanse of paving. 
(D)  Vehicles may overhang a landscape island provided said island is at least three and one-half (3.5) feet in depth per abutting parking space, at least five (5) feet in depth overall (except in cases where one (1) or more large trees are present on the island in which case the island must be at least ten (10) feet in depth overall), and protected by wheel stops or curbing. Two (2) feet of said landscaped area may count as part of the required depth of each abutting parking space. 
(d)  At least one (1) shade tree shall be planted in each required landscape island, and at least one (1) tree shall be planted for every thirty (30) linear feet of length in the side and rear setback areas required by the city's zoning ordinance. 
(e)  Where trees must be added to achieve the SDF, such additions shall be made between the street and the front of the building until such additions together with the existing trees compromise one-half (½) of the SDF. 
(f)  Existing trees which are in excess of the minimum SDF requirement but are outside the development area shall not be removed unless adjacent development would cause irreparable damage to the critical root area. 
(10)  The criteria for replacement trees in sites under development shall be as follows: 
(a)  Spacing and the potential size of species chosen shall be compatible with spatial limitations of the site on which they are to be planted. 
(b)  The species must be ecologically compatible with the specifically intended growing site. 
(c)  Replacement trees must have the potential for size and quality comparable to the removed trees. 
(d)  Preference shall be given to specimens of no more than three (3) inches DBH. 
(e)  Where the proposed development area is so large that the minimum SDF cannot be achieved, the development area shall be reduced by removing parking spaces in excess of the minimum required, additional planting islands shall be placed within the development area, and/or the area to be occupied by buildings shall be reduced until the minimum SDF is achieved. 
(11)  Existing trees and replacement trees on a site under improvement or development shall be protected by tree protection devices and restrictions on activities and conditions within the tree protection zone. 
(a)  Each tree and groups of trees to be preserved shall be protected during site development or improvement by completely surrounding the critical root zone of each tree, using as active tree protection (required in areas in proximity to construction activity) chain link fencing, orange laminated plastic fencing, or wooden post and rail fencing, and in areas where the tree is in jeopardy of being damaged by equipment, two-inch x four-inch boards strapped around the tree trunk, and using as passive protection (in all areas other than in proximity to construction) heavy mil plastic flagging a minimum of four (4) inches wide with dark letters on a bright background reading "Tree Protection Zone - Do Not Enter" or equivalent signage on a continuous durable restraint. 
(b)  The tree protection plan shall indicate in each instance whether the protection is to be active or passive. 
(c)  No construction within a tree's dripline will be allowed, unless protective measures to ensure the survival of the tree or trees are detailed in the tree protection plan and approved by the building inspector. 
(d)  All tree protection devices shall be installed prior to any clearing, grubbing or grading, and must remain in functional condition throughout all phases of the development. Such devices must be inspected and approved by the building inspector before the issuance of a land disturbance permit. 
(e)  Felling trees into tree protection zones or disturbance of the critical root zone is not permitted. 
(f)  No erosion or sedimentation control measures may be installed in a manner so as to result in the accumulation of sediment within a tree protection zone. 
(g)  All boring under the tree protection zone shall be done at a depth of at least thirty-six (36) inches O.C. and must begin and end outside the tree protection plan. 
(h)  Trenching outside a tree protection zone shall follow the specifications: 
1.  Crushed or torn roots shall be cleaved back to good wood and a sharp clean cut shall be made to promote regrowth. 
2.  Work in the area and foot traffic shall be confined to the side of the trench away from the tree. 
3.  All exposed root ends shall be kept moist. 
(i)  All tree pruning shall be done according to the ANSI A300 - Standard Practices for Tree Care Operations - Trees, Shrubs, and Other Woody Plant Maintenance. 
1.  All pruning shall start beyond the branch bark ridge of the tree. 
2.  Pruning shall be done so as to remove branch weight as much as possible before the final cut to prevent tearing of bark and cambium. 
3.  In all pruning, the branch collar, part of the trunk, shall remain intact and uninjured. 
(j)  All tree care operations shall comply with ANSI 2133.1 - 1994 Safety Requirements for pruning, trimming, repairing, maintaining, and removing trees and cutting brush. 
(12)  Where replacement trees are required to be placed on private property under the provisions of this section, the property owner and his successors in title shall maintain such trees and replace such trees if they die or are irreparably damaged in perpetuity. 
(13)  Violation of any provision of this section, or the violation of any provision of an approved tree protection plan, shall be unlawful and shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(14)  A person whose tree protection plan has been rejected shall have the right to file a written appeal of such rejection to the tree board, within thirty (30) days of the date of such denial. 
(Ord. of 11-15-11) 
Secs. 18-49—18-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST DECENCY AND MORALS[4] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference— Sexual offenses, O.C.G.A. Ch. 26-20; distributing obscene materials, O.C.G.A. Ch. 26-21; gambling and related offenses, O.C.G.A. Ch. 26-27; state literature commission, O.C.G.A. Ch. 40-31; improper language on telephone, O.C.G.A. § 104-9901; offense relating to hotels, O.C.G.A. § 52-9907 

Sec. 18-64. - Assembly for purpose of gambling. 
It shall be unlawful for any persons to assemble in a poolroom, restaurant or upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, motels, hotels or any other place, house, room or place of business for the purpose of gaming, gambling or playing poker, dice or craps for anything of value within the city. Cards, dice, poker chips and numbers found on the person in the room or on the floor, table, bed, counter or shelf shall be prima facie evidence of assembling for the purpose of gambling. 
(Code 1967, § 16-39) 
State Law reference— Gambling and related offenses, O.C.G.A. Ch. 26-27. 
Sec. 18-65. - Obscene literature, pictures. 
It shall unlawful within the corporate limits of the city for any person to publish, circulate, give or sell, or cause to be published, circulated, given or sold, or have in his possession any book, writing, print, picture, newspaper, pamphlet or other work of an obscene, licentious, lewd or libelous nature, or to publicly exhibit any lewd, obscene or indecent picture. 
(Code 1967, § 16-41) 
State Law reference— Distributions of obscene materials to minors, O.C.G.A. § 26-9901a et seq. 
Sec. 18-66. - Indecent or immoral motion pictures and shows. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or agent in charge of any motion picture theater in the city to exhibit or allow to be exhibited in such theater any indecent, immoral or obscene motion pictures. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit for a monetary consideration, to sell an admission ticket or pass or to admit for a monetary consideration to premises whereon there is exhibited a motion picture, show or other presentation which, in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors. 
(Ord. of 4-9-73, § 1) 
State Law reference— Distribution of obscene materials to minors, O.C.G.A. § 26-9901a et seq. 
Chapter 19 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Operation of parks, playgrounds and recreational facilities, § 2-9(w). 
State Law reference— Parks, playgrounds and recreation centers, O.C.G.A. § 69-312; gifts for public parks or pleasure grounds, O.C.G.A. § 69-504. 

Sec. 19-1. - Dedication of parks. 
The parks of the city shall be: 
(1)  The Silas T. and Mackie Peeples Tygart Memorial Park; 
(2)  Beetree Park; 
(3)  Dr. Y. F. Carter Park; 
(4)  Northside Park; and 
(5)  Heritage Park 
and the lands on which these parks are located, or any buildings located on these lands, are hereby dedicated and set apart for use as parks, playgrounds, recreation centers and for any other recreational purposes for which they can be lawfully used. 
(Ord. No. 1076, 11-22-76) 
State Law reference— Georgia recreation commission, O.C.G.A. § 99-2301 et seq.; limitation of liability of persons making land and water areas available to public for recreational purposes, O.C.G.A. § 105-403 et seq. 
Sec. 19-2. - Hours of organized recreation. 
All city organized recreation shall be completed or stopped at 12:00 midnight. 
(Mo. of 9-8-75) 
Sec. 19-3. - Group activity. 
(a)  Whenever more than twenty-five (25) members of any group, association or organization desire to use any park facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties or theatrical or other entertainment performances, a representative of such group, association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the mayor and council for such purpose. 
(b)  The mayor and council shall grant the application for a permit if it appears that the group, association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the park by individual members of the public, and if the said group, association or organization meets all other reasonable conditions which may be imposed by the mayor and council. 
(c)  Such application may contain a requirement for an indemnity bond to protect the city from any liability of any kind or character and to protect city property from damage. 
Sec. 19-4. - Fishing in city parks, etc., on Sunday. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to engage in fishing on the Sabbath (Sunday) in any of the city parks in the city or to fish on Sunday on any other city property. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, 6-30-75) 
State Law reference— Fishing licenses, O.C.G.A. § 45-301 et seq. 
Sec. 19-5. - Signs. 
It shall be unlawful for anyone to paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement or inscription whatever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park, except that these provisions shall not apply to any properly authorized government official in pursuit of any official duty. 
Sec. 19-6. - Camping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping, nor shall any person leave in a park after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used, or that could be used, for such purpose, such as a house-trailer, camp-trailer, camp-wagon or the like. 
Sec. 19-7. - Alcoholic beverages. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within any park to have in his possession, custody or control any alcoholic beverage of any kind whatsoever. 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages generally, ch. 3. 
Sec. 19-8. - Park hours of operation/loitering after hours. 
(a)  The public parks shall be open to the public daily from sunrise to sunset. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons other than city personnel conducting city business therein to occupy or be present in such parks during any other hours except as provided in section 19-2. 
(c)  any section or part of a park, or an entire park, may be declared closed to the public by either the director of public works or designee at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular or stated intervals if deemed necessary for the health and safety of the public at large or preservation of city property. 
(Ord. No. O-02-14, 8-11-14) 
Chapter 20 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Personnel management system. 
The Personnel Management System for the City of Nashville, as drawn by the Coastal Plain Area Planning and Development Commission, is hereby adopted as a part of this chapter as if set out at length herein. 
Sec. 20-2. - Status of employees; definition. 
(a)  Employees hired into continuing positions and who regularly work forty (40) or more hours per week are given career full-time appointments. Their conditions of employment are set forth in the city's personnel management system directive. The information contained therein applies to this group of employees. Certain employees are not automatically covered. They are excepted by ordinance from being subject to these conditions. Primarily these employees are the department heads in charge of the major departments listed in section 2-1. Their conditions of employment are established individually by the city council. 
(b)  The following types of employees are also excepted from the personnel management system: Employees hired as temporary, part-time, irregular or seasonal are not automatically covered by the conditions of employment set forth in the abovementioned directive. The city council may, by individual action, give any of the above excepted employees coverage under any part or parts of the provisions of the personnel management system. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 2) 
Sec. 20-3. - Position title and grade. 
(a)  The city maintains a file of job specifications. These specifications contain a position title, examples of duties, the knowledge, skills and abilities needed to perform the work and the qualification requirements to be met by applicants hired into the position. Each employee is assigned one (1) of these position titles. 
(b)  The city also has a grade or work level system composed of grade 1 through grade 15. These grade levels identify the level of difficulty, skill or responsibility of each city position as compared with other positions. The least difficult or trainee level jobs are at the bottom, and the highest skilled or responsible positions near the top of the scale. The grade of the position is one (1) of the more important factors considered in setting the salary of each position. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 6) 
Sec. 20-4. - Trial period. 
All newly hired or re-employed career full-time employees of the City of Nashville are required to serve a trial period. This period is used to closely observe the abilities and work of new employees and evaluate their potential to make satisfactory long term employees. The trial period begins with the first day of continuous full-time employment. The length of the trial period is six (6) months for any newly hired or re-employed career full-time employees of all departments of the City of Nashville other than the Nashville Police Department. The length of the trial period is one (1) year for any newly hired or re-employed career full-time employee of the Nashville Police Department. If at any time during the trial period it becomes apparent that an employee will not make a satisfactory career worker, dismissal action will be taken. Employees dismissed during the trial period do not have appeal rights. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 5; Ord. of 2-10-97, § 1) 
Sec. 20-5. - Pay. 
(a)  As chief executive, the mayor is responsible for setting the rate of pay for each employee at the time of employment. Employees are considered for raises at the beginning of each new fiscal year. Pay increases are not automatic. An employee who is not recommended or approved will continue to receive pay at the last authorized rate. Employees who are performing at an exceptional level may be given a special merit pay increase during the year. 
(b)  Overtime is paid in accordance with the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act (minimum wage law). Except for policemen and firemen, overtime at the rate of one and one-half (1½) times the regular rate is paid for hours worked over forty (40) during the seven-day administrative work week. Policemen and firemen are paid overtime in accordance with the above Act. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 7) 
Sec. 20-6. - Bonus. 
Each employee who has been in the employ of the city for at least six (6) months will receive a Christmas bonus to be paid on a pro rata basis. 
(Ord. of 7-16-73) 
Sec. 20-7. - Performance rating. 
(a)  After the end of the trial period, employees will be rated annually during May of each year by the department head. The mayor will review the recommended ratings and concur or change the evaluation to reflect his own conclusions. The mayor's rating will be official. Employees will be informed of their rating. If the overall performance is not satisfactory, the employee will be warned of action which may be taken if the deficiencies are not corrected. When performance is not brought up to satisfactory, dismissal actions may be initiated. 
(b)  The following ratings will be used: Excellent, satisfactory, marginal or unsatisfactory. A record will be kept of each rating. Employees may not appeal a performance rating through the grievance procedure. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 11) 
Sec. 20-8. - Workers' compensation. 
The city carries workers' compensation insurance as required by the state's workers' compensation laws. The purpose of workers' compensation insurance is to provide protection to employees who are injured while on the job. If an employee is killed or becomes temporarily or permanently disabled while on the job, the city's workers' compensation insurance provides compensation for time lost in accordance with the schedule contained in the law. An employee who is injured while at work shall report the injury at once to his supervisor. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 15) 
State Law reference— Workers' compensation, Ga. Code Ann., Title 114. 
Sec. 20-9. - State retirement system. 
(a)  The city retirement program is provided without cost to the employee. The city carries the total expense of this program. The retirement system, a joint program established in cooperation with other Georgia cities is called the Joint Municipal Employees Retirement System, referred to as "JMERS." 
(b)  Normal retirement age is sixty-five (65). Early retirement is permitted after age fifty-five (55) with ten (10) years of service. All full-time employees who were employed when the plan went into effect (November 1, 1973) were immediately covered. After the implementation date of the plan, all new full-time employees become eligible for membership after one (1) year of employment, provided they are hired on or before their fifty-fifth birthday. 
(c)  The size of the pension will depend on such factors as the number of years of creditable service at the time of retirement and the monthly earnings for a five-year period prior to retirement in which the employee's earnings were (or will be) the highest. 
(d)  The plan also offers several options with respect to the type of annuity which may be selected at the time of retirement. The employee may choose to retire under the option which pays the highest monthly benefit but under which all payments cease upon death, or a joint survivor option under which the retiree receives a reduced pension but under which a designated beneficiary continues to receive part of the pension after the retiree's death. 
(e)  Employees nearing retirement and others desiring more complete information on the subject should ask the department head for further details. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 14) 
State Law reference— Joint municipal employees retirement system, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1701 et seq. 
Sec. 20-10. - Disability added to retirement plan. 
Disability provisions are hereby added to the municipal employees retirement plan. 
(Mo. of 4-8-74) 
Sec. 20-11. - Grievance procedure—Purpose; definition. 
(a)  The purpose of the grievance procedure is to establish a fair and impartial procedure by which career full-time employees may make known their complaints and have these complaints adjusted. This procedure cannot be used by part-time, temporary, seasonal or irregular employees; however, these employees should discuss any problem or complaint with their department head. 
(b)  A grievance is any complaint or dispute concerning working conditions, interpretation of personnel policies, city policies, rules and regulations and decisions relative to dismissal, demotion, suspension or oral reprimand. 
(c)  This procedure may also be used for charges of discrimination based on sex, political affiliation, race, color, national origin or religion. 
(d)  Employees may not appeal dismissal during the trial period and performance evaluation. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 13) 
Sec. 20-12. - Same—Procedure. 
(a)  An employee must notify the department head of the grievance not later than three (3) days after the incident occurs. A complaint may be submitted on a continuing condition at any time. 
(b)  An employee receiving an unfavorable decision may continue a complaint to the next step providing it is submitted within three (3) days after receiving the lower step decision. 
(c)  Procedural steps. 
(1)  Step 1. Department head meets with employee within three (3) days after receiving complaint. Employee will be advised of the decision not later than three (3) days after the meeting. 
(2)  Step 2. The mayor appoints a grievance board. The board will conduct an inquiry within ten (10) days after the grievance is received. It will talk with witnesses and look at any documentary evidence. It will submit its written recommendations to the mayor within five (5) days after the close of the inquiry. The mayor will give the employee a written decision within five (5) days after receiving the board's recommendations. This decision will be final except for dismissal, demotion and discrimination complaints, which may be appealed in writing within three (3) days to the city council. 
(3)  Step 3. The city council will appoint a committee from its members, excluding the mayor, to review the case and report its recommendations. The decision of the city council is final. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 13) 
Secs. 20-13—20-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— As to additional information on the conditions of employment of career full-time employees, see the city's personnel management system directive, on file in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 20-29. - Rules of conduct—Generally. 
Employees shall conduct themselves, both on and off the job, in a manner which will reflect favorably upon themselves and the city. Although the city does not wish to interfere in the private lives of its employees, they are expected to be honest, reliable, trustworthy and of good character and reputation. Employees are expected to be loyal to the city. The rules of conduct in sections 20-30 and 20-31 set forth in general what is expected of employees. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 12) 
Sec. 20-30. - Same—Work rules. 
Employees are expected to observe the following rules and practices: 
(1)  Be at work on time and observe the time limits established for meal and break periods; 
(2)  Do not leave work during duty hours without proper permission; 
(3)  Notify supervisors as soon as possible, but not later than one (1) hour after starting time if unable to report for work on time due to emergency or illness; 
(4)  Do not abuse sick leave privileges; 
(5)  Do not report for work under the influence of alcohol or intoxicating drugs, or use them on duty; 
(6)  Obey all proper orders from superiors. Insubordination includes refusal to obey instruction and use of abusive, profane or threatening language toward supervisory personnel; 
(7)  Do not coerce or harass fellow employees, or use profane or insulting language or gestures toward them; 
(8)  Do not engage in arguing, fighting, horseplay or conduct violating common decency or morality; 
(9)  Do not bring firearms or other weapons to work except after being given proper permission, or when required by the position of employment; 
(10)  When required by the position, report for duty in a clean, neat, correct uniform; 
(11)  Do not sleep on duty unless authorized; 
(12)  Do not use government tools or equipment for personal use or remove them from government premises or control without proper permission; 
(13)  Gambling on duty or on government property is forbidden; 
(14)  Do not knowingly give false information on reports or other required documents; 
(15)  Maintain personal hygiene so as not to offend fellow workers; 
(16)  Do not knowingly violate any safety procedure or practice; perform work so as to protect against accidents to self and others; 
(17)  Always observe all proper rules, regulations, policies, guides and laws in effect which are issued, or require compliance, by the city. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 12) 
Sec. 20-31. - Same—Code of ethics. 
Employees shall: 
(1)  Put loyalty to the highest moral principles and to the city above loyalty to persons, party or department; 
(2)  Uphold the charter, ordinances, resolutions and regulations of the city and never be a party to the evasion; 
(3)  Perform a full day's work for a fully day's pay; giving one's earnest effort and best thought to the performance of one's duties; 
(4)  Seek to find and employ more efficient and economical ways of getting tasks accomplished; 
(5)  Never discriminate unfairly by the dispensing of special favors or privileges to anyone, whether for remuneration or not; and never accept, for self or family, favors or benefits under circumstances which might be construed by reasonable persons as influencing the performance of governmental duties; 
(6)  Make no private promise of any kind binding upon the duties of office, since a government employee has no private word which can be binding on public duty; 
(7)  Engage in no business with the government, either directly or indirectly, which is inconsistent with the conscientious performance of governmental duties; 
(8)  Never use any information received confidentially in the performance of governmental duties as a means for making private profit; 
(9)  Expose corruption wherever discovered; 
(10)  Uphold these principles, ever conscious that a public office is a public trust. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 12) 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for government service, Ga. Code Ann., § 89-925. 
Sec. 20-32. - Political activities. 
(a)  No employee of this city may hold an elective office in the city, nor shall such an employee offer as a candidate for elective office in any government while so employed. Neither shall an employee solicit any contributions or assessments, or services, nor publicly endorse any candidate for any government elective office. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall affect the right of employees to contribute to, hold membership in or support a political party, to vote as they choose, to express privately their opinions on all political subjects, to maintain political neutrality or to attend political meetings provided they do not participate actively. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 3) 
Charter reference— Political activities of officers and employees, § 5-5. 
Sec. 20-33. - Hours of work. 
All employees except police department and fire department personnel are assigned to work a forty-hour work week. Police department personnel are assigned to work a forty-eight-hour week. Fire department employees are assigned to a twenty-four-hour on-duty and forty-eight-hour off-duty schedule. The days and hours to be worked during the week for each employee are determined by the mayor. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 8) 
Charter reference— Mayor as chief executive officer of the city government, § 2-10. 
Sec. 20-34. - Administrative leave. 
Administrative leave may be granted with pay for such purposes as: 
(1)  Jury duty or an appearance as a witness for the city. 
(2)  Loans to the United Fund, Red Cross or other civic organizations. 
(3)  When employees are unable to work due to breakdown of government equipment, severe weather or other conditions making working conditions hazardous or unbearable. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 10) 
Sec. 20-35. - Vacation leave. 
Career full-time employees will be granted vacation time as follows: 
(1)  Employees hired after January 1 will earn leave during the first calendar year at the rate of: 
One (1) day for one (1) full quarter of work; 
Two (2) days for two (2) full quarters of work; 
Three (3) days for three (3) full quarters of work; 
Four (4) days for three (3) full; and 
One (1) partial quarter worked. 
(2)  Starting with the first full calendar year of employment, employees with up to five (5) years' continuous service will be granted leave for that calendar year equal to the number of days in their present standard work week. 
(3)  Employees with five (5) or more years of continuous service shall be granted leave for that year at the rate of two (2) times the number of days in their present work week. (For example, an employee with under five (5) years service, who works a forty-hour week, will receive forty (40) hours of vacation time off a year. A policeman with over five (5) years service, who works a forty-eight-hour week, will receive ninety-six (96) hours of vacation time off a year.) 
(4)  Employees will not be paid for vacation leave taken during the first three (3) months of employment. Normally, vacation leave will be taken within the calendar year in which it is granted. 
(5)  Employees shall submit requests for vacation leave in writing to their department head, who shall transmit them to the mayor and council for approval. 
(6)  After one (1) year of employment, employees leaving the service of the city will be paid for unused vacation leave to their credit for that year. 
(Ord. of 7-16-73; Ord. of 4-22-74, § 10) 
Sec. 20-36. - Leave without pay. 
Leave without pay may be directed or granted for such purposes as: 
(1)  Sickness, after all sick and annual leave is expended, up to three (3) months. 
(2)  Layoffs due to lack of work not to exceed six (6) months. 
(3)  Time off not to exceed one (1) year, including part of a day, for education purposes when the education will benefit the city. 
(4)  Any other purpose found to warrant such action at the discretion of the mayor. 
The mayor is the only authorizing official for leave without pay. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 10) 
Sec. 20-37. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Career full-time employees earn sick leave at the rate of one (1) day per month. Employees can accumulate unused sick leave as follows: 
Under five (5) years: Accumulate up to six (6) days; 
Five (5) years and over accumulate up to thirty (30) days. 
(b)  In order to be entitled to sick leave, an employee must be incapacitated for work due to illness, a non-job-connected injury or have a doctor or dentist appointment. Employees who are absent frequently for short periods of illness, or who are out sick over three (3) days, may be required to produce a doctor's statement verifying that the absence was necessary due to illness. 
(Mo. of 8-13-73; Ord. of 4-22-74, § 10) 
Sec. 20-38. - Holidays. 
(a)  The following holidays are observed: 
January 1 
MLK, Jr. Holiday 
Memorial Day 
July 4 
Labor Day 
Thanksgiving Day 
Christmas Day 
Special holidays may be observed at the discretion of the mayor and council. 
(b)  All career full-time employees scheduled for duty on a holiday, and whose duties permit, will receive the above holidays off with pay. Career full-time employees who are required to work on a holiday, in addition to their regular pay for that day, will receive additional pay for the hours worked at their straight-time rate, unless overtime pay is required under the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 9; Ord. of 11-26-90; Ord. of 2-11-02, § I) 
State law reference —Public and legal holidays designated, Ga. Code Ann., § 14-1809; O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1. 
Sec. 20-39. - Age limit. 
An employee, upon reaching sixty-five (65) years of age, shall be terminated, or if eligible, be retired from the career service without prejudice. The city council may authorize the immediate reemployment of such an employee under a temporary appointment, not to exceed one (1) year, when it serves the best interest of the city. Such an employee serves at the convenience of the city council and is subject to termination at any time by will of the council. The city council may exercise this authority each year at the expiration of the last temporary appointment. 
(Ord. of 4-22-74, § 4) 
State Law reference— Age requirement to hold civil office, Ga. Code Ann., § 89-101. 
Secs. 20-40—20-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL SECURITY FOR CITY EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Social security for employees of political subdivisions, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 99-21. 

Sec. 20-55. - Coverage. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Security Administration, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this chapter, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 761 of the 83rd Congress, and as provided for in Act No. 82, Georgia Laws 1956, approved February 13, 1956 (Ga. Code Ann., § 99-2101 et seq.). In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 17-1) 
Sec. 20-56. - Authority for agreements. 
The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia and officials as provided for in section 20-55 hereof to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1967, § 17-2) 
Charter reference— Mayor as chief executive officer of the city government, § 2-10. 
Sec. 20-57. - Coverage extended to policemen. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to sign all agreements, ordinances and regulations furnished by the Employees Retirement System to do whatever is necessary to provide social security coverage for policemen. 
(Code 1967, § 17-7) 
Sec. 20-58. - Excluded employees. 
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 17-6) 
Sec. 20-59. - Records and reports required. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 17-5) 
Sec. 20-60. - Withholdings. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 20-55 of this article are hereby authorized to be made in the amount and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(Code 1967, § 17-3) 
Sec. 20-61. - Appropriations from general funds. 
There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by the applicable state or federal law or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses and a guaranty fund to assure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 20-56 of this article. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by said agency. 
(Code 1967, § 17-4) 
Secs. 20-62—20-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRUG- AND ALCOHOL-FREE WORKPLACE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Inasmuch as an ordinance adopted Feb. 22, 1993, did not specify manner of codification, inclusion herein as Art. IV, §§ 20-66—20-75, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 20-66. - Policy. 
It is the policy of the City of Nashville to maintain a work place that is free from the effects of drug and alcohol abuse. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-67. - Use, sale, dispensing etc. of illegal drugs and narcotics or alcoholic beverages on city premises. 
Employees are prohibited from the use, sale, dispensing, distribution, possession, or manufacture of illegal drugs and narcotics or alcoholic beverages on city premises or work sites. In addition, employees are prohibited from the off-premises use of alcohol and possession, use, or sale of illegal drugs when such activities adversely affect job performance, job safety, or the City of Nashville's reputation in the community. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-68. - Hiring practices. 
The City of Nashville will not hire, unless state or local law provides otherwise, alcoholics or drug abusers whose current use of such substances prevents them from performing their jobs or who would constitute a direct threat to the property or safety of others. Whenever applicants for employment are to be tested for the presence of such substances, they are to be informed of the test in advance and in writing. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-69. - Disciplinary action. 
Employees will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination, for violations of this policy. Such violations include, but are not limited to, possessing illegal or nonprescribed drugs and narcotics or alcoholic beverages at work; being under the influence of such substances while working; using them while working; or dispensing, distributing, or illegally manufacturing or selling them on the city premises and work sites. Employees, their possessions, and city-issued equipment and containers under their control are subject to search and surveillance at all times while on city premises or while conducting city business. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-70. - Testing for illegal drugs or alcohol. 
Employees may be required to take a test at any time to determine the presence of drugs, narcotics, or alcohol, unless such tests are prohibited by law. Testing positive for illegal drugs or alcohol is a violation of this policy. Employees subject to the drug-free workplace act who are convicted of any criminal drug violation occurring in the work place must report such conviction to the personnel department within five (5) days, and the personnel department is then to take appropriate action as required by law. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-71. - Determination of need for examination. 
Supervisors should report immediately to the personnel department any action by an employee who demonstrates an unusual behavior pattern. The personnel department will determine whether the employee should be examined by a physician or clinic and/or tested for drugs and alcohol. Employees believed to be under the influence of drugs, narcotics, or alcohol will be required to leave the premises. A police officer should be notified to arrange safe transit. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-72. - Report of use of legal drugs. 
Any employees who use legal drugs or narcotics during work, and have any reason to expect such use may affect their ability to perform their work, must report this fact to the personnel department. A determination will then be made as to whether the employee should be able to perform the essential functions of the job safely and properly. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-73. - Counselling. 
Employees who are experiencing work-related or personal problems resulting from drug, narcotic, or alcohol abuse or dependency may request, or be required to seek counseling help. City-sponsored or required counseling should be kept confidential and should not have any influence on performance appraisals. Job performance alone, not the fact that an employee seeks counseling, is to be the basis of all performance appraisals. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-74. - Leave of absence to undertake treatment. 
Any employee who is abusing drugs or alcohol may be granted a leave of absence to undertake rehabilitation treatment. The employee will not be permitted to return to work until certification is presented to the personnel department that the employee is capable to performing his job. Failure to cooperate with an agreed-upon treatment plan may result in discipline, up to and including termination. Participation in a treatment program does not insulate an employee from the imposition of discipline for violations of this or other company policies. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Sec. 20-75. - Awareness programs. 
The city will, to the extent feasible, provide continuing awareness programs for the work force about the harmful effects of drug and alcohol abuse. 
(Ord. of 2-22-93) 
Chapter 21 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note— An ordinance enacted May 12, 1986, repealed Ord. No. 1-75, dated June 30, 1975, from which Art. II, Flood Damage Protection, of Ch. 21 was derived. The substantive provisions of former Art. II consisted of §§ 21-18—21-25. In addition, the ordinance of May 12, 1986, also enacted new provisions which have been included as a new Art. II herein. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Planning commission created; membership; terms of office; powers and duties. 
(a)  The city does hereby authorize and create a planning commission as provided for in state enabling statutes as set forth in Georgia Laws of 1957, page 420, as amended (Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1201 et seq.). 
(b)  The planning commission shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the mayor and city council with staggered terms consisting of not less than three (3) years and not more than five (5) years. 
(c)  The said planning commission shall be clothed with all the powers and duties as set out in the above mentioned enabling legislation. 
(Code 1967, § 2-9) 
Secs. 21-2—21-7. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Sept. 14, 2009, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II consisted of §§ 21-8—21-41, pertained to the same subject matter and derived from an ordinance adopted May 12, 1986. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-8. - Statutory authorization, findings of fact, purpose and objectives. 
(a)  Authorization. Article IX, Section II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(a) have delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. 
(b)  Findings of fact. 
(1)  The flood hazard areas of Nashville, Georgia, are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. 
(c)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities, which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(2)  Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; 
(3)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion; 
(4)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; and 
(5)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. 
(d)  Objectives. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To protect human life and health; 
(2)  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(3)  To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; 
(4)  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(5)  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(6)  To minimize prolonged business interruptions; and 
(7)  To insure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. of 9-14-09, art. I) 
Sec. 21-9. - Definitions. 
Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this ordinance shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application. 
Accessory structure means a structure having minimal value and used for parking, storage and other nonhabitable uses, such as garages, carports, storage sheds, pole barns, hay sheds and the like. 
Addition (to an existing building) means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building in which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other than a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition, which is connected by a firewall or is separated by an independent perimeter load-bearing wall, shall be considered "new construction". 
Appeal means a request for a review of the administrator's interpretation of any provision of this article. 
Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO or AH zone on a community's flood insurance rate map (FIRM) with base flood depths from one (1) to three (3) feet, and/or where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate, and where velocity flow may be evident. 
Area of special flood hazard is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one (1) percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. In the absence of official designation by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, areas of special flood hazard shall be those designated by the local community and referenced in section 21-11. 
Base flood means the flood having a one (1) percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
Base flood elevation (BFE) means the elevation shown on the flood insurance rate map for zones AE, AH, A1-A30, AR, AR/A, AR/AE, AR/A1-A30, AR/AH, AR/AO, V1-V30, and VE that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from a flood that has a one-percent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year. 
Basement means that portion of a building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
Building means any structure built for support, shelter, or enclosure for any occupancy or storage. 
Critical facility means any public or private facility, which, if flooded, would create an added dimension to the disaster or would increase the hazard to life and health. Critical facilities include: 
(a)  Structures or facilities that produce, use, or store highly volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic, or water-reactive materials; 
(b)  Hospitals and nursing homes, and housing for the elderly, which are likely to contain occupants who may not be sufficiently mobile to avoid the loss of life or injury during flood and storm events; 
(c)  Emergency operation centers or data storage centers which contain records or services that may become lost or inoperative during flood and storm events; and 
(d)  Generating plants, and other principal points of utility lines. 
Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating, drilling operations, and storage of materials or equipment.
