Use of bulk solid waste containers property designed for available mechanical pickup equipment may be approved by the administrative officer for apartment houses, commercial places, institutions and similar locations where large amounts of solid waste are generated. Approvals for use of bulk containers shall be based upon durability of construction, adaptability to mechanical pickup equipment, adequacy of capacity, ease of maintenance, proposed location and any other factors upon acceptability of the proposed bulk container. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.2) 
Sec. 25-57. - Garbage containers to be kept clean. 
Solid waste containers containing garbage of any sort shall be washed thoroughly after being emptied and shall be treated with an insecticide, or they shall be lined with a suitable paper or plastic material. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.13) 
Sec. 25-58. - Materials prohibited in containers. 
It shall be a violation of this chapter to place or cause to be placed in any refuse can or container for collection any acid, explosive material, inflammable liquids or dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.11) 
Sec. 25-59. - Tampering with containers. 
No person other than the owner thereof, or an agent or employee of the administrative officer, or an employee of a person holding a contract with the city for collection of solid waste, shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing solid waste pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where same shall have been placed by the owner thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.7) 
Sec. 25-60. - Yard debris. 
No grass clippings, shrubbery clippings, tree limbs, bushes or any similar yard debris may be deposited into the container for household solid waste for disposal. All such yard debris shall be removed by the property owner/resident/commercial collector or deposited on the street or curbside for pick up by the City of Nashville. No yard debris shall be placed or disposed of by the owner/resident/commercial collector on the street or curbside in such manner as to impair, impede or obstruct in any manner the City of Nashville storm drainage system. Violation of this section may result in a citation and fine in accordance with the applicable schedule of fines for the City of Nashville. 
(Ord. of 10-27-08) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Oct. 27, 2008, amended § 25-60, which pertained to tree and brush waste and derived from an ordinance adopted Aug. 14, 1972, in its entirety to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 25-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Oct. 27, 2008, deleted § 25-61 which pertained to the storage of trash and leaves in bags and derived from ordinances adopted Aug. 14, 1972; Mar. 25, 1974; and Aug. 26, 1974. 
Sec. 25-62. - Collection of pet litter. 
Pet litter will not be collected unless placed in a securely closed plastic or paper bag. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.12) 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 25-63. - Liquid wastes. 
Liquids will not be collected by the city and shall be disposed of by other means. The administrative officer shall assist persons in finding a solution to disposal problems involving them. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.7) 
Sec. 25-64. - Accumulation of refuse generally. 
Each owner shall prevent the continued, excessive and unsightly accumulation of refuse and litter upon the property occupied by him or public thoroughfares adjoining his property, or water drainage ditches. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 7.10) 
Sec. 25-65. - Unauthorized accumulation of waste as nuisance. 
Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste on any premise is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of solid waste within such reasonable time as may be fixed by written notice of the administrative officer shall be deemed a violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.6) 
State Law reference— Abatement of nuisances in cities, Ga. Code Ann., § 72-401. 
Secs. 25-66—25-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS AND MULTIPLE DWELLINGS 

Sec. 25-82. - Approval of refuse storage arrangements. 
Before a building permit shall be issued for construction of a commercial establishment or multiple dwelling, arrangements for the storage of refuse and location of containers must be approved by the administrative officer and furnished by the establishment. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.1; Ord. of 3-25-74) 
Cross reference— Buildings, Ch. 5; issuance of building permits, App. A, § 102. 
Sec. 25-83. - Location of commercial containers. 
Commercial containers at existing commercial establishments and multiple dwellings shall be placed at locations approved by the administrative officer for collection by the sanitary department. The city will not collect refuse from commercial establishments or multiple dwellings unless it is placed in commercial containers, properly located. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.2) 
Sec. 25-84. - Collection of cardboard boxes. 
Cardboard boxes shall be flattened and placed in containers; exception to this must be obtained in writing from the administrative officer. All exceptions must have an increase in fee. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.2) 
Sec. 25-85. - Maintenance of area around shared containers. 
Where the occupants of two (2) or more commercial establishments share the use of a refuse can or commercial container, it shall be the joint responsibility of the users to maintain the area surrounding such cans or containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.3) 
Sec. 25-86. - Maintenance of area around multiple dwelling containers. 
Where multiple dwellings are served by commercial containers, it shall be the responsibility of the management of such property to maintain the area surrounding such commercial containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse and litter. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 8.4) 
Secs. 25-87—25-102. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POLLUTION CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate the emission of smoke or other exhaust, § 2-9(ii). 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide air pollution control services, Ga. Code Ann., § 2-6102; unlawful activities relating to fires, Ga. Code Ann., § 26-9926a; Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-701 et seq.; air quality generally, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 43-27. 

Sec. 25-103. - When burning permitted. 
A permit for burning shall be granted by the fire department in such cases as follow: 
(1)  Reduction of leaves on the premises on which they fall by the person in control of the premises, after notice to the fire department, unless prohibited by local ordinance and/or regulation; 
(2)  Destruction of combustible demolition or construction materials either on site or transported to a burning facility approved by the department of natural resources, unless prohibited by local regulations; 
(3)  For recreational purposes or cooking food for immediate human consumption; 
(4)  Fires set for purposes of training public fire-fighting personnel when authorized by the appropriate governmental entity and the guidelines set forth by the department of natural resources are strictly observed; 
(5)  Disposal of tree limbs and other loose materials resulting from storm damage. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 15.3; Mo. of 8-26-74) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 25-104. - Outdoor burning of garbage. 
No garbage or other materials from which offensive or nuisance odors emanate during combustion shall be burned outside of any building. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 15.2) 
Sec. 25-105. - Fires on solid waste disposal or storage site. 
No person shall set fire to or burn any papers or other solid waste deposited at any storage or disposal site or on the grounds thereof. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 15.1) 
Sec. 25-106. - Bonfires on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build or make any fires in or upon any of the streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-13) 
Secs. 25-107—25-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COLLECTION OF REFUSE 

Sec. 25-123. - Collection and disposal generally. 
Refuse may be collected, for disposal by the city, by individuals or commercial sanitation firms licensed by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 11-6; Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.1) 
Sec. 25-124. - Frequency of collections. 
The city and its licensed scavengers will collect refuse under the following conditions: 
(1)  Refuse will be collected at least twice each week from residential units; yard trash will be collected once weekly on a day specified by the administrative officer. 
(2)  Refuse will be collected as often as five (5) times a week from commercial establishments. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.2; Ord. of 3-25-74) 
Sec. 25-125. - Curbside pickup—Designation of days. 
When curbside pickup service is designated within a pickup route or district the administrative officer shall designate in writing the days of the week upon which curbside pickup will be made; the days are to be the same in each week and shall not be changed to a different day or days without at least ten (10) days' notice in writing to each owner or occupant on the route. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.7) 
Sec. 25-126. - Same—Fee. 
(a)  The fee for curbside pickup of refuse on a complete route basis as described and defined in this article shall be determined by the council. 
(b)  Sanitation fees for regular curbside pick-up for ninety-five-gallon containers will be: 
Residential: Thirteen dollars and fifty cents ($13.50) per month, per container. 
Beauty shop: Thirteen dollars and fifty cents ($13.50) per month, per container. 
Commercial: Fourteen dollars and forty cents ($14.40) per month, per container. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.9; Ord. of 8-22-05) 
Sec. 25-127. - Same—Placement of refuse on curb. 
On the days designated for curbside pickup it shall be the duty of each owner to carry his refuse to the curb in front of his residence before 8:00 a.m. or prior to the arrival of the pickup crew. Any bag or container of refuse placed on the curb after the departure of the pickup crew shall be at the peril of the owner and he shall be subject to prosecution for violation of section 18-42 should the street become littered from the contents of this bag or container. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.8) 
Sec. 25-128. - Holidays. 
Collections shall not be made on the following holidays unless otherwise specified by the administrative officer: New Year's Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.6) 
Sec. 25-129. - Collection of dead animals. 
Small dead animals, not over thirty (30) pounds in weight, if kept separate from garbage and rubbish, will be collected without charge upon notice to the administrative officer, provided that a charge will be made for such animals collected from animal hospitals, kennels, pet shops and the like. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.3) 
Sec. 25-130. - Discontinuance when containers unfit. 
Collection service shall be discontinued where residential containers or commercial containers are inadequate or have been condemned as unfit by a sanitary inspector and notice of same has been given to the owner or occupant of the premises who has refused to correct the situation then existing. 
(Code 1967, § 11-2; Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.4) 
Sec. 25-131. - Materials not collected by city. 
The city shall not be responsible for collecting or hauling discarded building material, dirt, rock or discarded furniture and appliances from private property, nor shall it be responsible for collecting or hauling trees, bushes or other vegetation from commercial tree trimmers, landscapers or building contractors except on a special fee basis as may be established by the council. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.5) 
Sec. 25-132. - Contract collectors. 
Any person may contract with the council to engage in the business of collection, transporting or disposing of solid waste, provided such person has applied for and obtained an appropriate solid waste permit in accordance with rules and regulations of the department. Persons contracting for solid waste collection and disposal shall, before engaging in such business, be licensed by the city and shall conform to all regulations providing for safe and sanitary collection and transportation of waste to a point of disposal, and shall execute a bond to the city in the amount stipulated by his specific contract specifications but in no case less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), with a responsible surety company duly authorized to do business in the state, to be approved by the council, establishing conditions for the full and faithful performance of all agreements and covenants in said contract. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.10) 
Sec. 25-133. - License for collection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to collect solid waste within the city, except from his own residence or business or industrial property, without first obtaining a license for such business operation from the city. 
(b)  Written applications for licenses shall be filed with the administrative officer two (2) weeks prior to the date of any action required with respect thereto, with the following three (3) exhibits: 
(1)  A collector's permit as required under solid waste regulations; 
(2)  The required license tax as set forth in the occupational license tax schedule on file in the office of the city clerk; and 
(3)  Evidence executed by representatives of a duly qualified insurance company attesting that liability and property damage insurance has been issued to the applicant in amounts acceptable to the administrative officer, to remain in effect for the term of the license, and that the administrative officer shall be notified not less than thirty (30) days prior to any change in, expiration of or cancellation of such insurance. The administrative officer shall cause to be made an appraisal of the application including, but not limited to, the qualification of the applicant, equipment proposed to be used, service to be provided, methods of operation and capacity to finance the proposal; when the requirements herein specified are found to be met and the best interests of the city to be satisfactorily served, the administrative officer shall approve the application and forward same with fees to the city clerk, who shall issue the license. All such licenses shall expire on December thirty-first of the year of issue. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 9.1) 
Sec. 25-134. - Transportation of refuse—Requirements for vehicles. 
Vehicles to be used in streets and highways for solid waste collection, transportation or disposal shall be kept clean and shall be certified in regard to highway safety by the motor vehicle division of the Georgia Department of Public Safety. Such vehicle bodies shall be in good condition and repair, covered and constructed in such manner that the contents thereof cannot be spilled, leaked or blown from the vehicle. The outside of the body shall be painted and identified by the name, telephone number and permit number of the person owning the collection business in letters and numbers not less than three (3) inches high and easily legible. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 10.11) 
Sec. 25-135. - Same—Securing material transported. 
It shall be unlawful for any person including city collectors and sanitary contractors to haul, convey or cause to be conveyed any refuse, including discarded building material or discarded furniture, upon or along the public streets except when the material transported is adequately secured in such a manner as to prevent it from falling, leaking or being blown from transporting vehicles. The operator of the offending vehicle shall be personally responsible for any violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 11.1) 
Sec. 25-136. - Same—Unlicensed collection. 
It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person, not licensed by the city, to collect and haul any refuse, other than that arising from his own accumulation, within any area of the city in which refuse collection service is maintained by the city. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 11.2) 
Secs. 25-137—25-152. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SANITATION FEES 

Sec. 25-153. - Sanitary docket. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk or his authorized deputy to prepare, maintain and keep for public inspection a complete record of the name of each owner, the address of the premises served, either by street address or by tax map reference if no street address is available, the amount of the sanitation fees, the amount of each payment and an entry showing when each payment was made. This record shall be called the sanitary docket. Each docket shall be cumulative of all unpaid monthly installments. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 17.2) 
Sec. 25-154. - Determination of fees. 
Fees for the collection and disposal of solid waste by the city shall be set and determined by the council after appropriate public hearing. 
(Code 1967, § 11-4; Ord. of 8-14-72, § 16.1) 
Editor's note— The schedule of solid waste collection fees is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 25-154.1. - Sanitation deposit charge. 
There shall be a sanitation deposit charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) to guarantee the payment of monthly sanitation charges for commercial and residential customers who do not pay for water or gas services with the City and do not have a water or gas deposit. When service to customer is discontinued permanently, this deposit, less any amounts still due the city for sanitation service, shall be refunded without interest. Should customer failed to pay their bill, service will be discontinued with container being picked up and amount due city will be deducted from deposit. Customer will be responsible for any balance due after deposit has been applied. 
(Ord. of 8-28-06) 
Sec. 25-155. - Mailing and payment of statements. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk or his authorized deputy to prepare and mail to each owner or commercial lessee in the sanitary district of Nashville who receives sanitary service a statement showing the amount due and the amount in arrears, if any. Such statements shall be prepared in advance. Each payment shall be paid in advance by the owner, and such payment shall become delinquent upon the first day of the next succeeding month. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 17.1) 
Sec. 25-156. - Records available for public use. 
Upon the request of any person interested in examining the title of any parcel of real estate within the city, the person in charge of the maintenance of the sanitary docket under the supervision of the city clerk or his authorized deputy shall furnish to him a form statement showing the information required in this article, which form statement shall be signed by the person maintaining said docket and said authorized deputy as to the correctness of the information contained therein. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 17.3) 
Sec. 25-157. - Termination of service when fees unpaid. 
On premises being served by the sanitation department where there is a delinquent sanitary installment, after the owner or commercial lessee thereof has been notified by the inclusion of the amount of the past due installment in a current statement or on a separate bill or other notice and the owner or commercial lessee refuses to promptly pay same, the administrative officer shall have the authority to refuse sanitary pickup at such premises. Regardless of whether the installment remaining delinquent was incurred by a prior owner or commercial lessee, the sanitary service shall not be restored until such delinquent and current installments are paid in full. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 17.5) 
Sec. 25-158. - Issuance of executions; liens. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk or his authorized deputy to make an annual audit of the sanitary docket during the last quarter of each calendar year, but not later than December 15, and issue a fi. fa. or execution against the property served, which fi. fa. or execution shall have the same lien dignity and priority as fi. fa.s or executions issued for city taxes. Each monthly installment shall immediately become a lien against the property served upon the date it fall due. 
(Ord. of 8-14-72, § 17.4) 
State Law reference— Executions and proceeding thereunder, O.C.G.A., tit. 39; liens, tit. 67, part VII. 
Chapter 26 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Powers of mayor and city council with respect to streets and sidewalks, § 2-9(u). 
Cross reference— Curbside pick-up of solid waste, § 25-125 et seq.; traffic, Ch. 28; utilities, Ch. 29; classification of streets, App. A, § 63; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference— Neglect of streets, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-306; authority of city to construct, open, extend and close public streets, alleys and sidewalks, § 69-312; street improvements, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-401 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks. 
No person shall place in any street or alley or upon any sidewalk of the city, any boxes, casks, goods, wares or merchandise or other obstruction of any kind, or use any hand vehicle on any sidewalk so as to prevent the free and safe passage of persons. 
(Code 1967, § 20-2) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to control obstructions upon or adjacent to streets, § 2-9(v). 
State Law reference— Without express legislative authority, a municipality may not grant to any person the right to erect or maintain a structure or obstruction in a public street, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-304. 
Sec. 26-2. - Removal of obstructions. 
The mayor is hereby given full authority to order the removal of any and all obstructions on the streets and sidewalks of the city, including telephone and light posts, filling stations, trees, awnings and their supports and any other obstructions which are now or in the future may be in the way of, or may hinder, the proper paving and improving of the streets and sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 20-1) 
Sec. 26-3. - Permits for street cuts; fees; inspections. 
(a)  Permits. The building official shall issue permits, to cover cost of repairing streets and alleys, to a person where said person finds it necessary to dig holes, ditches or other excavations in order to place pipe lines, sewer lines, water lines, electric, telegraph or telephone wires under or across any street or alley within the city limits. The amount of the permit shall depend upon the cost of repairing a street or alley to its former condition, immediate to the time of issuing the permit. 
(b)  Fees. No permit shall be issued for less than three dollars ($3.00). Permit fees shall be based on costs of repair, and fees shall be twenty (20) percent of such costs. 
The building official shall see that all fees are paid for permits and paid over to the city. He shall keep a record of all transactions of his office and shall be provided with proper blank applications for the convenient listing of information regarding the work for which the permit is being issued. 
(c)  Inspections. The building official shall make inspection on jobs for which he has issued permits, from time to time, and shall see that, at the completion of the work, conditions are the same as before work started. 
All payments for such inspections shall be made before the building official shall give a certificate of inspection to the person having the permit for such work. 
(Code 1967, § 20-3) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
Secs. 26-4—26-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET PAVING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to construct and improve streets and sidewalks, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-312. 

Sec. 26-20. - Additions, etc., on streets and roads; regulation; application. 
(a)  All additions, detractions, alterations, installations, construction, repairs, renewals, removals and any other acts of maintenance to, in, along, over or under any street, road or highway belonging to the city shall be done in a manner so as to comply with the regulations of such activity, which said regulations are set up by the state department of transportation under the authority given said department by Ga. Code Ann., § 95A-205. 
(b)  Subsection (a) hereof shall apply to all public, private or cooperative operations, activities and equipment including publicly-owned fire and police signals and street lighting systems, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 20-5) 
Sec. 26-21. - Curbs and gutters prerequisite to paving. 
(a)  Policy declared. It shall be the policy of the council, whether by petition or otherwise, that no streets that have not been paved will be paved in the city until they have been curbed and guttered and an assessment made against the property owners for the cost of same; old streets which have been paved in the past will not be repaved until they have been curbed and guttered. 
(b)  Payment. The property owners, when assessed upon completion of such curb and guttering, shall pay cash, and in cases where the owners of the property do not deem it advisable to pay cash for the curb and gutters they will have a privilege after the assessment is made of paying the assessment in twelve (12) monthly installments, as part of the utility bill, at the maximum lawful rate of interest. 
(Code 1967, § 20-4) 
State Law reference— Maximum lawful rate of interest, Ga. Code Ann., § 57-101. 
Sec. 26-22. - Street improvements—Resolution. 
Whenever it shall be necessary to open, lay out, widen, grade, straighten, vacate, close, abolish, curb, pave, drain, alter, pave and renew paving and improve the public streets, alleys and lanes and sidewalks, of the city, and to put down, repair and renew curbing, side grades, cross drains, crossings and other improvements thereon; and to charge, assess and collect expense thereof for paving curb and guttering and improving the streets, alleys and sidewalks and repaving same in said city, the mayor and council shall pass a resolution naming the streets wherein the paving, curb and guttering, resurfacing, straightening and draining are to take place and the cost of same. The property owners fronting on the streets shall receive a copy of such resolution. 
(Code 1967, § 20-21) 
Sec. 26-23. - Same—Notice. 
The notice of the resolution shall be served personally or by certified mail on all of the city owners, at their last known address, by the chief of police, and show cause on a date and hour certain, before the mayor and council why they should not be assessed per linear foot for the curb, gutters and paving. 
(Code 1967, § 20-22) 
Sec. 26-24. - Same—Assessment of costs. 
The resolution and notice given thereof as provided and no objections having been made by the property owners affected, before the city council on the date and hour set for the hearing, an assessment for the cost of the curbs, gutters, paving and repairing shall be made by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 20-23) 
Sec. 26-25. - Petition for paving; contents; fee; presentation to council. 
(a)  Any citizen who shall own real property in the city, who may want the street in front of his property paved, shall first file with the city clerk a written petition. The petition shall state: 
(1)  The name and address of all of the real property owners of the street to be paved; 
(2)  The name of the street; 
(3)  The width and length; 
(4)  The total number of feet owned by each property owner fronting the street to be paved; and 
(5)  That all (one hundred (100) percent) of the real property owners who front on the street are willing to share in the cost of paving. 
(b)  When the petition is filed with the city clerk, it shall be accompanied by a minimum deposit of one dollar ($1.00) per front foot of the length of the street to be paved and a rough drawing of the street. The petition must contain a statement that the real property owners will pay two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the cost of paving. The city clerk shall present the petition to the city council at its next meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 20-15) 
Sec. 26-26. - Payment of one-third of cost by city. 
(a)  The city council, by this article, is authorized to pay one-third ( 1/3 ) of the street-paving cost, from the general funds of the city, provided: 
(1)  The petition is in order, the deposit is made with the city clerk and the other conditions of the petition are met. 
(2)  The petition must be approved by the head of the utilities department and have his written approval. 
(3)  The petition must be approved by the head of the street department and have his written approval, that it is advisable and feasible. 
(4)  The city has on hand funds or funds are available for such purpose. 
(b)  The city council, if satisfied that all provisions of this section have been complied with, may authorize the paving and payment of one-third ( 1/3 ) of the cost. 
(Code 1967, § 20-16) 
Sec. 26-27. - Bids; approval; expenses; contracts. 
(a)  When petitions are approved by the city council for the paving of streets as provided in section 26-25, the city clerk shall secure bids from paving contractors and notify the council and all of the real property owners of the cost of paving. All bids received by the city clerk shall be passed upon by the city council. All of the real property owners as set out in the petition shall agree to the cost of paving. 
(b)  All expenses of securing bids for paving, easements, attorney fees in drawing contracts and examining titles shall be paid by the petitioners. 
(c)  All contracts shall have the approval of the head of the utilities department and the head of the street department, and all contracts shall be satisfactory to the city attorney, in form and substance. 
(Code 1967, § 20-17) 
Sec. 26-28. - Contractor's bond. 
(a)  All contractors who are awarded contracts shall be required to give bond in double the amount of the bid with two (2) good and solvent securities or to furnish a corporate bond in the amount of bid for the faithful performance of the contract and to indemnify the city for any damages occasioned by a failure to perform the paving contract. 
(b)  The bond shall provide for the use of the city and of all persons doing work for or furnishing skill, tools, machinery or materials under or for the purpose of such contract, conditioned for the completion of the contract in accordance with its terms, for saving the city free from all costs and charges, that may accrue on account of the doing of the work, specified for the payments as they become due, of all just claims for work, tools, machinery, skill and materials furnished by persons under or for the purpose of such contracts. 
(c)  The bond shall provide for the use of the city, that the contractors shall indemnify said city against all damages, injury and loss to which said city may be subjected by reason of any wrongdoing, misconduct, want of care and skill, negligence of said principal, his agents and employees in and about the execution of said contract. 
(Code 1967, § 20-18) 
State Law reference— Bond for public contractors, Ga. Code Ann., § 23-1705 et seq. 
Sec. 26-29. - Deposit of additional funds. 
Upon final approval, by the property owners and the mayor and council, of the cost of paving of the street set out in the petition, the property owners shall deposit any additional funds that may be needed to meet their share of paving with the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 20-19) 
Sec. 26-30. - Completion notice. 
The contractor, when the work is completed, shall notify the head of the street department, who shall make an inspection of the work and upon his written approval and acceptance, the clerk is authorized to pay the contractor the amount set out in the contract. 
(Code 1967, § 20-20) 
Secs. 26-31—26-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET NUMBERING 

Sec. 26-47. - Property owners to number improvements. 
All property owners within the city limits shall be responsible and required to place numbers on their improvements on their property which correspond with the street numbering system in the city. For example, the owner of the house at 512 Giddens Avenue shall be responsible for placing the number 512 on the front of the house in a prominent place so that it can be seen from the street. 
(Ord. No. 3-77, 5-9-77) 
Sec. 26-48. - Height, color of numbers; supplied by city. 
The numbers required by this article shall be a minimum of two (2) inches in height and shall be in contrast in color with the rest of the building. The numbers will be made available to the residents of the city at no charge and can be picked up at the city engineer's office or at the city hall. 
(Ord. No. 3-77, 7-25-77) 
Sec. 26-49. - Duty of meter reader. 
The meter reader shall have the responsibility of checking each building in Nashville to ascertain whether or not the numbers have been placed on the buildings. If they have not, then he shall report this to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3-77, 5-9-77) 
Sec. 26-50. - Notice of violation. 
When any house, trailer, commercial building or any other type of improvement in the city limits does not have a number prominently displayed, the owner will be notified by the city clerk in writing that he has thirty (30) days to comply with this article after which time he will be in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3-77, 7-25-77) 
Secs. 26-51—26-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PREVENTION OF DAMAGE IN EXCAVATIONS AND DEMOLITION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference— Blasting or excavating near underground gas pipes, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1301 et seq. 

Sec. 26-67. - Short title. 
This article may be cited as the "Underground Utility Damage Prevention Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 1, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-68. - Definitions. 
As used in this article: 
Damage includes the substantial weakening of structural or lateral support of an underground utility, penetration or destruction of any protective coating, housing or other protective device of an underground utility and the partial or complete severance of an underground utility. 
Demolish or demolition means any operation by which a structure or mass of material is wrecked, razed, rendered, moved or removed by means of any tools, equipment or discharge of explosives. 
Excavate or excavation means an operation for the purpose of the movement or removal of earth, rock or other materials in or on the ground by use of mechanized equipment or by discharge of explosives, and including augering, backfilling, digging, ditching, drilling, grading, plowing-in, pulling-in, ripping, scraping, trenching and tunneling, but not including the tilling of soil for agricultural purposes. 
Mechanized equipment means equipment operated by means of mechanical power including trenchers, bulldozers, power shovels, augers, back hoes, scrapers, drills, cable and pipe plows and other equipment used for plowing-in or pulling-in cable or pipe. 
Operator means any person who owns or operates a utility. 
Person means any individual, any corporation, partnership, association or any other entity organized under the laws of any state; any subdivision or instrumentality of a state; and any employee, agent or legal representative thereof. 
Utility means any line, system or facility used for producing, storing, conveying, transmitting or distributing communication, electricity, gas, petroleum, petroleum products, hazardous liquids, water, steam or sewage. 
Working day means every day except Saturday, Sunday and national and legal holidays. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 2, 9-12-77) 
State Law reference— Public and legal holidays designated, Ga. Code Ann., § 14-1809. 
Sec. 26-69. - Filing requirements of utility operators. 
(a)  Within ninety (90) days after the effective date of all other sections of this article, each operator having underground utilities in the city shall file with the city clerk a list containing the name of every section within the city in which it has underground utilities (including those utilities that have been abandoned in place by the operator but not yet physically removed), the name of the operator and the name, title, address and telephone number of its representative designated to receive the written or telephone notice of intent required by section 26-72. 
(b)  Changes in any of the information contained in the list filed under subsection (a) hereof shall be filed by the operator with the city clerk within five (5) working days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 5, 9-12-77) 
State Law reference— Gas companies to file certain information, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1303. 
Sec. 26-70. - Duty to locate underground utilities. 
Except as provided in section 26-76, no person may excavate in a street, highway, public place, a private easement of an operator or near the location of a utility installed on the premises of a customer served by such utility, or demolish a building, without having first ascertained in the manner prescribed in sections 26-72 and 26-75 the location of all underground utilities in the area that would be affected by the proposed excavation or demolition. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 4, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-71. - Excavation or demolition damage. 
(a)  Except as provided by subsection (b) hereof, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 26-70 that results in any damage to an underground utility shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator of such utility of the location and nature of the damage and shall allow the operator reasonable time to accomplish necessary repairs before completing the excavation or demolition in the immediate area of such utility. 
(b)  Each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 26-70 that results in damage to an underground utility permitting the escape of any flammable, toxic or corrosive gas or liquid shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator, police and fire departments, and take any other action as may be reasonably necessary, to protect persons and property and to minimize the hazards until arrival of the operator's personnel or police and fire departments. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 11, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-72. - Notice of intent to excavate or demolish. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 26-76, before commencing any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 26-70, each person responsible for such excavation or demolition shall serve written or telephonic notice of intent to excavate or demolish at least three (3), but not more than ten (10), full working days: 
(1)  On each operator which has filed a list required by section 26-69 indicating that it has underground utilities located in the proposed area of excavation or demolition; or 
(2)  If the proposed area of excavation or demolition is served by an association provided for in section 26-74, on such association and on each operator which has filed a list required by section 26-69 indicating that it has underground utilities in the proposed area of excavation or demolition that is not receiving the services of the association; provided, 
where demolition of a building is proposed, operators shall be given reasonable time to remove or protect their utilities before demolition of the building is commenced. 
(b)  The written or telephonic notice required by subsection (a) hereof must contain the name, address and telephone number of the person filing the notice of intent, and, if different, the person responsible for the excavation or demolition, the starting date, anticipated duration and type of excavation or demolition operation to be conducted, the location of the proposed excavation or demolition and whether or not explosives are to be used. 
(c)  If the notification required by this section is made by telephone, an adequate record of such notification shall be maintained by the operators and associations notified to document compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 6, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-73. - Precautions to avoid damage. 
In addition to the notification requirements of section 26-72, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 26-70 shall: 
(1)  Plan the excavation or demolition to avoid damage to or minimize interference with underground utilities in and near the construction area; 
(2)  Maintain a clearance between an underground utility and the cutting edge or point of any mechanized equipment, taking into account the known limit of control of such cutting edge or point, as may be reasonably necessary to avoid damage to such utilities; and 
(3)  Provide such support for underground utilities in and near the construction area, including during backfill operations, as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of such utilities. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 10, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-74. - Operator associations. 
Operators may form and operate an association providing for mutual receipt of section 26-72 notifications of excavation or demolition operations in a defined geographical area. An association that provides such service on behalf of operators having underground utilities within the city shall file with the city clerk the telephone number and address of the association, a description of the geographical area served by the association and a list of the names and addresses of each operator receiving such service from the association. 
Sec. 26-75. - Response to notice of intent to excavate or demolish. 
Each operator or designated representative (including an association established in accordance with section 26-74) notified in accordance with section 26-72 shall, not less than two (2) working days in advance of the proposed excavation or demolition (unless a shorter period is provided by agreement between the person responsible for the excavation or demolition and the operator or designated representative), supply, by use of maps when appropriate, the following information to the person responsible for the excavation or demolition: 
(1)  The approximate location and description of all of its underground utilities which may be damaged as a result of the excavation or demolition; 
(2)  The location and description of all utility markers indicating the approximate location of the underground utilities; and 
(3)  Any other information that would assist that person in locating and thereby avoiding damage to the underground utilities including providing adequate temporary markings indicating the approximate location of the underground utility in locations where permanent utility markers do not exist. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 8, 9-12-77) 
Sec. 26-76. - Emergency excavation or demolition. 
Compliance with the notice requirements of section 26-72 is not required of persons responsible for emergency excavation or demolition to decrease an imminent danger to life, health or property, provided, however, that such persons give, as soon as practicable, oral notice of the emergency excavation or demolition to each operator having underground utilities located in the area (or to an association provided for in section 26-74, that serves as operator) where such excavation or demolition is to be performed and requests emergency assistance from each operator so identified in locating and providing immediate protection to its underground utilities. An imminent danger to life, health or property exists whenever there is a substantial likelihood that loss of life, health or property will result before the procedures under sections 26-72 and 26-75 can be fully complied with. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 9, 9-12-77) 
State Law reference— Blasting or excavating in event of emergency, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1309. 
Sec. 26-77. - Permits. 
A permit issued pursuant to law, authorizing excavation or demolition operations, shall not be deemed to relieve a person from the responsibility for complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 8-77, § 3, 9-12-77) 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to provide for the issuance of permits, § 2-9(s). 
State Law reference— Duties of persons engaged in blasting or excavating, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1305. 
Chapter 27 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to levy taxes and to contract for services in connection therewith, § 2-9(n); finance and taxation generally, § 7-1 et seq. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; alcoholic beverage taxes, § 3-50 et seq.; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference— Taxing power restricted, Ga. Code Ann., § 2-6103; sales for municipal taxes, redemption of property sold, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 92-44; exemption of personalty from ad valorem tax, § 92-239. 

Sec. 27-1. - Interest on unpaid taxes. 
Unpaid city taxes shall bear interest at the maximum lawful rate after January 20th of each year, and the delinquent taxpayer shall also pay fi fa costs. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74) 
Charter reference— Authority of city to add interest to taxes not paid when due, § 7-3. 
Sec. 27-2. - Report of sale of real estate. 
Every person selling real estate owned by such person shall, within thirty (30) days from the date of such sale, report such sale, giving a description of the property, where located, the sale price and the name of the purchaser, to the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 21-2) 
Chapter 28 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to regulate and control public ways, § 2-9(v). 
Cross reference— Use of city vehicles, § 2-45; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Georgia Rules of the Road adopted. 
Pursuant to Georgia Code, Title 68A, Section 68A-1503 through Section 68A-1507, the entire Title 68A of the Georgia Code, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, is hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. 
Sec. 28-2. - Authority of police and firemen. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Officers of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter; provided that, in the event of fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic, as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 15-2) 
Cross reference— Fire department, § 10-21 et seq.; police department, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 28-3. - Obedience to officers directing traffic. 
All persons are required to observe the directions of all authorized officers when engaged in directing traffic within the city. This includes county officers and also includes authorized air raid wardens and civil defense workers in time of emergency. 
(Code of 1967, § 15-3) 
Cross reference— Civil defense, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 28-4. - Obedience to signs; devices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to obey or to disregard any stop sign, traffic light or parking sign as follows: 
(1)  To fail to stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  To cross an intersection when the light is red. 
(3)  To park where a parking sign has printed thereon "no parking." 
(4)  To remain parked for a longer period of time than indicated by the parking sign. 
(Code 1967, § 15-4) 
Sec. 28-5. - Unregistered vehicles prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to occupy the driver's seat of any vehicle which is not properly registered under the laws of the state or not otherwise entitled to be operated in the state. 
(Code 1967, § 15-8) 
Sec. 28-6. - Noisy vehicles. 
No cutouts shall be allowed upon the street while motor vehicles are in use upon said streets. Unusual and unnecessary noises made by motor vehicles shall not be permitted, and neither may unusual and unnecessary blowing of automobile horns be permitted. 
(Code 1967, § 15-17) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 68-1716, 68-1717. 
Sec. 28-7. - Application of chapter to bicycles. 
Every person riding a bicycle shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter, except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1967, § 15-6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-1202. 
Sec. 28-8. - Persons propelling pushcarts or riding animals to obey traffic regulations. 
Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the operator of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter with reference to the equipment of vehicles and except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1967, § 15-5) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-105; authority of city to regulate persons propelling pushcarts, § 68A-1502(a)(17). 
Sec. 28-9. - Responsibility of parents, guardians, employers; duty of police. 
Any parent, guardian or other person, or employer who has charge of or control over, either or both, any child or employee under the age of seventeen (17) years, and who knowingly and willfully allows such child or employee to operate any motor vehicle, including bicycles, motorcycles and motor scooters, propelled by motor power over and upon the streets and public places within the city contrary to the ordinances and laws of the city with regard to the operation of motor vehicles upon the public streets and public places of the city and with regard to the restrictions thereof and the regulations thereof by city ordinances and laws, shall be guilty of a violation of such ordinance and law. 
(Code 1967, § 15-7) 
State Law reference— Juvenile courts, Ga. Code Ann., Title 24A. 
Sec. 28-10. - Passengers. 
No person shall be allowed to drive a passenger automobile or motor vehicle upon the streets of the city when the same contains more passengers than can be seated upon the regular seats originally provided and constructed therein by the manufacturer. In buses, taxicabs and other public conveyances operated by motor, not more than two (2) passengers shall be allowed to occupy the front seat with the driver, and all other passengers carried therein must be seated while the same is in operation. 
(Code 1967, § 15-10) 
Sec. 28-11. - Projecting loads. 
No passenger-type vehicle shall be operated on any highway with any load carried thereon extending more than six (6) inches beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of such vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 15-14) 
Sec. 28-12. - Spilling loads, etc. 
No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from dropping, shifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom. 
(Code 1967, § 15-13) 
Sec. 28-13. - Boarding or alighting from moving vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1967, § 15-11) 
Sec. 28-14. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person traveling upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle to cling to or attach himself or his vehicle to any other moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1967, § 15-12) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate persons upon skates, coasters, sleds and other toy vehicles, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-1502(a)(18). 
Sec. 28-15. - Pedestrians crossing streets; right-of-way over certain vehicles. 
Pedestrians shall cross the streets of the city wherever possible only at intersections. They shall cross only at right angles. Pedestrians crossing streets in marked and designated crosswalks shall at all times have the right-of-way over vehicles making turns into the streets being crossed by the pedestrians. 
(Code 1967, § 15-16) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 68A-502, 68A-503. 
Sec. 28-16. - Pedestrians interfering with traffic. 
Pedestrians shall not carelessly or maliciously interfere with the proper use of the public streets. 
(Code 1967, § 15-15) 
Sec. 28-17. - Search of vehicles of persons arrested. 
All officers of the city shall impound all automobiles and all other types of motor vehicles, public or private, occupied by, driven by or in the custody of any person violating any municipal ordinance or state statute, shall remove the defendant therefrom and shall cause a complete inventory and search of said vehicle to be made at the city hall, or at such other place as shall be convenient to such officer. Said officers shall make a complete inventory of all articles and items therein contained for storage and safekeeping, shall file the original thereof with the city clerk and shall deliver to the defendant from each motor vehicle searched a copy of such inventory of said motor vehicle seized. 
(Ord. of 5-8-72, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 28-18. - City council support for speed detection devices. 
The city council fully supports enforcement of speed laws and encourages the use, by trained police personnel, of speed detection devices to apprehend those motorists who disobey the laws in disregard for safety. 
(Res. No. 1-79, 2-1-79) 
Editor's note— Res. of Feb. 1, 1979, being not expressly amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 28-18 in the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 28-19—28-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to prevent the blocking of public ways, § 2-9(v). 
Cross reference— Off-street automobile parking and storage, App. A, § 65; off-street loading and unloading, App. A, § 66. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-1502(a)(1). 

Sec. 28-34. - Vehicles interfering with traffic. 
No vehicle shall so occupy any street or part thereof as to unreasonably interfere with or interrupt the free passage of other cars or vehicles or persons. 
(Code 1967, § 15-47) 
Sec. 28-35. - Stop lines at traffic lights. 
A stop line shall be painted at all traffic lights to enable large vehicles to make a proper turn. No driver shall stop a vehicle beyond such line. 
(Mo. of 3-25-74) 
Sec. 28-36. - Parking spaces. 
Every vehicle parked in an area where parking spaces have been designated or marked off shall be parked entirely within a single such space. 
(Code 1967, § 15-30) 
Sec. 28-37. - Parking prohibited at certain places. 
No person shall stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or with the provisions of this chapter or in compliance with the directions of a traffic officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within ten (10) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within ten (10) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of roadway. 
(8)  Within twenty (20) feet of a driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance when properly signposted. 
(9)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(10)  Alongside any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge of a street. 
(11)  At any place where signs prohibit stopping. 
(12)  Upon any street, other than an alley, leaving less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except that an operator may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or material. 
(Code 1967, § 15-31) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-1003. 
Sec. 28-38. - Parking in alleys. 
No driver, operator or person having charge of any motor vehicle shall park the same in or along any alley in the city except for such time as may be necessary for the purpose of immediately taking on or discharging passengers or freight. 
(Code 1967, § 15-33) 
Sec. 28-39. - Parking on private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on private property or in a private parking lot, private throughway, private road or private driveway where a sign is posted prohibiting such parking in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the passageway through these private parking lots. 
(Ord. No. 4-77, 8-15-77) 
Sec. 28-40. - Standing in street or alley for purpose of repairs. 
No vehicle shall be left in any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground in such a manner as to obstruct the free use of the same for the purpose of being repaired, or for any other purpose except in case of unavoidable necessity, when the same shall be removed within a reasonable time. 
(Code 1967, § 15-35) 
Sec. 28-41. - Parking vehicle for sale. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park upon a street any vehicle displayed for sale. 
(Code 1967, § 15-34) 
Sec. 28-42. - Parking regulations at specific locations. 
The mayor and chief of police may from time to time regulate, restrict or prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles on specified streets or portions of streets or in specified areas. When signs or markings are in place giving notice of such regulations, restrictions and prohibitions, it shall be unlawful to violate or fail to comply with such signs or markings. 
(Code 1967, § 15-32) 
Sec. 28-43. - No parking areas. 
Parking at any time is prohibited in the following areas: 

 
(Code 1967, § 15-36; Ord. of 10-12-70, § 3; Ord. of 2-12-96; Ord. of 7-8-96) 
Sec. 28-44. - Parking on courthouse square and side streets. 
(a)  The following plan is adopted and shall be implemented as soon as possible: 
(1)  East Avenue, one-way west—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of avenue. 
(2)  West Avenue, one-way west—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of avenue. 
(3)  North Avenue, one-way north—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of avenue. 
(4)  South Avenue, one-way south—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of avenue. 
(5)  West Washington Avenue, two-way traffic—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of street. 
(6)  East Washington Avenue, two-way traffic—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of street. 
(7)  South Jefferson Street, two-way traffic—cut back sidewalks and parking on both sides of street. 
(b)  All parking on the square and for one (1) block off the square shall be limited to two (2) hour parking only, except for the two (2) hour parking limit around the inside square at the county courthouse; this parking area shall be used for courthouse business parking. 
(Ord. of 7-9-73) 
Sec. 28-45. - Abandonment of motor vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or to leave unattended for a period in excess of ten (10) days any motor vehicle on any street. 
Sec. 28-46. - Travel and parking of all trucks, truck trailer combinations and refrigerated trucks. 
(a)  [Unlawful.] 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for all trucks or trailer combinations having more than six (6) wheels [to travel] on the city streets except on the following highways and streets: 
U.S. Highway 129 (Davis Street), Georgia Highway 125 (Tifton Highway), Georgia Highway 76 (Marion Avenue and Adel Road), Spells Street, Georgia Highway 168 (East McPherson Avenue), East Smith Avenue to Old North Coffee Road, Avera Mill Road, Marie McGill Road, Old North Coffee Road south to North Mathis Street, North Mathis to Marion Avenue, East Dennis to South Davis Street, Industrial Blvd., Langdale Drive, Hull Avenue, Enigma Road, Watson Street, Middle School Circle, West Washington to Dogwood Drive, Dogwood Drive, Cecil Road, Exum Street, County Farm, Anderson Road, Hazel Avenue and Old Milltown Road. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for refrigerated trucks, regardless of number of wheels, to be parked in any residential area except for loading and unloading of goods. 
(b)  [Regulations.] 
(1)  Trucks, as herein defined, may use any street or alley for the purpose of picking up or unloading goods. 
(2)  Trucks can be driven to and from residences by the shortest or least congested routes as determined by the Nashville Police Department. A permit, to be renewed annually, will be issued to authorize the driver to operate only on the designated route. Only persons named in the permit may operate the truck on the designated route. Cost of the annual permit is fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. An operator who has a current City of Nashville business license must obtain the above permit but will not be required to pay the fifty-dollar permit fee. 
(3)  Trucks must be parked at least five (5) feet from the surface of any street. 
(4)  Trucks will not be parked in such a manner as to block the vision of drivers of other vehicles at any intersection. 
(5)  Trucks will not be parked immediately in front of another citizen's residence. 
(6)  Trucks shall not be operated in a residential area between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. 
(7)  Truck repairs and servicing must not create a disturbance in the neighborhood. This includes the revving-up of engines or other noises that disrupt a normally quiet neighborhood. Noxious odors will not be allowed. 
(8)  Violations of this section will result in permanent revocation of the permit. This includes any act that may create a disturbance in a residential area. 
(c)  [Signs.] Signs indicating restrictions on trucks shall be permanently placed in areas where restrictions apply. 
(d)  [Violations.] Persons violating this section shall be cited by the Nashville Police Department to the city court and shall be fined not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation plus court cost. 
(Ord. of 7-14-03) 
Secs. 28-47—28-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-62. - Right-of-way at unmarked intersections. 
The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection not controlled by stop or yield signs or traffic-control signals shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from a different street. 
(Code 1967, § 15-59) 
Sec. 28-63. - Through streets, stop intersections and limited or restricted traffic areas. 
(a)  The mayor and the chief of police may from time to time designate through streets and stop intersections. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop at the entrance to a through highway and shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection from said through highway or which are approaching so closely on said through highway as to constitute an immediate hazard, but said driver having so yielded may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection on said through highway shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle so proceeding into or across the through highway. 
(c)  The chief of police, upon approval of the mayor and council, is authorized to establish and designate certain long-term, temporary, seasonal, or permanent, limited or restricted traffic areas such as reduced or no through traffic, no turn(s) at certain times, or other traffic control measures to facilitate safe and improved traffic flow during peak school or business traffic hours, or other unsafe traffic conditions requiring alteration of previously established traffic routes. 
(1)  All traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings shall conform to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the state transportation board. All signs and signals required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this Code shall be official traffic control devices of the city. 
(2)  Any violation of any traffic zone, marking, sign or other traffic control device established hereunder shall be a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 15-57; Ord. of 11-9-09) 
Sec. 28-64. - Yield intersections. 
The mayor and the chief of police may from time to time designate "yield right-of-way" intersections. 
(Code 1967, § 15-56) 
Sec. 28-65. - No-passing zones. 
(a)  Passing prohibited. No vehicle shall at any time be driven to the left side or the right side of any vehicle overtaken on any street designated as a "no-passing zone street". 
(b)  Marking. The no-passing zone street shall be marked by a solid barrier line, placed at the right-hand element of a combination strip along the center or lane line; the barrier line shall be yellow. 
(c)  Areas designated. North Davis Street, from Marion Street to the north city limits, is hereby designated as a "no-passing zone street". 
(Code 1967, § 15-66) 
Sec. 28-66. - General duty to drive carefully. 
It shall be the duty of such operator to have his vehicle in full and complete and immediate control, and to keep and maintain a constant watch for other vehicles, and for pedestrians, and exercise all reasonable precautions to prevent collision and injury. 
(Code 1967, § 15-55) 
Sec. 28-67. - Speed limits—Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon, on or along any of the public or private, local or state routes of the city at a faster rate of speed than that established under the attached list of roadways for the city prepared by the Georgia Department of Transportation and identified as List Number 0220174690 consisting of four (4) pages classifying and identifying on-system and off-system roads within the corporate limits of the city and specifying the applicable speed limits as set forth therein is hereby adopted and approved by the mayor and council for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 15-53; Ord. No. O-01-17, 4-10-17) 
Editor's note— List Number 0220174690 hereinabove referenced is attached to Ord. No. O-01-17, incorporated by reference, and on file with the city. 
Sec. 28-68. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. O-01-17, adopted Apr. 10, 2017, deleted § 28-68 which pertained to speed limits on state routes, and derived from ordinances adopted Aug. 27, 1973; Oct. 29, 1973; Res. No. 1-79, adopted Feb. 1, 1979; and Ord. No. 81-2, adopted Mar. 9, 1981. 
Sec. 28-69. - Speed limits—Where posted. 
In addition to the areas designated in this article, when appropriate signs are posted giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful to exceed the posted speed limits. 
(Code 1967, § 15-54) 
State Law reference— Municipal alteration of speed limits, Ga. Code Ann., § 68A-804. 
Sec. 28-70. - Drag racing. 
It shall be unlawful for any person by himself, herself or in a contest with another to engage in dragging, in drag racing, in a drag race or to meet, assemble or be at any point or place within this city for the purpose of engaging in dragging, drag racing or in a drag race, or for aiding, abetting or for taking any part in dragging, or a drag race, or for the purpose of witnessing, as a spectator, any dragging, drag racing or drag race, or for remaining at any place, as a participant or as a witness thereto, after to would or should appear to an ordinary person from an ordinary inquiry in the exercise of ordinary care and inquiry that dragging, or drag racing, or a drag race was taking place, or was about to take place. 
(Code 1967, § 15-60) 
Sec. 28-71. - Driving while drinking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink beer, wine or intoxicating liquors and operate an automobile, truck or any other vehicle upon the public streets, sidewalks or alleys in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-6) 
Charter reference— Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 28-72. - Towing. 
No vehicle shall tow more than one (1) other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed sixteen (16) feet in length. 
(Code 1967, § 15-63) 
Sec. 28-73. - Driving through processions. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession which they are in motion, provided that such vehicles are conspicuously designated. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or a police officer. 
(Code 1967, § 15-61) 
Sec. 28-74. - U-turns. 
It shall be unlawful for any kind of vehicle to make a U-turn between the intersection of Marion and Davis Streets and the intersection of Davis and Washington Streets. 
(Code 1967, § 15-50) 
Sec. 28-75. - Slow-moving vehicles. 
Slow-moving vehicles shall at all times be operated as close to the right-hand side of the street as practicable. 
(Code 1967, § 15-49) 
Sec. 28-76. - Maximum speed limits. 
(a)  Enigma Road, from the northwest city limits boundary to a point one thousand (1,000) feet northwest of the intersection with SR 125, shall be zoned forty-five (45) miles per hour. From a point one thousand (1,000) feet northwest of the intersection of Enigma Road and SR 125 shall be zoned thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(b)  The maximum speed limit on all other local streets, lanes, alleys and roadways in the city, not before specifically set out, shall be thirty (30) miles per hour. Speed detection devices shall not be operated on these streets. 
(Res. No. 1-79, 2-1-79; Ord. No. 81-2, 3-9-81; Ord. of 10-26-81) 
Sec. 28-76.1. - Operation of motorized wheelchairs and other individual transportation devices by physically disabled persons on public roadways and park trails. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the administration and enforcement of this section. 
Motorized individual transportation devices shall mean those special vehicles limited to persons who require assistance because of physical infirmity in their personal transportation with such devices being limited to the capacity of carrying or transporting a single individual. 
Operate shall mean to ride in, or on, and control the operation of a motorized wheelchair or other motorized individual transportation device. 
Physically disabled shall mean any person who, because of physical disability: 
(1)  Cannot walk without substantial risk of falling; 
(2)  Cannot walk two hundred (200) feet without stopping to rest; 
(3)  Cannot walk without the aid of another person, walker, cane, crutches, braces, prosthetic devices, and/or wheelchair; 
(4)  Is restricted by respiratory disease to an extent that the person's forced (respiratory) expiratory volume for one (1) second when measured by Spirometry is less than one (1) liter; 
(5)  Has an arterial oxygen tension (PAO2) of less than sixty (60) mm/hg; 
(6)  Uses portable oxygen; 
(7)  Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are verified by their personal physician as requiring assistance for transportation purposes; 
(8)  Has lost an arm or a leg and does not have or cannot use an artificial limb; 
(9)  Has a disability that would be aggravated by walking two hundred (200) feet or more under normal environmental conditions as verified by their personal physician. 
Right-of-way shall mean any street, avenue, place, drive or other public drive in the city. 
(b)  Operation on public property. 
(1)  No person shall operate a motorized wheelchair or motorized individual transportation device within the public right-of-way of any state or county highway, state aid or city street within the City of Nashville except as hereinafter provided under this section. On right-of-way designated for city streets, motorized wheelchairs or motorized individual transportation devices shall be permitted only on the shoulder of the roadway or, in the absence of an improved shoulder, on the right-most portion of the roadway and in the same direction as the street traffic on the nearest lane of the roadway adjacent thereto. No person shall operate a motorized wheelchair or motorized individual transportation device within the public right-of-way of any state of county highway, state aid or city street between the hours of one-half (½) hour after sunset and one-half (½) hour before sunrise. 
(2)  All such persons operating motorized wheelchairs or motorized individual transportation devices shall display the slow-moving vehicle emblem thereon as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-4. 
(3)  The operation of motorized wheelchairs or motorized individual transportation devices for all persons who are physically disabled shall be allowed on the park and public trails existing within the city. The operation of police, fire and emergency vehicles and public works vehicles shall be allowed in the park and public trail systems of the city. Except as otherwise provided herein no motorized vehicles shall be allowed on the public trail systems of the city. No motor vehicles except as provided herein shall be allowed in the city parks of the city except on established and paved parking surfaces posted for that purpose. 
(4)  No person shall operate a motorized wheelchair or an individual transportation device to push, pull, tow or attach anything, including, but not limited to, an additional individual transportation device, a vehicle, bicycle, cart, wagon or a person on a skateboard, roller skates, scooter, coaster, sled or any similar object. 
(5)  No person shall operate a motorized wheelchair or an individual transportation device in a manner contrary to or inconsistent with its design and intended purpose which is to carry or transport a single individual person. 
(Ord. of 5-11-09; Ord. No. O-06-18, 1-14-19) 
DIVISION 2. - MOTORIZED CARTS 

Sec. 28-77. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Motorized carts means electric-powered and gasoline-powered pleasure carts, commonly known as golf carts. These carts have not less than three (3) wheels and cannot be operated typically at more than twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09; Ord. No. O-07-18, 1-14-19) 
Sec. 28-78. - Operations and limitations. 
Motorized carts may be operated within the corporate limits of the city by: 
(1)  Those persons who are sixteen (16) years of age and older and have a valid motor vehicle driver's license. 
(2)  Those persons who are fifteen (15) years of age, but not yet sixteen (16) years of age, if accompanied in the front seat by a person at least eighteen (18) years of age who holds a valid motor vehicle driver's license. 
(3)  No person under the age of fifteen (15) years of age shall be permitted to operate a motorized cart on any public street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(4)  All operators of motorized carts shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic. 
(5)  All child occupants of said motorized carts shall be appropriately restrained in accordance with all traffic regulations applicable to motor vehicles under state law. 
(6)  Motorized carts shall not be operated on sidewalks or in city parks other than in parking areas. 
(7)  Motorized carts shall be operated during daylight hours only from thirty (30) minutes after sunrise until thirty (30) minutes before sunset. 
(8)  Motorized carts shall be equipped with an amber strobe light or LED visible for at least five hundred (500) feet as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-35. 
(9)  Motorized carts may not transverse streets and highways under the jurisdiction of the state department of transportation. Motorized carts may cross these streets to access other streets at designated street intersections as set forth in section 28-82. 
(10)  No person shall operate a motorized cart on any public street within the corporate limits of the city to push, pull, tow or attach anything, including, but not limited to, another motorized cart, individual transportation device, vehicle, bicycle, cart, wagon or a person on a skateboard, roller skates, scooter, coaster, sled or any similar object. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09; Ord. No. O-07-18, 1-14-19) 
Sec. 28-79. - Registration. 
(a)  Before any motorized cart may be operated within the corporate limits of the city, the cart must be registered and receive a decal from the city clerk signifying its registration. A person desiring to register a motorized cart shall bring documentation setting forth a description of said cart to the city clerk's office and complete an application for registration of said cart. Upon registration, the clerk shall issue a decal to be applied to the rear of such cart so as to be plainly visible. There shall be a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for such registration. The decal, issued, shall be nontransferable from the cart for which it is issued. The registration shall be effective until such time as the cart is sold. New owners must register a cart within ten (10) business days within change of ownership at a cost of ten dollars ($10.00). If the registration is not transferred within ten (10) business days, a twenty dollar ($20.00) penalty will be applied in addition to the ten dollar ($10.00) transfer charge. 
(b)  Before any motorized cart may be operated within the corporate limits of the city, the cart must have affixed thereto an emblem as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-4. The emblem shall conform with those standards and specifications adopted for slow-moving vehicles by the American Society of Agricultural Engineers in December 1966, and contained within such society's standard ASAE S276.1, or shall be an emblem of the same shape and size painted on such vehicle in a bright and conspicuous retro-reflective red-orange paint. Such emblem shall be mounted on the rear of such vehicles, in the approximate horizontal geometric center of the vehicle, at a height of three (3) to five (5) feet above the roadway, and shall be maintained at all times in a clean and reflective condition. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09) 
Sec. 28-80. - Liability insurance coverage. 
Each person operating a motorized cart is liable for his own actions. Liability insurance coverage varies and each person operating a motorized cart shall provide proof of coverage upon request. Failure to maintain insurance in accordance with the minimum limits required under O.C.G.A. title 40 shall subject the owner/operator to a fine as set forth under section 28-83. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09) 
Sec. 28-81. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Nothing in this division shall apply to any self-propelled, two-wheeled vehicle. 
(b)  Nothing in this division shall apply to motorized carts operated by the city. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09) 
Sec. 28-82. - Designated crossing. 
Motorized carts which are in compliance with section 29-79 may be operated on any city street within the city which are not within the jurisdiction of the Georgia Department of Transportation and may only cross streets or roads within the state highway system at intersections or crossings designated for that purpose by the department of transportation. The designated crossings will be at the following locations: 
(a)  US 76 at College St./Chism Ave.; 
(b)  US 76 at S. John St.; 
(c)  State Route 125 at Griner St.; 
(d)  State Route 129 at Hull Ave./Hall Dr.; 
(e)  State Route 129 at Avera Ave.; 
(f)  State Route 129 at Dennis Ave.; 
(g)  State Route 168 at S. Anne St./Anderson Rd. 
(Ord. of 2-23-09) 
Sec. 28-83. - Violation; penalty.
