APPENDIX B - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Appendix "B" sets forth the Subdivision Regulations of the City of Nashville as enacted March 22, 1971. The nature of a subdivisions ordinance, the requirements of state law as to the procedures for enactment, amendment, appeals and the like, preclude its physical incorporation as an integral part of the Code; therefore it has been included in the Appendix, as enacted for the information and convenience of the user. 
Unless otherwise indicated by a history note following a particular section, the ordinance is set out as enacted, the article headings and numbers, and section numbers and catchlines having been retained. 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and city council to prescribe regulations for the subdividing or platting of property, § 2-9(jj). 
Cross reference— Buildings, Ch. 5; mobile homes, Ch. 16; planning, Ch. 21; flood hazard areas, § 21-25; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 26; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference— Subdivision regulations generally, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1214 et seq.; injunction to prevent violation, § 69-1219. 

ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE, AUTHORITY, JURISDICTION AND DEFINITIONS 

Section A. - Purpose. 
The public health, safety, and general welfare require the harmonious, orderly, and progressive development of land within the City of Nashville. In furtherance of this objective, these subdivision regulations are adopted for the following purposes, among others: 
1.  To encourage the development of an economically sound and stable community; 
2.  To assure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to new land developments; 
3.  To assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments; 
4.  To assure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in new land developments through the dedication or reservations of land for recreational, educational, and other public purposes; and, 
5.  To assure, in general, the wise development of new areas, in harmony with the comprehensive plan of the community. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1214. 
Section B. - Authority. 
These subdivision regulations are adopted under the authority of the State of Georgia General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 as amended [Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1201 et seq.] 
Section C. - Jurisdiction. 
The subdivision regulations contained herein shall govern all subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the City of Nashville as now or hereafter established. 
Section D. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of these regulations, certain words used herein are defined as follows: 
1.  Subdivision: The division, development, or redivision of a lot, tract, or parcel of land, regardless of how it is to be used[,] into two (2) or more lots, tracts, or parcels of land, either by plat or by metes and bounds description, or the division or redivision of land involving the dedication of a new park, playground, street, or other public right-of-way or facility; or the vacating or closing, realignment, or any other change in existing streets, alleys, easements, recreational areas, water areas, or other public improvement of facilities, and when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the act or process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. 
2.  Lot: A portion of a subdivision intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for development or both. 
3.  Lot width: The distance between side lot lines measured at the building setback line parallel to the street right-of-way line. 
4.  Building setback line: The minimum horizontal distance between the street right-of-way line and the building or any projection thereof except: 
a.  Steps, terraces, and open fire escapes. 
b.  Architectural features such as eaves, cornices, gutters or canopies projecting not more than three (3) feet beyond the main wall of the building. 
5.  Words used in the present tense include the future tense. 
6.  Words used in the singular number include the plural, and words used in the plural number include the singular. 
7.  The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory. 
8.  The word "may" shall be deemed as permissive. 
9.  Subdivider: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other entity, acting as a unit, subdivision, or proposing to subdivide land as herein defined. 
10.  Planning commission: The local planning commission officially designated by the city council for local planning purposes as specified in the General Planning Enabling Legislation of 1957, as amended [Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1201 et seq.]. 
11.  Plat, preliminary: A map of a proposed land subdivision showing the character and proposed layout of the tract in sufficient detail to indicate the suitability of the proposed subdivision of land. 
12.  Plat, final: A map of a land subdivision prepared in a form suitable for filing of record with necessary affidavits, dedications and acceptances, and with complete bearings and dimensions of all lines defining lots and blocks, streets, public areas and other dimensions of land. 
State Law reference— Control of subdivision entrances to state highways, Ga. Code Ann., § 95A-948 et seq. 
ARTICLE II. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Section A. - Streets. 
1.  Right-of-way. The dedication of right-of-way, measured from lot line to lot line, shall be as shown on the thoroughfare plan on page 5 [of the original ordinance], said thoroughfare plan is hereby made a part of these regulations and shall meet the following standards. (See cross sections, page 6 [of the original ordinance]) 

 
2.  Intersection. The centerline of no more than two (2) streets shall intersect at any one point. No street shall intersect another street at less than eighty (80) degrees and shall as nearly as possible intersect at ninety (90) degrees. A tangent no less than one hundred (100) feet shall be placed between a curved street and the nearest right-of-way line of the street which it intersects. 
3.  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred fifty (150) feet shall not be allowed. (See illustration 1, page 8 [of original ordinance]) 
4.  Additional right-of-way. If the subdivision boundary lies adjacent to the right-of-way line of an existing platted street of less than minimum right-of-way width, a minimum of one-half the required additional width shall be dedicated. 
5.  Dead-end streets. Permanent dead-end streets shall be prohibited. 



6.  Cul-de-sacs. Permanent cul-de-sacs shall not be longer than five hundred (500) feet measured from the nearest street right-of-way line with which the centerline of cul-de-sac intersects and shall terminate in a circular turnaround with a radius of no less than fifty (50) feet at the right-of-way line and forty (40) feet at the curb line. 
7.  Access. Every lot within a subdivision shall have adequate access to a public street. The planning commission may control the access from a subdivision to the major streets by requiring all lots to face and have access only to other streets. 
8.  Coordinated street system. Where, in the opinion of the planning commission, it is desirable to provide for street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended by dedication and improved to the boundary of such property. Where it is deemed necessary by the planning commission, such temporary dead-end streets shall be provided with a temporary turnaround having a roadway diameter of at least eighty (80) feet. 
9.  Private streets and reserve strips. There shall be no private streets platted in any subdivision. Every lot in a subdivision shall be served from a publicly dedicated street. There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to a street, except where the control of such strips is definitely placed with the community under conditions approved by the planning commission. 
10.  Street names. Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the names of existing streets. In no case shall the name for proposed streets duplicate or be sufficiently similar to existing street names, irrespective of the use of the suffix "street," "avenue," "boulevard," "drive," "place" or "court." 
11.  Curved streets. The intercurb radius shall not be less than three hundred fifty (350) feet for major arterial streets; two hundred fifty (250) feet for collector streets; and one hundred (100) feet for residential streets. Centerline tangents between reverse curves shall be no less than two hundred (200) feet for collector streets and one hundred (100) feet for residential streets. 
12.  Curb cuts. Curb cuts shall be prohibited within forty (40) feet of an intersection. 
13.  Curb radius. The curb radius at street intersections shall be no less than twenty (20) feet except that on major streets where the Georgia Highway Department Standards shall prevail. 
14.  Future development. Where the plat to be submitted includes only part of the tract owned or intended for development by the subdivider, a tentative plan of a proposed future street system for the unsubdivided portion shall be prepared and submitted by the developer. 
Section B. - Blocks. 
1.  Nonresidential. Blocks for other than residential use shall be of such length in width as may be suitable for their perspective use including adequate provisions for off-street parking and maneuvering space. 
2.  Residential. The length of residential blocks shall not, unless natural or man-made barriers such as streams and railroads dictate, exceed one thousand eight hundred (1,800) feet or a depth less than two (2) tiers of lots except where double frontage lots are permitted. 
Section C. - Lots and lot lines. 
All lots shall front upon a public street. Lot lines shall as nearly as possible be perpendicular to the street right-of-way lines or in the case of a curved street as nearly as possible perpendicular to the tangent of the street right-of-way lines. 
1.  Minimum lot size. Minimum lot size shall be as prescribed in the zoning regulations for the City of Nashville provided that they are served by a public sewerage system. Lots not served by a public sewerage system shall meet the minimum size requirements of the public health department. 
2.  Minimum lot elevation. The lot area contained within and contiguous to the building walls and for a minimum distance of ten (10) feet measured from all sides of said building shall have a minimum elevation of two (2) feet above the maximum flood stage of streams or canals in the particular area being developed based upon acceptable engineering procedure and approved by the planning commission. The said minimum elevation shall be subject to approval by the County Board of Health. 
3.  Building setback line. All building setback lines shall be as specified in the zoning regulations for the City of Nashville. 
4.  City limits. Lots shall not be divided by corporate boundary lines. 
5.  Corner lots. Corner lots shall be sufficiently wider and larger in area to permit the building setback line outlined above. 
6.  Double frontage lots. Double frontage lots shall only be permitted where it shall be found necessary to separate a development from all roads, major and secondary thoroughfares, or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography. Where a railroad or major or secondary thoroughfare abuts or runs through a portion of the subdivision, the lots abutting the railroad or major or secondary arterial shall have a minimum depth of one hundred seventy (170) feet to include a twenty (20) feet [foot] planted buffer strip separating the lots from the right-of-way. 
7.  Commercial use buffer strip. When a portion of the subdivision is to be devoted to commercial purposes or the subdivision abuts existing commercial development and when this commercial use abuts residential lots, a buffer strip shall be provided. Said buffer strip shall be twenty (20) feet in width and shall be planted with shrubs or trees at the same time the adjoining street is developed so as to provide visual screening. Said buffer strip shall be labeled as such on the subdivision plat. 
Section D. - Easements. 
Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided where necessary for utilities or drainage or for access to public facilities. All utility and drainage easements shall have a minimum width of twenty (20) feet, and all other required easements shall be of sufficient width to accommodate the use for which it is intended. 
ARTICLE III. - REQUIREMENTS FOR APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLAT 

Section A. - Preliminary plat. 
The preliminary plat shall meet the standards of design as set forth in Article II and shall give the following information: 
1.  The title block shall show the name of the subdivision; name, address, and Georgia registration number of the engineer or surveyor; and scale; 
2.  Date, north point, and graphic scale; 
3.  Existing contour lines dashed and proposed contour lines solid, and both shall be shown at two (2) foot intervals of elevation, based upon mean sea level (M.S.L.) datus. Accuracy shall be within one-half foot intervals; 
4.  Acreage of land to be subdivided; 
5.  Boundary lines of the area to be subdivided and their bearings and distances; 
6.  Existing and proposed easements and their location, width, and distances; 
7.  Existing railroads, streets, and rights-of-way on and adjacent to the tract and their names and widths; 
8.  The location of any streams, natural drainageways, other waterways which exist on the property, and names of adjoining property owners or subdivisions; 
9.  Proposed street system within the subdivision, with grades indicated if over 3%; 
10.  Proposed lot lines with approximate dimensions; 
11.  Blocks designated by letter and lots by number; 
12.  Location of existing utilities on and adjacent to the tract, showing pipe sizes for water and sewer lines; 
13.  Location and sizes of proposed utilities; 
14.  Sites, and their acreages, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for public uses. Sites, if any, for semi-public, multi-family, or commercial uses; 
15.  Minimum building setback lines from the street; and, 
16.  Copies of proposed deed restrictions, if any, shall be attached to the preliminary plat. 
Section B. - Preliminary approval. 
The developer shall prepare a preliminary plat as specified in this ordinance and obtain approval of it prior to the making of any street improvements or installation of utilities. Three (3) copies of this plat shall be submitted to the building inspector at least fifteen (15) working days prior to the regular meeting date of the planning commission. The planning commission shall call a hearing on the preliminary plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be sent by the secretary or chairman of the planning commission by registered or certified mail to the person or persons designated as requesting preliminary plat review and approval, no less than five (5) days prior to the date of the hearing. Within thirty (30) days after submission, the planning commission shall review the plat and indicate its approval, disapproval (listing reasons), or approval subject to listed modifications as a basis for the preparation of the final plat. Failure to act within thirty (30) days shall be deemed approval of the preliminary plat unless the developer agrees to an extension of time. Approval of the preliminary plat shall lapse unless the final plat is submitted within one (1) year from the date of preliminary approval. After action by the planning commission, copies of the preliminary plat shall be distributed as follows: Developer—One copy; building inspector—One copy; planning commission—One copy. 
Section C. - Physical improvements of subdivision. 
After preliminary approval of the plat has been given by the planning commission, the developer may then proceed to grade the streets and install all improvements required by this ordinance and any other applicable city ordinance. If the subdivider wishes to record the final plat prior to completion of the improvements herein required, the city commission may require, in lieu of such completion, the subdivider to file a surety bond or certified check with the city clerk to insure the actual construction of such improvements according to the plans and specifications approved by the planning commission within a period of time not to exceed two (2) years from the date of approval of the final plat. Such bond shall be in the amount of one hundred percent (100%) of the estimated cost of the improvement as determined by the planning commission and with surety and conditions satisfactory to the city commission. No building construction shall be permitted on any lot that does not comply with the provisions of these regulations, and no municipal utility service will be furnished to such lot. In any case where the commission does not require a bond for the improvements required herein, no building shall be permitted on any lot or in any area in a subdivision where the proposed construction will produce runoff or require utility services that affect other areas or lots located within or outside the subdivision unless a bond, in the amount of one hundred percent (100%) of the estimated cost is posted for the portion of the drainage or utility improvements that will protect the affected area. 
Section D. - Development required for approval. 
1.  Streets. 
a.  Grading and paving. The subdivider shall grade and pave all streets to their full pavement width as set forth on page 6 [of the original ordinance (Recommended Standards for Street Cross Sections)]. 
b.  Curb and gutter. The subdivider shall install curb and gutter and proper drainage as required by city specifications. 
2.  Monuments. Concrete monuments, four (4) inches in diameter or square, three (3) feet along, with a suitable center point shall be set at each street intersection on the street right-of-way line and at all points on boundary lines of the subdivision where there is a change of direction. Iron pins at least one-half inch in diameter and twenty-four (24) inches long shall be placed at all lot corners. 
3.  Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system, including necessary open ditches, pipes, culverts, intersectional drains, bridges, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all natural water flow and shall be of sufficient length to permit full width roadway and the necessary slopes. The size openings to be provided shall be determined by the acceptable engineering procedure but in no case shall the pipe be less than twelve (12) inches. 
4.  Water supply system. Water mains properly connected with the city water supply system shall be constructed in such a manner as to adequately serve all lots shown on the subdivision plat for both domestic use and fire protection. The sites of water mains, the locations and types of valves and hydrants, the amount of soil cover over the pipes, and other features of the installation shall conform to specifications and standards established by the city. 
5.  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewer lines properly connected with the city sewerage system shall be installed in such a manner as to serve all lots within the subdivision in accordance with specifications and standards established by the city; provided, however, that sanitary sewers shall not be required to be installed unless a public sewerage system is now or will soon be accessible to the subdivision in the opinion of the planning commission. 
6.  Drainage easements. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way which shall conform substantially with the lines of such watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream and shall be of such additional width or construction, or both as will be adequate for the purpose. 
Section E. - Final plat. 
The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and shall give the following information: 
1.  Date, title, name and location of the subdivision, graphic scale, and true north point; 
2.  Street boundary line, right-of-way lines of streets, easements, and other rights-of-way and property lines of residential lots and other sites with accurate dimensions to the nearest one-hundredth of a foot, bearings and deflection angles on all lines, radii, arcs, and central angles of all curves with readings to the nearest minute; 
3.  Name and right-of-way width of each street, width of each easement or other right-of-way; 
4.  Blocks designated by letter and lots by number; 
5.  Purpose for which parcels of land, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved; 
6.  Minimum building setback lines from the street; and 
7.  Location and description of monuments; 
8.  Names and locations of adjoining subdivisions and streets, and the location and names of owners of adjoining unplatted property; 
9.  Certification on plat of title showing that applicant is the owner and a statement by such owner dedicating street rights-of-way and any other sites for public use; 
10.  Certification on plat by surveyor or engineer as to the accuracy of the survey and plat; 
11.  Certification by the County Board of Health that water supply and sewage disposal are in accord with approved standards; 
12.  Certification by the City Clerk of the City of Nashville that the subdivider has complied with one (1) of the following alternatives: 
a.  All the improvements have been installed in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance and other applicable city ordinances; or, 
b.  A surety bond or certified check has been accepted by the city in sufficient amount to assure such completion of all required improvements. 
13.  Protective covenants or deed restrictions, if any, placed directly on the final plat or attached thereto in form for recording; 
14.  Certificate on the plat to be signed by the secretary of the planning commission when the plat has been given final approval by the planning commission. 
Section F. - Final plat requirements. 
The developer shall submit an original tracing drawn in black indelible drawing ink and four (4) copies or the final plat of the subdivision, or that portion thereof to be recorded and developed, to the building inspector, who will check and certify that monuments and completion of (or payment for) improvements are satisfactory. Such plat shall be submitted no less than two (2) weeks prior to the regular meeting date of the planning commission. The planning commission shall afford a hearing on the final plat. Notice of the time and place of such shall be sent by the secretary or chairman of the planning commission by registered or certified mail to the person or persons designated as requesting final plat review and approval, not less than five (5) days prior to the date of the hearing. Within thirty (30) days after submission, the planning commission shall review the final plat and approve or disapprove it (listing reasons for disapproval). Failure to act within thirty (30) days will deem approval of the final plat unless the developer agrees to an extension of this time. The tracing with certification shall be returned to the developer, plus one copy for filing with the Clerk of the Superior Court, and one copy for filing with the Clerk of the City of Nashville. The remaining two (2) copies shall be retained, one by the building inspector and one by the planning commission. 
Editor's note— A footnote in the original ordinance reads: "The illustration on page 23 presents the format which shall be followed for final plats." The note refers to the sample plat shown at the end of this article. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Section A. - Enforcing officer. 
The provision of this ordinance shall be administered and enforced by the city building inspector. His duties shall include: 
1.  Receiving subdivision plats; 
2.  Obtaining the approval of the planning commission of all subdivision plats and having the chairman of the planning commission sign said plat before being signed as approved by the zoning administrator; and, 
3.  Inspecting subdivisions for compliance with the terms of this ordinance and other applicable city ordinances. 
The city building inspector shall utilize the services of the nonresident city engineer when necessary. 
Section B. - Enforcement provisions. 
1.  Penalties for transferring lots in unapproved subdivision. The owner, or agent of the owner, of any land to be subdivided within the municipality of Nashville who transfers or sells or agrees to sell or negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat of subdivision of such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Berrien County shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by law; and the description by metes and bounds in the instruments of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. The city, through its attorney or other designated official, may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by appropriate action. 
2.  Erection of building. From and after the time when the platting jurisdiction of the planning commission shall have been established by virtue of adoption by the city of these regulations, no building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and line with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by said planning commission or with a street located and accepted by the city. Any building erected in violation of this section shall be deemed an unlawful structure, and the building inspector or city attorney or other designated official of the City of Nashville may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. 
Section C. - Amendments. 
1.  Planning commission responsibility. This ordinance may be amended from time to time, but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall first have been submitted to the planning commission for review and recommendations. The planning commission shall have thirty (30) days within which to submit its report to the city council. If the planning commission fails to submit a report within the thirty (30) day period, it shall be deemed to have approved the proposed amendment. 
2.  City council responsibility. Before enacting an amendment to this ordinance, the city council of Nashville shall hold a public hearing thereon; at least fifteen (15) days' notice of the time and place of which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
State Law reference— Amendments to subdivision regulations, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1216. 
Section D. - Violation and penalty. 
It shall be unlawful to convey title of lots of a platted subdivision or improve property by the construction of buildings on such lots, which has not been approved and recorded as provided in these regulations, except those parcels recorded prior to the effective date of these regulations. 
It shall be unlawful to record a subdivision plat, or once recorded, to make any changes thereon whatsoever which have not been reviewed by the planning commission and approved by the county commission in accordance with the provisions of these regulations. 
Each and every day's violation of any provision of this ordinance shall constitute a separate offense. 
A violation of these regulations shall be deemed a misdemeanor. Any person or persons, firm, or corporation or association of persons who shall divide and offer for sale any real estate in violation of the terms or provisions of these regulations or who records a subdivision in violation of these regulations, shall be punished as provided by law. 
Charter reference— Penalty for violation of ordinances, § 2-9(ww). 
ARTICLE V. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS 

Section A. - Conflict with other laws. 
When the provisions of this ordinance specify more restrictive standards than required by any other ordinance, the requirements of this ordinance shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other ordinance require more restrictive standards, the provisions of such ordinance shall govern. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1213. 

Section B. - Validity. 
Should any section or provision of this ordinance be declared by the courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, such declaration shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any part thereof other than the part so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
Section C. - Effective date. 
This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its adoption. 
Editor's note— The subdivision ordinance was adopted on March 22, 1971.
